Man oh man what a ride this one was. I chanced the trip to Tucson in my van that is edging ever closer to 300,000 miles, and that is about the payoff I got. 

The plot is masterful, the creature spfx are enormous, and rightly deserved the Oscar it won, and the best part? There are no oxygen destroyers, no fantasy fictitious scientific weapons. Nothing but real life applications such as ship cabling and explosive laden aircraft to employ in their frantic effort to take the monster down. And the cliffhanger of the dorsal fin shaped radiation burn spreading across the female protagonist's neck was the best part.
I sincerely hope that there will either be a direct sequel or that Yamazaki is tapped to do another kaiju film. I know I will be watching!

I wanted to wait a bit to make sure it wasn't recency bias, but I'm confident in calling Godzilla Minus One the best Godzilla movie in the franchise's 35+ catalog. With a gripping story of confronting and dealing with grief and guilt, the film utilizes Godzilla as a perfect representation of the internal and external chaos we encounter in life. Only by learning to value and cherish his own life does Kōichi find true purpose in living. Every human character is incredible in their writing and acting. Godzilla is a terrifying presence that capitalizes on every element that makes him a great antagonist. The low budget is often brought up as part of the mind-blowing realization that this movie fits right in with Hollywood's best effects, and for good reason. With Oscar-winning visuals, Godzilla Minus One is able to deliver one of the best stories of 2023 with a beautiful canvas in its presentation. Always thrilled to see the Kaiju genre be used so masterfully.

"THE BEST MOVIE OF 2023" IS ALL I CAN SEE WHEN I WATCHED THE MOVIE. It was perfect, every single bit of the movie. The atomic breath scene with the dorsal fins look very clean. I thought for a second when I watched the trailer that the city behind Godzilla really was destroyed, turns out I was wrong, it was just the best CGI I have ever seen. This movie shouldn't just deserve only 1 Oscar for just best action movie, It deserves best movie of the year.

I never expected even to watch another Godzilla movie, but luckily I read some rave reviews and went. This is one of the strongest recent movies from any country, and it may be the greatest giant monster movie ever made, in part because of the stellar special effects, cinematography, editing etc., but mainly because you care deeply about the human characters--all of them, including the nameless city dwellers who have to face destruction. There's a strong sense of tragedy that is right up front and really makes you love the characters, even the ones who seem at first to have been crushed by the war. They recover in moving ways. There's a moment early on when an embittered neighbor lady who has lost everyone in her family suddenly makes a decision to help an orphaned baby and the young mother who has taken her in. It sounds cheesy, but the actors make it work really well. At that point I realized this might be something special, and it keeps getting better and more gripping from there. There's another moment where a major character gets swept away, as if she were nothing, that made me sob loudly  in a theater for the first time in years. Great psychological depth throughout, and politically interesting in that its disillusioned heroes are striving toward a different form of heroism than the fascist wartime version of heroism as self-destruction.  If you want to see a convincing movie about the power of hope, watch this. Plus it's got the best little crying girl in movie history.

Godzilla Minus One is unequivocally and truly a cinematic triumph.  With a 15 million dollar budget we received a film with emotional depth, meandering characterization, beautiful visuals, and a masterpiece addressing significant themes of survivors guilt, PTSD, shame, and the human condition.  

I am blown away simply by how this can be one of the best action films of the year, perhaps the best Godzilla film ever put to screen, yet have me invested emotionally in so many of the characters. In typical fashion, this is not normally the case.

After reading and hearing all the hype for this film, I did want it to be in my top 10 of 2023 but, I don't think, by no fault of the filmmakers, that this is necessarily a movie that resonates with me.  And full transparency, perhaps my viewing experience and personal feelings towards the film may have been elevated if I'd watched it in a theatre with an audience. 

Nevertheless, this is (hopefully) a wake up call for Hollywood; great films can be made with amazing visuals and an encompassing narrative without the 200+ million dollar price tag attached.

I never thought I would walk away from 2023 with "Godzilla: Minus One" in the Top 3 Best Movies of the Year, but here we are and I'm still mad that it wasn't nominated for Best Picture.  Then again, the Awards never made sense anyway, nor have they ever mattered in decades.

One of the many things that has been missing from the Godzilla films, especially the ones made in the USA, are likable characters we want to see survive.  And this movie delivers that missing ingredient, along with great directing, writing, and acting.  Despite the film being in Japanese, I was able to understand and become invested in the lives of these characters in a post-WWII setting of Japan.  The main character has an arc that is in connection to Godzilla, and it's done very well.

Speaking of which, Godzilla himself makes a return to his roots as just being a monster of destruction, a true animal of nature on a bigger scale.  In what appears to be a mixing of previous films interpretation on the King of Monsters' origins, Godzilla is an ancient creature that mutates due to the radiation of the nuclear bombs dropped in Japan.  So, it's a mix of mother nature and man-made.  And the best part is that they made Godzilla scary again.  Which in turn makes you want to see the characters survive and win against the giant monster that is tearing apart their new lives that have been built from the ashes of a world war.

There's only a few flaws to speak of.  Some of the CGI isn't that good, although when it is good, it's really good.  There's a few edit choices that felt weird and some moments of dialogue that didn't feel right, but they're very few and far between.  Aside from that, it's a very solid film.

In all honesty, this just might be the best Godzilla film ever made.  It has emotional weight, a terrifying Godzilla, interesting and likable characters, and just an enjoyable experience.

I did not see the original color release of Godzilla Minus One, but friends had recommended I see it. Being over 70 years old, seeing the Minus Color version took me back to my Saturday afternoon matinees as a kid. It was very much like watching the old films I remember, but better.
Story and special effects where great!
cinematography was perfect. Action seen were well done and didn't feel overdone or cheesy.
One of the best Godzilla films ever. Got a great story with the humans and seeing Godzilla on big screen and hearing the iconic theme on it as well gave me goosebumps. Definitely a 10/10 film.
Excellent movie. Probably the best Godzilla movie ever made. Even if you're not a fan of monster movies it's still an excellent movie in it's own right. I hope they make more.
Great storyline, totally over my expectations!

Awesome movie! Though not really a fan of the "Godzilla" series (I might have seen one or two of them during my teenage years), or even of "monster movies" in general, I found this to be thoroughly entertaining from beginning to end. The story was more interesting to me than the monster itself — but various scenes involving the monster were quite compelling. Probably my favorite movie of 2023, even though I saw only this, the B&W, version in February 2024. It didn't really look "low-budget" to me the sets and cinematography totally brought me, making "suspension of disbelief" work in most every way except when it came to the monster.
My two sons and I love the movie even though want’t colors. Well at least has English sub.
An instant classic. Most likely the greatest Godzilla movie since the original. Monochrome was a nice added touch that made me possibly prefer it a smidge over the color version.
Surprisingly, one of the best movies I've seen this year!

I liked the Minus Color first as it captured the feel of post World War II era but my review for this movie is the same as my review with that version. Perfection from the characters, less but more effective & terrifying screen time for Godzilla, and an efficient way to spend the production budget that delivered so much more than the modern movies as of late. This deserves an award for that alone in Hollywood and they should really take notes. 5 stars.
Sensational - in color and b/w!

Dear Hollywood,

When making monster movies moving forward, you should really take notes from Godzilla Minus One. Keep the human drama front and center while also having it feel compelling. That way the audience can have characters to latch onto from start to finish, especially after sht hits the fan. Incredible VFX work made all the more impressive by the fact that this film was made on such a low budget. Magnificently scored too.
I loved loved loved every single second of it. Everyone need to go see it!

an absolutely epic, gritty, terrifying and beautiful thrill ride. one of the best films i've seen in a long time. this will be a timeless classic.

I've seen every Godzilla movie ever made. This is, hands down, the greatest one. It's an underdog story about redemption for not only the central characters but the country, as well. For some context, I missed the first theatrical release and saw the Minus Color version, after hearing about the nominations.  While I haven't seen it in color, to me the visual effects felt almost like a surreal blend of modern CGI and the goofy [to our modern eye] classic rubbersuit practical effects.  My gut is telling me it looks a lot more modern in color

That being said!  The film holds up to an award-winning rating even without relying on it's effects.  Characters were compelling, pacing and editing are extremely tight, and the entire thing feels like a timeless cinematic classic.  What if Godzilla but with Miyazaki levels of charm and Kurosawa levels of thematic depth?

Amazing . The most well thought out emotional and terrifying

Godzilla Minus One is ABSOLUTLEY the best Godzilla film in the franchise. And this is coming from a die hard Godzilla fan, collector and connoisseur. And just when you think it can’t get better. It does. Godzilla Minus One Minus Color is even better. The B&W version is simply magnificent. It’s like a whole new movie. Plays like a documentary of real events and ups the ante. Takashi Yamazaki outdid himself again. Not only should this win the Oscar for best VFX. It should have been nominated and should have won best picture. Brilliance.

I've definitely seen more Godzilla movies than the average viewer due to being friends with some absolute nerds (<3) so I can add my verification that this is one of if not the best Godzilla movie made. Typically I either find the destruction funny/lackluster or the human story unnecessary and dull, but this one aced both sides. The characters were each memorable and had excellent actors, they all contributed to give a strong sense of humanity in a time of crisis in a way that was deeper than previous Godzilla movies. This gave the destruction and devastating parts a truly epic feel that none of the characters just "walked off" afterward. This Godzilla monster caused a deep-seated dread in me while watching which is something this franchise is either really good at or fails terribly at. All in all a truly great movie.

I can't think of a better film to see in 2023 or 2024. From the beautiful visuals to the incredible story, everything in Godzilla Minus One is over the top. The story of the little girl, Akiko, is extremely sad, and even I was broken up over her situation. And the girl playing Akiko did a phenomenal job! This movie is "Jaws" meets "Jurassic Park" meets Akira Kurosawa.  This movie is amazing, and it shows what's wrong with so many American action movies.  The characters are so compelling!  Unlike so many "monster" movies, the story between the human characters is as important -- or maybe more important -- than the story about the monster.  This is a truly great movie.  My only criticism is that very occasionally some of the special effects are a little substandard, but given that the movie only cost $15 million, it is amazing.  Full of heart, a little humor, lovable characters and great action!  Go see it in the theater!

Definitely not a typical "Godzilla" movie and that's a good thing. This is more of a war drama following the traumatic experiences of a failed Kamikaze pilot along with the residents of a war-ravaged Tokyo. Godzilla is more of a secondary character and a symbol of another enemy combatant that allows retribution for our main character. Well written and a superb and refreshing "Godzilla" movie which does have plenty of action when Godzilla attacks with a couple of unexpected twists along the way.

For the first time since the original 1954 Godzilla movie, I actually cared about the human characters in a Kaiju movie. Unlike most other films about giant monsters, this one focuses more on the struggles of trying to rebuild after everything has been destroyed and it works beautifully. You really feel for these characters and you get tense and worry when the titular monster rampage is its way back into their lives. 
Godzilla himself has been taken back to his roots as the villain of the flick. He's a being of pure destruction, an unstoppable force of nature that can't be reckoned with and it's perfect. 
In my opinion this is by far the best Godzilla movie and it a strong contender for my favourite film of 2023.

I have been a fan of Godzilla since I was a little boy. I have seen the original 50's version all the way up to newer installments. This movie takes Godzilla back to its roots and makes the human side of the story on top of that very interesting. Normally I don't  care about the characters not named Godzilla this movie changed that. The writing was incredible, and the acting was top notch. That combined with the great special effects,  visuals, and action make this a great movie. I would say not only is this now my favorite Godzilla movie of all time, but also just a great movie in general. Even if you have no experience with Godzilla feel free to go watch this movie you will not be disappointed.

I have high expectations on this based on stories heard from the media. It was a bore-fest, highly predictable and histrionic. Ignoring the monster, I have to suspend believe when it comes to plot. How easy to find his damsel in decimated Tokyo, in the most populated city in the world? Easier than buying my coffee at Pret - at least there's a queue. He just walk right up to meet her in the middle of it all. A sailor walked into control centre to declare he's actually is the nation's top scientist? WTAF. 

I've grown up watching Japanese films. Never have I expect the acting is still this OTT. It is distracting. It is one dimensional. Every actor has the same expression. The worst is Kuranosuke Sasaki. He becomes hysterical with every scene, even at dinner. Muscle clenged, eyes bulging and mouth wide ajar, its excruciating to watch. 

It is cheesy, it is predictable and Godzilla is so prosthetic. Expect the expected. Reminiscent of 90s Hollywood big budget disaster films from Michael Bay and Roland Emmerich minus the slow motion. Its the same - everyone survives, everyone claps in the end. Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V.

Absolute masterpiece!  The storytelling in this movie was amazing and it tugs on the heart strings throughout.  You would expect that a movie BARELY featuring Godzilla wouldn't really entice fans of the series, but the monster is so well done and its rare appearances so spectacular that you're just waiting with bated breath until the next time he does pop up on the screen.  Godzilla was always intended as a cautionary tale about the danger of nuclear weaponry and this movie returns to the series roots in glorious fashion.  They did a tremendous job of conveying the raw destructive power of Godzilla, but do yourself a favor and see this in theaters so you can truly experience it in all its glory.  My ONLY complaint is that they changed Godzilla's iconic roar.

There are good moments, but I was intensely aware of the editing process and the lack of sense in the sequence of scenes. The last scenes should've been the most intense but it was so disjointed it felt like random events from different movies. The character's motivations didn't follow the facts laid down by the film and then their actions didn't follow their motivations as laid out by the film. The character growth was undermined by the deus ex machina undoing meaningful choices. The monster design face looks like a sea lion with a big clown grin and for some reason they gave it human eyes with big stone eyebrows that say "angry" which is just too goofy. The body is identical to Barney character in the children's show. It stands and walks like a fat naked toddler taking its first steps. The boats behaved like cars, they simply parked in rows in the ocean. The main character was the only character with any depth. The monster was a slow lumbering moron then a whiplash fast clever opponent, but then a lumbering moron again.

This is the best Godzilla film ever made and the best film of 2023. First and foremost, Godzilla is SCARY. This is the most menacing depiction of the legendary Kaiju, and two sequences in particular had me gripping my seat. The visual effects are breathtaking and better than anything Hollywood has put out in years. Godzilla's main city attack MUST be seen on the biggest screen possible - the mayhem, destruction, menace, and sound should be experienced in IMAX theaters. All that aside, the heart of the film is the characters. This is the only Godzilla film to date in which the characters are so well developed that you care about each and every one of them. The finale will tug at heart strings, and I heard some sniffles in the theater. When the credits rolled, applause erupted with myself included. 

GODZILLA MINUS ONE - An epic, astonishing cinematic achievement, the best Godzilla film of all time, and easily the best film of 2023. Go see it!!!!

Godzilla: Minus One proves just how solid direction and a darker tone on a character as old as him, can still be entertaining and thrilling after all these years.

The movie exceeds in it's visuals and atmosphere to sell you on the setting of a Post-War Japan which is now under threat of a greater evil. When Godzilla is on the screen the scenes are great, they're engaging and tense which is exactly what you want with a movie like this. Alongside with a set of characters with some decently good performances to boot.

Where this movie lacks, is the character development being quite minimal for everyone besides the central character. This isn't an automatic issue, but these additional side characters felt more like props to the main character rather than individuals with their own morales and personalities. It comes across as the movie as a whole contains only 3 characters, Shikishima (the main character), the side characters and Godzilla.

Godzilla just being a force of nature with a clear murderous intent to cause death and destruction everywhere he goes, it's shallow but works for the style of character he plays in the movie. And the side characters play nothing more than the prop that pushes Shikishima forward. There's some small exceptions to this but they're never shown more than a few minutes of screentime and automatically conclude with blending into the same formula everyone else plays into. It's extremely jarring how lacking these side characters feel, when we get so many scenes around them. 

This added onto how predictable and cliché the movie ends, if you knew how it was going to end when watching you were likely correct. It doesn't ruin the experience and I'll happily rewatch it when it gets posted on streaming or a physical copy release. However the movie had so much potential to be so much more, yet ended up being a pretty inoffensive and by the books movie.

One which I'm happy people enjoy, but I think after almost 70 years. We deserve so much better.

A story about love, loss & redemption. You wouldn’t think I’d be talking about a Godzilla movie but indeed we are. Godzilla returns and this time he’s menacing, terrifying and absolutely unstoppable. An extraordinary film that taps into the heart of what it means to be courageous in our darkest hour. Extremely well developed characters that take us on this journey, often times forgetting we’re watching a Godzilla movie. Incredible scenes of destruction balanced with an emotional story and unforgettable characters.

Minus one is a masterpiece. 

It stands right along other greats like Shin, 84, and Biollante. The characters are well written and do a great job of grounding the story. Goji is definitely CGI, but he looks scarier than ever before. The effects were good (not as polished as the Legendary movies) as was the story. Godzilla Minus One is an unexpectedly amazing film with deep character and story development. While you want to see Godzilla decimate cities and wreak havoc, those types of scenes are used sparingly in Minus One. However, when Godzilla makes appearances , it has maximum impact. Less is definitely more. The human characters and stories are the heart of this film, which truly make it stand out. It is a story of survival, rebuilding, gaining hope and losing hope. It is also a movie about PTSD, relationships, and camaraderie and altruism. Godzilla just happens to be the antagonist and an excellent one at that. Go see it, even if you're not a monster movie/Godzilla fan. You will not be disappointed unless you have absolutely no empathy or feelings. The acting, character development, and story are that damn good. With a budget of 15 million, this movie easily equals and easily surpasses many Hollywood blockbusters with 200 million dollar budgets or more.

Absolutely spectacular!! Seriously. But I have to include a warning: this is NOT classic Godzilla. He’s scary as hell!! Think twice before bringing your children to the theater to see this, because more than a few parents had to escort their crying kids out of the showing I was at!

Shikishima, a failed kamikaze pilot, struggles to come to terms with his cowardice and building a life in bomb damaged Tokyo.   Godzilla doesn't help.

This is what I've wanted every time they announced a new Godzilla film.   And they always failed me.   The series of silly heroic Godzilla films of the 60s and 70s were entertaining as a kid, but when I was older I realized what a quality film the original was.    This film honors that initial portrayal and instead of giving us lackluster humans we don't care about (such as in the recent US films) we are given sincere portrayals representing citizens and soldiers to which we can relate.   Found family.  Survivor's guilt.   Hope.  Redemption.  These themes are explored in such a way we are made part of the characters' journeys.  

Highly recommended

Not only is Godzilla Minus One a spectacular monster movie, but it also manages to cross genres and give us an excellent World War II movie. Told from the perspective of characters grappling with the aftermath of WWII, over the course of the story they struggle to find their place during the period of Japanese reconstruction. How can life ever return to some semblance of normal with cities in ruins, families destroyed, and a new threat already on the horizon? The story is heartfelt and surprisingly moving. By the end you care so much for the lives of the characters, lending refreshing gravity to the threat of the monster. This is my favorite movie of 2023 by a long shot, highly recommend checking it out.

This throwback to the origins of the Gojira legend leaves every Hollywood version in the radioactive dust.
Cloverfield is the only American monster movie that comes close in terms of emotional resonance, but even that relied heavily on narrative gimmickry.
What makes Godzilla Minus One stand out so much is good old fashioned storytelling. While it takes it's time establishing it's characters and setting, it never drags due to the standard of writing and acting. This milieu of people eking out an existence in post-war Tokyo is interesting enough without a monster attack, so when the carnage does start, we genuinely care about these characters.
If only Hollywood could put away their DEI manuals and concentrate on good writing like this, the cineplexes wouldn't be clogged with so many empty spectacles.
Exactly what I wanted going in. I kept myself from watching any trailer or synopsis.

A fantastic movie!  You're cheering for Godzilla and cheering for the better people as well.   Great story telling!  The characters are relatable and you feel for them. It's nice to see Godzilla back.
Best Godzilla movie ever!

As someone who despises the Godzilla films of Legendary from the past few years, this was refreshing as heck. The humans actually feel important, and they make actually logical decisions on how to handle said kaiju, and have proper character development. The writing in monsterverse was abnormally stupid, I must admit (they had a kaiju-destroying bomb but they preferred to abduct kong from his natural habitat and destroyed a whole city, like what?), but it's good to see that the humans here actually seem like they're doing what they can as they learn about Godzilla, and the post-war storyline behind the movie was done very well. The only downside to this movie would be that Godzilla, as a CGI monster, had very blocky movements at points when the shots were afar, and the water CGI was also a bit meh, but to be fair, its budget was 15M, which is especially impressive since Godzilla vs Kong was literally 10x that much and it was pretty bad.

Godzilla Minus One was such a wonderful surprise of a movie. I went with my 13 year old twin boys and even they loved the emotional storyline and the suspense in addition to Godzilla destroying things, which is really what they came to see! The subtitles did not get in the way of enjoying this movie. You didnt even notice it because the acting, story and action were just so captivating. I also thought that the innovative and scientific way they came up with trying to defeat Godzilla was so refreshing and a welcome intellectual departure from just using guns and bombs, which is typically what you see with monster movies. You will not be disappointed. And the orchestral classical musical score was so outstanding! Its what made the suspenseful parts suspenseful and was the perfect complement to the magnitude of this movie. The score was even something you would want to listen to on its own. Hands down, the best movie Ive seen in a long time and unquestionably the best movie of the year. Bravo Godzilla Minus One! Bravo.

Better than I was expecting. This was a compelling story with characters I cared about. Godzilla -1 went well beyond the standard monster vs the good guys flick. No bs western preaching. Just a good story.

The first Godzilla movie, from 1954, depicts a post-war Japan devastated by war and nuclear bombs.
"Godzilla Minus One" takes place mostly in the late 1940's Japan and plays on the same theme. In fact, Minus One borrows heavily from the early Godzilla movies, and its great.

The protagonist, Kōichi Shikishima played by Ryunosuke Kamiki, is ridden with survivor's guilt. He's kind of mopey and somewhat dislikable. It begs the question of whether, we as an audience, should appreciate his yearning for a heroic sacrifice. On the other hand, the movie's heartwarming qualities comes from the supporting cast, humanizing the victims of this new threat.

Beyond its visuals, themes, and great soundtrack, "Godzilla Minus One" managed something amazing; It rejects traditionalistic values and brilliantly exclude any involvement from the military or the government from the problem solving. 

Most definitely one the best movie in the franchise, if not of the whole genre.
I did enjoy the movie, even though it was in Japanese.  I did not like that I had to read to understand the movie
The movie was amazing to watch, it always had me on edge. I also prefer that it is in Japanese with English subtitles.

This is an excellent movie. It avoids all the cliché stuff that you see in Hollywood productions of Godzilla movies. Great development of characters and you never know the fate of certain characters. The only minor gripe is the slow pacing in certain places. Overall a great change to how a Godzilla movie was made compare to U.S. ones.
A fantastic drama with compelling character development and emotion, with the Godzilla action and spectacle being the cherry on top.
A well-written, powerfully-acted, emotionally-gripping historical drama... that happens to have a nuclear-powered dinosaur in it!
The action, the story, the setting, the characters, the emotion. Well rounded film that over performed any expectations I had going in. This is the best Godzilla film I've seen and I've seen many.

This was arguably the most predictable movie I've ever seen. Halfway through the movie I could tell you exactly how it was going to end, and knowing how it was going to end made the lead up to the final scene a complete slog. They spent way too much time building up to a climax that everyone in the theater knew was coming. It's like the script was written by an AI who had spent the last 10 years learning all the action movie cliches. I had really high hopes and walked out feeling like I had wasted two hours seeing a movie I'd already seen a hundred times before.

As a fan of the MonsterVerse films, this is everything that I have been missing and so much more. Going into it I knew the Godzilla aspect of the film would be wonderful, but the emotional depth and tone of the story made for such a captivating film. My only problem with this sort of film is the redundant nature of making up a new way to kill Godzilla and Godzilla being able to withstand it. With that being said, it was better that the film was mainly, human, character development led. The interconnectivity between the visuals and the story made for a smooth 2 hour runtime that keeps you entertained the whole time. Moreover, the fact that the film was created with just $15 million is absolutely insane and you could tell so much effort/work was put into the final product to create an enjoyable fan experience. Basically, it was a lot more meaningful/heavy (in terms of subject matter) than I was expecting it to be and I'm ashamed I waited so long to see it!

"Godzilla Minus One: A Thrilling Cinematic Experience!"

"Godzilla Minus One" is an exhilarating cinematic journey that captivates audiences with its stunning visuals, powerful storytelling, and mesmerizing action sequences. As a devoted fan of the Godzilla franchise, I was thrilled to witness this latest installment that takes the beloved giant monster saga to new heights.

What sets "Godzilla Minus One" apart is its ability to balance the awe-inspiring spectacle of colossal battles with a poignant and compelling narrative. The filmmakers have masterfully crafted a storyline that not only showcases epic showdowns between larger-than-life creatures but also delves into the emotional depth of the characters involved.

The special effects in this film are nothing short of phenomenal. The CGI work is seamlessly integrated, bringing the monstrous creatures to life in a breathtakingly realistic manner. Every clash, roar, and destruction scene is delivered with such detail and grandeur that it immerses the audience in the heart of the action.

Furthermore, the cast's performances are commendable, with each actor bringing authenticity and depth to their respective roles. The human element in the film is as crucial as the giant creatures themselves, adding layers of emotion and empathy that resonate throughout the storyline.

The pacing of "Godzilla Minus One" is another aspect worth praising. The movie keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish, delivering adrenaline-pumping sequences while also allowing moments of quiet reflection, creating a perfect balance between excitement and contemplation.

I also appreciate how the film pays homage to the classic Godzilla legacy while infusing fresh and innovative elements into the narrative. It's a testament to the filmmakers' dedication to honoring the franchise's roots while offering something new and captivating for both longtime fans and newcomers alike.

In conclusion, "Godzilla Minus One" is a triumphant addition to the Godzilla series that exceeds expectations on multiple fronts. With its remarkable visuals, engaging storyline, and heartfelt performances, it's a must-watch for anyone seeking a thrilling cinematic experience. Whether you're a die-hard fan of the franchise or simply a lover of epic monster movies, this film delivers on all fronts and leaves a lasting impression that won't soon be forgotten.

This is not a Godzilla film in the way I think most people will assume it to be. It is an examination of grief, sacrifice, and perseverance in the years immediately following the devastation experienced in post WWII Japan... and Godzilla. 

That's absolutely a reductionist view of the titular monster; he is the physical representation of the evil of man that would bring about such devastation against whom the humans must defeat for hope, not only in survival but in a better world, to possibly be restored. 

Ok, that might be too lofty a description also, but frankly, it's hard to find the words to accurately describe this film and all that it achieved. I am not a Godzilla fan. I've seen the newer ones and they're ok. The idea of a giant ramping monster especially once it starts fighting other rampaging monsters always sounded silly to me. I understand its origins were born in making sense of the horrors of the atomic bomb and fears for humanity after its creation, but mostly its appeal has been extremely limited for me, especially after 1998. I'm sorry but ew. 

BUT. 

Godzilla Minus One is just a GOOD F***ING FILM. I cannot say enough good things about it. It is 100,000% worth paying to see in the theater, and there's just not a lot of movies out these days that you can really say that for. It truly deserves more than just an Oscar for best VFX which it has been nominated for. Writing, directing, cinematography/art direction, best actor, and yes best film. 

Go see it in theaters now while you can.
Awesome!!!!! Best Godzilla flick ever!!!!!

It did not talk about Godzilla lore, and with all the drama, they didn't even kill Godzilla. The story and acting were amazing. Even with reading subtitles and not understanding the actors actual speech, you can feel the emotion and sincerity in their voices. Due to its length and the amount of drama I don't think it's one that I will want to watch as often as other godzilla movies, but the post-WWII tie-in is compelling and adds so much to the depth of the story.

Don't miss this! Godzilla Minus One is a movie about people you'll care about ... that just happens to have a monster. It serves as a thoughtful companion piece to Oppenheimer that presents the Japanese perspective of the atomic bomb ... while also wrestling with the consequences of war, deftly navigating the stages of trauma, guilt, grief, and redemption. It measures up to prime 1970s-1980s Spielberg for the masterful way it anchors amazing action and cinematic virtuosity with believable humanity. What a surprise! My favorite movie of 2023.
Great story. Unexpected ending. Has you on edge from begging to end. 10/10 recommend.
The best Godzilla ever. Great effects, fantastic acting, a moving story, and that classic Godzilla theme never gets old.
Incredible. Next level vfx, set design, costumes, performance. B Genre with A+ technical prowess 🇯🇵

Godzilla Minus One tells an intriguing and at times heart wrenching human story set to the backdrop of early post World War II. The monster itself delivers all the punch you would hope for as a modern version of the classic Godzilla we know and love. Every scene is a work of art. A bit of humor is interspersed to keep the mood from trending to dark. I usually hate CGI but found the effects in this movie felt more practical than computer generated. This wild ride is what going to the movies is all about.

I haven't been to the cinema since 2018. And there hasn't been a single film I've been enticed to see in all that time. Hollywood is, and has been, dead to me.

But then Godzilla rumbles into town and shows me that Cinema isn't dead .. it's just moved HQ.
This movie was spectacular .. and I'm not talking just about visual effects (which are pretty much a given in this day in age). The story is tight, compelling .. wastes no time and yet breathes with incredible ease. Letting you get to know the characters without any ham-fisted plot dumps. It's not possible to watch this movie without tearing up even just a little. You WILL get a lump in your throat and you will be grateful for it!

I'm not particularly into Godzilla or monster flicks in general .. but I have to say I am grateful to some friends who convinced me to go and see this film. I had seen reviews of it saying it was brilliant so I was sure it would be an enjoyable film .. but seeing is believing. This film absolutely deserves a 100% rating .. and it's very heartening to see it get 98% from both the professional cretins (critics) and audience alike.

So bravo to Toho studios .. you guys knocked it out of the park!

I have never had such a powerful experience in a theater. Immediately engaging, and every moment is potent until the last credit leaves the screen. Did not know me and my wife would be crying tears throughout for a Godzilla movie. This is maybe the most important movie to come out in my lifetime. As a descendant of Japanese people who endured WWII it was a deeply moving and overwhelmingly spiritual experience. I will never be the same.

Please go and see this movie, in theaters if you can.

Godzilla shouldnt be that good. Gave you all the monster destruction you expecting and then hit you in the feels with themes of guilt and redemptions and Japanese Reconstruction after WWII. One of my favorite movies of the year.
Great Godzilla movie!  Saw it in Japanese with subtitles and enjoyed that.  Great acting and story line.

Great storytelling. Good combination of analog and digital effects. Characters I cared about. Great character arcs. Essential universal human values honored, cherished and celebrated. Evolution of a family and nation coming together through hardship with love. Great depiction of a terrifying Godzilla.
This is an absolute masterpiece of a movie and a must see, as a Godzilla fan I can say this movie is worthy.

This film, besides the 1954 original, is the best Godzilla film I've seen.  I highly recommend seeing it on the big screen.  This is Godzilla at his finest moment and most poignant.  Godzilla, as a symbol, has never been more terrifying.
The best Godzilla film of all-time. Normally I don't care about the people in a monster movie but this time I did. Incredible story telling, and a great monster movie!
Great movie one of the best Godzilla movies I seen in a while
best movie i’ve seen this year

Really enjoyed it. The film takes its time developing the characters and Godzilla's mystic isn't killed with cheap attempts to humanize it or by overusing it in scenes. They also limit the amounts of time they show its full length and size which is how you're supposed to treat a giant monster in a giant monster movie. Score was amazing and no wasted scenes. By far my favorite film of the year and I appreciate both bomb scenes in this one over Oppenheimer which was beautiful but slightly underwhelming especially after the first time you watch it. Anyways go check it out folks.
Left me a bit more optimistic about the monster movie genre returning to its roots.
An emotional, human story with devastating destruction and tense Godzilla fights.
It had an absolutely horrible story and had more screen time of a baby crying then godzilla.

My first Godzilla movie ever! Came with my sister and we had zero expectations and was just enthralled from beginning to end. It's not just a monster movie. At its core it's a movie about people and how they deal with collective trauma. I can't spoil but its definitely the best movie that came out this December, if not this year. I can't believe I'm saying that for a supposedly monster movie, but I am.

this movie was overall the best movie i have ever seen in my entire life!

This movie was true to the originals and particularly appreciated its raw look at post-war Tokyo.  Excellent film!

Stunningly superb!  A surprisingly moving human story of duty, shame, redemption, and tenderness, all embedded in a monster movie, of all things.  Highly recommended.

When I was a kid my parents had a VHS of Godzilla's Son that introduced me to the Godzilla universe. I watched that movie a hundred times. Going in fairly blind to Minus 1, my expectations were tempered as recent Hollywood versions have been a bit too childlike for me (I had enough of goofy Godzilla). This film is a work of art, with real characters to root for and a monster that's actually terrifying. I hadn't experienced this much fun in a cinema in a while. You can sense the filmmakers were so committed and inspired. My love and nostalgia of Godzilla is alive and well!
Me encanto la trata de la pelicula, es muy interesante y tiene muy buenos efectos

So good! I loved absolutely everything about this film. I grew up amidst the monster craze of the 1970s, and Godzilla was my first favorite. He looks and sounds great in this film. The human cast is great as well and the story is deep and heartfelt. Awesome!
Loved everything except the main character.

Easily the best Godzilla film I've ever seen. I cried like, multiple times. Godzilla was legit terrifying.

I actually cared about all of the human characters, something that hasn't happened since the first 15 minutes of Gareth Edwards Godzilla.

After this, I think Americans should just leave Godzilla alone. Let Japanese creative teams handle it, the American versions are nowhere near this quality.
This was the perfect Godzilla movie for the modern age! So glad I went to see it!

Honestly best movie that toho has released (In my opinion). It makes the human characters actually interesting and entertaining. Godzilla is terrifying and everything he does is horrifying and the fact that he's a reflection of the atomic bomb that destroyed Japan is amazing. The CGI and everything graphical is great and makes Godzilla look real. Honesty there is probally more to say but that's all I can give this movie credit.

It's a perfect Godzilla movie for the new age. The blend of practical effects and special effects was seamlessly done and visually excels above most Hollywood productions. The human story was thrilling and every time Godzilla was on screen, it invoked the terror you'd expect.

To me, this movie is an outstanding tribute to the classic Godzilla movies!  There were so many moments that caused a "flashback" to the originals, brought back to life in such a spectacular way! Really hoping they do more films like this adding Mothra, King Ghidorah, Rodan, Ebirah, KIng Caesar etc.
Wow, it was amazing! Never thought I’d cry watching a Godzilla film. It’s that good and probably one of 2023’s best movies! Do yourself a favor and go watch it before it leaves the theaters.

As a Godzilla fan, this movie is everything I wanted. Great action and interesting human characters. This movie awe you with the terrifying sequences of Godzilla and brings you to tears with main characters. A perfect balance.

One of the best depictions of Godzilla. The movie portrays the struggle of the common folk against insurmountable odds. Minus One deserves your attention for it is an triumph.

"Godzilla Menos Uno" es una epopeya cinematográfica que fusiona la grandiosidad de los monstruos clásicos con una trama intrigante. Con efectos visuales impresionantes, la película cautiva con su intensidad y creatividad. Cada escena es una oda al espectáculo visual, llevando a los espectadores a un emocionante viaje a través de la destrucción y la redención. Una obra maestra moderna que redefine el género de kaijus con su enfoque audaz y una narrativa que deja al público anhelando más.

es una película que se sumerge en la temática de redención y nacionalismo de manera abierta y sentimental. La narrativa persigue una historia de redención en la que Kōichi y Japón son protagonistas. La película no presenta a Godzilla como una criatura amigable, sino como un monstruo enojado e incomprensible, que parece no estar motivado por el hambre, el deseo o la venganza. Además, aborda temas de trastorno de estrés postraumático (TEPT), vergüenza y culpa del superviviente, ofreciendo una exploración optimista de estos problemas. En resumen, es un homenaje verdadero a la película original de Godzilla, con temas postguerra y un enfoque en problemas mentales y emocionales.

I was genuinely having a hard time believing the good reviews this movie was getting, and keep in mind this is coming from a hardcore Godzilla fan. So I was hearing a lot about this movie ever since it released and I finally came to watch it tonight. And I have to admit, I was worried it was going to be a disappointment. However, now having sat through the whole film, I can safely say it was quite the opposite of that. From beginning to end, I was hooked. That's something I never get from one of these movies. Like I mentioned before, I'm a fan of these monster flicks. But I've never given a monster movie a good rating only because I'm biased towards it. This changed everything.
I don't even know where to start. The beginning sequence. The ending sequence. The family dynamic. The score. The VFX. The main character. And of course, Godzilla himself. I actually care about the characters here, and it was heartwarming seeing this disjointed family come together. Some might find this all a bit slow, but personally I was invested. I was never left wondering when the next Godzilla scene will take place. And of course, we have to talk about that. Godzilla in this movie is just, wow. He was not there to play games. He was not there to save the world against some world-ending threat. He was just a monster, there to cause destruction and make the characters we know suffer. Legitimately, this was the only time I remember wanting the humans to win and not the big old kaiju. There might be mixed feelings on his screen time, though. Some say he's got plenty to offer, while others say he's in it too little. My take is that if you take the term "screentime" literally, then yes, that lacks a bit here. But the thing is, he always feels like a threat. You can feel his presence. He's just lurking in the ocean, waiting for the next time to strike. And when he does come on screen, my god. He is terrifying and you will not be disappointed, even if it's a brief scene.
Many of us can agree he is more of a side character, which I can imagine a few people getting upset about. But what about the center of the story? The main character, Shikishima, is a failed kamikaze pilot. He deals with survivor's guilt and has trouble coming to the realization he's even alive. He's convinced he died back in the war, and his newfound life was just his last dream. I'm not going to spoil anything, but his character felt very complete and well written. His character development was straight up beautiful. The other stars of the show are a little girl, her adoptive mother, and a minesweeper crew. They all have their good moments and have a lot of heart and personality to them. 
This movie also has a very good score. It has hope, it has fear, it's haunting, it's grandiose. And of course, classical. The original Godzilla theme, is of course, used in the film. It is remastered, but it still keeps the feel and terror of the 1954 suite.
This movie cost less than 15 million dollars. Look what they did with that money. The average MonsterVerse movie costs around 200 million dollars. Look what they did with that money. The fact that the CGI cost just a mere fraction of a Hollywood movie and looks just as good, if not better than one, is mind-blowing. There are just shots where you are staring at Godzilla and his imposing figure. It really is mesmerizing. This should be the standard for modern movies.
So in my conclusion, this is my personal favorite Godzilla movie by far. It's a beautiful story that you will get lost in. I can only really see one small flaw with it, and that's how it is a bit overacted in some parts. But the more I think about this movie, the more I appreciate it. It's almost perfect. I came out of the theater only a couple of hours ago and I already feel like seeing it again. I can see myself rewatching this over and over again for years to come. And this review is not biased at all, I am giving my true and honest opinion. You will probably have a good time watching this movie even if you are not into kaiju movies. If you are into the goofy, more dumb fun monster flicks, I can't guarantee you'll like this film as much as others and I have. If you like more grounded, serious, but still light-hearted movies, I highly recommend it. Go see it before it leaves theaters, I'm honestly very happy I got to see it on the big screen because it truly was a big experience. I'm so happy about this film's success and I can only imagine how embarrassed Hollywood is right now. They really need to wake up.

LOVED this movie! A perfect tribute and celebration of the franchise 70-year history! A very serious treatment, with excellent casting, direction, and production. These are real characters with an emotional story to tell. Everyone involved in this project contributed masterfully. The original score is perfectly performed and aligned. The subtitling was also executed tremendously well (not a distraction of your attention - you stay immersed in the action and drama). HIGHLY recommend for every Gojira fan and absolutely anyone who has ever wondered what the "big deal" is. This is not camp, cheese, or silliness - it's an excellent homage to the franchise roots and reintroduction for current and future generations. Thank you TOHO and everyone involved!

This was an outstanding movie, and a good alternative to the more over the top shenanigans of a Legendary Godzilla movie.  That's not a knock on those movies, I love the role they play also.  After Shin Godzilla, I was disappointed that it didn't get a sequel because it was so different and explored avenues that the franchise never had done before. I was really pleasantly surprised by how much I liked the human characters in this movie.  For once I wasn't always anticipating the next Godzilla sighting.  That's not something you can usually say about a Godzilla movie and it wasn't that Godzilla wasn't exciting and incredible... it just was a great overall experience.  

You don't need to be a Godzilla fan to love this movie.  That's the biggest compliment a movie like this can earn.

What a great Godzilla movie! It recaptures the feel of the original where Godzilla is an existential threat to the people of Japan. Also no suit-nation here this Godzilla is executed with modern special effects that are scary and real. Godzillas initial appearance and indeed the whole movie is probably too intense for younger viewers. This is an adults Godzilla. And his appearances are rationed enough that you dont get used to his size and destructiveness. And since it is a period piece (set in the post war 1940s)It is also a window on postwar Japan and the hardships endured by its people. I find it better than the latest Warner Bros monster universe movies. You may genuinely be moved and cheer by the end. And yes its subtitled but it is not to me overwhelming and nor did it take me out of movie. I happy I go to see it on the big screen!

In short, Minus One is my favorite movie of the year, and possibly the best Godzilla movie I have seen. 

It does a fantastic job of creating characters that actually feel real and meaningful to the story. Where previous Godzilla movies have often had shallow or underwhelming characters that serve to bridge the gaps between scenes where the titular monster is on screen, Minus One has established a set of characters that genuinely feel like the primary focal point of the film. The characters are well-written and feel so legitimately human that they steal the show from Godzilla - something that works wonders for the pacing and narrative of the movie and makes Godzilla's actions feel much more meaningful. 

In addition, the visual effects of the movie feel phenomenal. Godzilla movies have a history of requiring some considerable suspension of disbelief to make the monsters feel real; this is a trend that I expected to see carried on into Minus One, especially with its incredibly small budget. However, the look of the movie is nothing short of phenomenal. I never felt like the movie was ever cutting corners or trying to keep its effects within budget. The shots of Godzilla and the general feel of the movie as a whole feel very similar to the original Godzilla, but put together in a way that holds up to the modern cinema standards. 

All together I personally feel like this is the best movie I've seen this year, and highly recommend anybody - not just Godzilla fans - to watch this entry into the series.

I have given this a top rating and like all reviews, it is entirely subjective but I would like to offer some context first. 

As a Gen-X'r, I have grown disillusioned with movies over the past decade at least to the point where until seeing this film, I haven't been to the cinema for over six years. I know there has been good films out there over but having seen so many underwhelming movies over the years, I have turned to apathy due to fear of being let down again and just not bothered. 

I had heard a lot of positive things about Godzilla Minus One as a fan of Japanese entertainment and had decided to give it a chance once it was released here in the UK but when it did, I had got cold feet and decided not to bother. However, I had went to the cinema the other day to see this on an impulse and was blown away by it. 

I'm not going to do a in-depth review of this movie as other people have done such a better job but I want to describe my feelings about this, why I had given it such a high rating and why I have renewed faith in blockbusters now. 

It is simple that at the heart of this film, is not a monster going on a rampage but a disaster movie where a group of people are thrust into the destruction and mayhem caused by this monster and do their best to survive it. 

As the film focuses on the characters rather than overblown CGI and action sequences, I was sucked into the world of these characters, their fears, their problems and yes, their hopes for survival and it made me care for them  and become overcome by their emotional struggles. 

Sure, some of the heart string pulling has been done plenty of times before and parts of it is corny but the story is so strong, the direction brilliant and the acting amazing that it didn't bother me and I let myself get carried along on the whirlwind of emotions that the film threw at me. 

As I had mentioned at the start this is purely subjective and  if this film had come out at a time where the overall quality of movies is more superior as to what it is now, the film may not have had the same effect on me but it isn't and because of this, I feel justified in giving it such a high rating. 

I know people may be put of because it is a monster movie but I had said, it is more than that and is highly recommended to watch.

I've seen this movie four times and I now am confident that it is the best Godzilla movie ever, surpassing the original. The story is one of personal honor and family, built around The King's appearance near Japan at the end of World War II. The acting is superb. Everything is treated seriously it's not like the cartoonish Godzilla movies of the 1960s. It offers a new perspective of Godzilla's threat: several instances show him menacing ships at sea. The CGI images of him raising hell on land are magnificent. And there's nothing quite like watching half of a Navy destroyer coming flying across the screen after Godzilla has ripped it apart and thrown it away. It's not simply an exceptional Godzilla movie. It's not simply a good science fiction movie. It's an outstanding movie period....

While I typically haven't gone to movies with subtitles, I was very happy that I chose to go to this one. I'm a big fan of movies of this genre, so I may be a bit biased, but the film stitched together a great storyline with wonderful graphics. There was not too much CGI that has made other movies seem cartoonish, the acting was appropriate and when our dear friend Godzilla is on-screen, it is truly intimidating and jarring.  The dialog is just enough to become engaged with the characters and feel for them as they pursue their goals. The subtitles are well spaced that you don't feel you're reading versus watching a movie. Ultimately, the two hours flew by and I would highly recommend this film.

Godzilla Minus One is a standalone Godzilla movie from Japan. It brings the franchise back to its roots where Godzilla is a monstrous force of nature, an allegory of war. While I do love the Western Monsterverse franchise, it is mostly for seeing Godzilla or Kong fight another giant monster. The writing and characters have never been a highlight in that universe. Does Godzilla Minus One deliver more than the Monsterverse?

Firstly, Godzilla's design is spectacularly frightening, his roar is menacing and his heat rays are some of the best and most impactful blasts I've seen from Godzilla. Every Godzilla action set piece is terrifying and tense. I love how these sequences are filmed from a human perspective, so we get to truly see the scale and how dangerous Godzilla is. The music score by Naoki Sato is phenomenal! His subtle orchestral score compliments the scene and illustrates the pain and struggles that Japanese people in WW2 went through. He then uses a strong powerful orchestral score for Godzilla to show how he is bringing back the pain again. His use of the Godzilla theme is effective every time. The visuals and cinematography look great while the CGI can be a bit wonky sometimes, for the most part, it looks good. Especially for Godzilla who looks awesome. It is honestly astounding how good this film looks for a movie under a $15 million budget.

What this film succeeds at in comparison to Western Godzilla movies, is having compelling human characters that you truly care about. The characters are all suffering in some way from World War 2, whether it is PTSD or loss. You're watching these characters try to overcome and push through this dark period. The camaraderie and family dynamic is at the core of all the characters and it is extremely touching to watch. I was especially rooting for the main character to get development just because I wanted to see him be happy. That is why for the first time, I was rooting for Godzilla to lose as I didn't want to see our characters get hurt. I also love how the story doesn't shy away from the negative aspects of Japan's government during WW2. The human drama is wonderfully engaging and can even tug at the emotional strings which is such an achievement in a Godzilla movie.

Overall, Godzilla Minus One is not only a terrific Godzilla movie, it's an amazing movie period. This movie shows that you can tell a great story with great characters and still have Godzilla as a major element. Not only that, you can still make a great looking movie with good CGI on a low budget. The CG in this movie looks better than a lot of these western movies with 200 or 300 million budgets. Godzilla Minus One is must watch and I highly recommend going to a theatre near you to experience it in all its glory!

Godzilla Minus One is quite simply the best Godzilla movie to date! It handles the same themes as the 1954 original, but better. This film addresses the human cost of war, defeat, and tragedy with a level of passion and honesty that the original was simply not allowed to.

Characters were actually compelling, writing was quite good, and the appearances of Godzilla were awe-inducing and even a bit frightening at times. Puts Hollywood to shame, and with far less of a budget than any dedicated blockbuster. Must-see.

A Japanese historical WWII drama which happens to feature a giant lizard.  The plot plays out as expected but has a more traditional style, focusing on the characters as they struggle to deal with the aftermath of the war and a new threat of the giant monster.  Cultural issues such as the virtues of honor and survivors guilt are well portrayed by the varied cast of characters, but it does make it a bit slow to get going and some scenes felt labored.  Godzilla itself looks impressively menacing and the special effects and scale of destruction invokes shock and awe.  Great use of music and an emotional ending, even if it was a bit too happy.

No Japão pós-guerra, devastado pelos ataques aéreos, vai se reconstruindo, até que uma criatura gigantesca emerge do fundo do mar, despertada pelos testes atômicos no Atol de Bikini, e o Japão está no seu caminho. Decididamente, os Estados Unidos não conseguem desenvolver filmes envolvendo os famosos kaijus e, em especial, o Godzilla. Tivemos vários filmes americanos com o monstro, desde a iguana anabolizada do Roland Emmerich, até este último no encontro com King Kong. Agora temos aqui uma película que custou US$ 15 milhões e tem uma CGI muito melhor que todos os filmes americanos com o Godzilla, principalmente porque as cenas com efeitos são de dia e não de noite. Outro ponto: a participação dos personagens humanos. Os filmes americanos enchem com personagens desinteressantes e sem nenhuma empatia com o público. Este filme tem um personagem principal, que tem todo um arco bem desenvolvido. Você se interessa por ele, ele te emociona, mesmo em momentos em que parece manter as pessoas afastadas dele. O seu entorno também possui personagens secundários que nos emociona como a Noriko de Minami Hanabe, a vizinha dele,ou os seus colegas do barco caça-minas onde ele vai trabalhar. E todos são bons atores. Takashi Yamazaki fez um filme de kaiju, com excelentes personagens, críticas sociais tanto ao Japão da época quanto a política dos Estados Unidos, mais preocupado na Guerra Fria com a União Soviética, excelente elenco, CGI admirável, boa reconstituição de época. Você teme pela vida das pessoas mesmo que sejam apenas figurantes. Há destruição. E, principalmente, há o Godzilla, como imaginamos que ele seria se existisse. No final de 2023, uma grande e agradável surpresa e uma lição para os americanos.

One of the best movies of 2023, and probably the best Godzilla film. Learning more about Godzilla's origins, symbolism, and his past representations has made me love this film even more. If I had seen all of the Godzilla movies I believe that this would still be on top. This movie doesn't even feel like a Godzilla movie, it feels like an interpersonal drama featuring Godzilla. It has some of the most beautiful, gripping, and heart reaching character/relationship development that I have ever seen and it truly drives the movie. It is the strongest part of the movie, yet it doesn't sacrifice the quality of the action. Godzilla's presence alone is the most menacing and intimidating I  have ever seen it, and his destruction is unparalleled, making him the first Godzilla to actually scare me. From the little that I have learned about Godzilla movies, this truly feels like it does justice to the monster's original purpose and symbolism. His shear viciousness and relentless power is chilling, and this paired with the next level character development achieves something that no other action movie has for me: it made me truly worry for the main character's lives. The only criticisms that I could barely conceive would be that it is very corny and on the nose with a lot of its dialogue (but it's a Godzilla movie so that is expected), and some could argue that there are some SLIGHT pacing issues. But overall, the pace feels very fluid and the 2 hour run time suits the movie perfectly. I will forever be astounded that this movie was executed with a 15 million dollar budget, especially because Godzilla Vs Kong, the last Godzilla movie to come out, had 140 million dollars more to work with, and it still wasn't as good in my opinion. Go see this movie, on my second watch it was sad to see that there were only two other people in the theater, give this movie the love it deserves, you will not regret it.

I don’t normally give reviews but this movie was outstanding. It was not your typical Godzilla movie. The mostly old school Godzilla scenes with modern but subtle technology was a nice change. 100% recommend this movie to any and all. I also found myself getting choked up a few times.

Easily the best film I've seen all year. I'd seen the trailer which looked great and then heard all the good reviews for it on Youtube and the internet, so I decided to watch it if and when it was released here. 

It was brilliant. Its more accurate to call this a film with Godzilla in it rather than a Godzilla film with side stories. Its more about the healing and redemption after the trauma of war and loss. The importance of being part of something whether its your family, your crew or the taskforce. 

The acting is great, you feel for these people and want to see some sort of happy ending for them, and instead of cheering Godzilla on, this time you want the big guy to lose.

The actions scenes are epic, whether is the first attack on their boat to the final battle. The Ginza scene is particularly jaw dropping. The special effects were for the budget absolutely top notch. Its hard to believe a film like this was made for only $15million, especially when you consider how bad some of the multimillion dollar flops like the Marvels or the The Flash looked and they cost nearly 20 times as much.

Watch this film, you will not regret it. My film of the year easily.

I would have never dreamed I'd be engaged at this level in the human side of a Godzilla film! By far my favorite Godzilla movie of them all and I've seen almost all of them!

A visual feast that lacks emotional depth and strong character development. Godzilla Minus One forgets the cardinal rule show, don't tell as the film develops its characters mostly through dialogue. Excessive exposition nullifies the impact of emotional moments since the audience is told the emotional state of a character instead of showing us through the actions of a character or through dialogue with subtext. Nevertheless, the eponymous Godzilla is beautifully realized through stunning effects and creative cinematography. If you prefer the power of western storytelling, the plot may not grab your attention, but the well-choreographed action and destructive capabilities of Godzilla will keep you somewhat engaged.

The human story was moving and unexpected, showed the real side of PTSD and loss, and actually made me cry more than once (I don't cry at movies). The animation of Godzilla is phenomenal, and the new effect of his nuclear breath was shocking, intimidating, and incredible. 2023 finally allowed for a serious Godzilla movie that does Godzilla, his power, his terror, his majesty, his destruction, and his horror all true justice. Having such a fantastic and moving human story only elevated this movie more.

Scripted with creativity and heart, taking place in beautiful scenery and sets, engagingly shot and accompanied by a phenomenally dreadful and energetic score, this addition to the franchise delivers lots of moving movements in the storyline as well as drastic action and tension as soon as the infamous lizard himself steps onto the scene. Ryûnosuke Kamiki's performance is shockingly touching, especially during his emotional outbreaks, while Godzilla is designed and written in a successfully horrifying way. The movie starts with a surprisingly strong scene, starring a truly scary juvenile Godzilla and a cast that reacts to him accordingly in authentic panic. The characters are interestingly written, especially the protagonist, and mostly well casted, including Sakura Andô which was a smart choice for her role. Godzilla's writing and design is terrifyingly crafted, sharing some similarities with the ones from the older movies. The atomic breath and following explosion scenes are intense theatrical feasts, with its sound design and visuals. Even though there are such great qualities to offer there are some disappointments as well. A scene which seems to be some sort of an american broadcast with a montage of clips felt really out of place and totally unnecessary, adding nothing new or interesting to the plot which the audience didn't know already. There is also another montage including the main characters passing some time together which could have been handled better, with a tone that would have fit the rest of the movie and a better soundtrack. Now coming to the obvious; the movement animations on the fully grown Godzilla are too often stiff and puppet-like when he doesn't attack or swim. One scene in particular stuck with me, in which the hero flies his plane into the monsters mouth, however Godzilla stays completely frozen and motionless, even with the massive impact. That's a bit of letdown but it essentially doesn't ruin the authenticity of the monster. The effects and the rest of the production are absolutely impressive for the budget of only $15M, nonetheless.

Recently, a friend's wild enthusiasm drove him to embark on an 8-hour journey to catch a movie. Whether he's a die-hard franchise fan or just slightly eccentric, I couldn't resist the intrigue. The film in question, "Godzilla Minus One," was slated for a limited release in select theaters, and my friend insisted it was a cinematic gem.

Returning from his trip, he couldn't stop praising this $15 million-budget marvel, claiming it outshone its predecessors. Intrigued, I joined a group of nine for a screening, only 2-hours from home the following weekend. Despite the theater being less than ideal, the film's magnetic pull kept me glued to my seat for the entire two hours.

This unexpected gem didn't rely entirely on explosive special effects. Instead, it unfolded as a gripping narrative, a rare throwback to when stories took precedence. The action, though loud and at times comical, seamlessly wove into the tale of overcoming adversity. "Godzilla Minus One" became a story about hitting rock bottom, descending even further, and then summoning the will to rise again.

My friend's insistence that Godzilla symbolizes more than a monstrous entity proved accurate. Godzilla is a metaphor for any catastrophic event, encouraging me to focus on character dynamics rather than awaiting destruction. I found myself emotionally invested, shedding a few tears along the way (I wasn't the only one).

Whether or not you're a Godzilla enthusiast, "Godzilla Minus One" deserves the acclaim it's garnered. Take a chance; the worst-case scenario is ten bucks out of pocket and a couple hours of your time. At best, you'll find yourself labouring over the right words for your first ever review, compelled to share the magic.

Chris Yuill

What an absolute delight, Godzilla Minus One is one of the hits of 2023 so far. At its heart it truly is a classic Godzilla movie, from the Godzilla walk and its classic backing track however its the story between the make-shift family that stars as the movies true heart and soul of the movie. The connection between the characters and their history is so gripping and emotional, to the point that its hard to not root for our main cast. Shikishima's story is one of tragedy yet hopefulness, with so many plot points that were littered throughout the movie, payed off in such powerful ways, the character has his flaws which makes him more relatable and you feel the weight behind every decision he must make in the movie. I love that we stayed focused on this make-shift family for the entirety of the film, no side missions, we are always following the next phase of the group. I could ramble on for paragraphs about just how great this movie is. Thank you Japan, you have given us masterpiece in storytelling, acting, character-work and dread, an absolute piece of art.

If you have ever seen a Godzilla monster movie on TV as a kid, you will surely love this homage from Toho movies. The drama! The Plan! The Plan B! The Plan B Backup Plan! The wavy-haired scientist! The stodgy Naval captain! The emotionally-wracked failed Kamikaze pilot! The war-torn Tokyo! The wounded warriors volunteering ONE MORE TIME!

There are no plot twists. At. All. But man, what a trip down memory lane! Just pure fun, from beginning to end.

My only gripe is the unexplained janky movement of Godzilla at times, almost like he's taking a page of out Shin's book. But it's very easy to overlook that considering the quality of the rest of the film.
Overall, an absolute stunner of a film; by far the best representation of Toho's creation to date.

Definitely a builder - first 20mins felt like a slowish Japanese re-hash of Jurassic Park, (island and all). You know, the bit where everyones fave T-Rex dino turns up and starts eating folk one half at a time. But slowly you do get to care about the lead character and the rest of the cast, and then (about half way) it gets rather juicy. 
Lots of stomping, chomping, and pointless merciless killing of innocent folks (random ones, and maybe even ones you like); along with general giant monstering about and destruction. Nice satisfying ending - although not really anything unexpected - just Jurassic Park on steroids with an added heat ray. But there's nothing wrong with that. 
Better and certainly more satisfying than most of the other - more monied - studio offerings of late. Well worth watching despite having to tackle the subtitles, which I'm usually one to avoid. To be fair and honest the plot is not very complicated, so you really don't need to read the subtitles too much.

To be honest I've never been a fan of Godzilla. I wasn't very excited to go see this but I was won over within 10 minutes.
I love a good story and that is exactly what this movie gives. The characters were written so beautifully. The acting is great. The CGI is great. The cinematography is stunning. And Godzilla is finally a creature that is capable of utter destruction. 
I think anyone can appreciate this film. It's very possibly the best movie of 2023.

The best movie I've seen all year and will probably be better than anything coming out in the next year as well. I came in expecting another fun but not so great big lizard movie, but was pleasantly surprised by the greatness of this movie. The movie left me speechless walking out of the theater. The problem I always have with movies like this is they don't have meaningful characters and they become the main focus. The characters in this movie are relatable and feel real. The relationship between the main protagonist and Godzilla shows the tenacity of humanity even when in the face of something devastating. That's what makes this a good film is the writing and the overall story, but it doesn't stop there. Godzilla in this is by far the greatest iteration of the character. When I say it makes the humans seem doomed to fail it's an understatement, Godzilla is a truly monstrous presence that seems to be unfazed by anything anyone can throw at it. And that's leaving out the greatest part, THE ATOMIC BLAST is amazing. The most beautiful, devastating, and powerful atomic blast ever seen on screen. The sound cuts out for a second before the blast hits and then you hear the explosion. The suspense it creates even though you know what is coming keeps you on the edge of your seat. This movie is amazing, spending money on a movie in theaters is a waste of it's not this one. When it gets a Digital release I will be the first one in line to buy it, and same with a physical release of it gets one.
These actors deserve Oscars.

Absolutely the best Godzilla movie ever, rivaled by only the best of the classics, but not only is it one of the best Godzilla movie; it's the best kaiju movie, and one of the best movies I have ever seen. That is all not to say that the namesake himself is not just as spectacular; Godzilla. Godzilla is a true monster. There is no explanation as to why he's here, or why he's the way he is, and there doesn't need to be. Goji is here to destroy, and claim the world as it's own. So once more: if you haven't seen this movie yet; GO WATCH IT.

The most exhilarating Godzilla rendition of its time explodes off the screen thanks to its beautiful cinematography, unique effects, and pitch perfect script. About as close to a balancing act as possible, Godzilla Minus One never feels like it's cheating its iconic central figure or the humans characters that inhabit the rest of the story. Different themes weaved into the subtext of the movie make it perhaps the most universally resonant monster ever made. This is a must see that will leave viewers moved, devastated, and blown away.

This is a tough review for me. I rate 3.5 But My family rates 4.5.
