The focus of the movie was the character development and story of the people and their backstory. I was very impressed with the appearance of Godzilla. He looked AMAZING!!! FYI: this is a full subtitle movie. No English dubbing is available.

No ano em que celebramos os setenta anos do icônico Godzilla, Takashi Yamazaki entrega uma obra cinematográfica excepcional que mergulha nas raízes do filme original de 1954, revitalizando a essência do Rei dos Monstros de maneira magistral. Como diretor, roteirista e responsável pelos efeitos especiais, Yamazaki não apenas homenageia o legado de Godzilla, mas também incorpora elementos narrativos, visuais e sonoros que o elevam a um novo patamar.

A direção de Takashi Yamazaki é uma aula de maestria cinematográfica. Sua habilidade em utilizar recursos visuais para transmitir a intensidade emocional dos personagens é notável. A fotografia do filme não apenas captura a destruição causada por Godzilla, mas também proporciona uma imersão profunda nos traumas pós-Segunda Guerra Mundial. As referências a eventos reais, o contexto político e as situações vivenciadas pelos personagens adicionam uma camada de realismo e robustez à trama, enriquecendo a narrativa de maneira única.

O próprio Godzilla, apresentado de maneira mais ameaçadora e assustadora do que nunca, emerge como o verdadeiro protagonista da destruição. Seu visual imponente e os sons impecáveis que o acompanham criam uma presença palpável, mesmo quando fora de cena. A imponência atinge tal magnitude que sua presença se torna uma espera angustiante, aguardando o momento em que ele ressurgirá para incendiar o Japão mais uma vez, deixando-o em um estado negativo devastador. Gojira se manifesta em um estado frenético e raivoso, lançando todo seu ódio impiedosamente sobre os japoneses, que se veem impotentes diante dessa força de destruição em massa.

A destruição que ele causa, seja demolindo prédios ou aniquilando navios, é retratada de maneira violenta, transmitindo um peso visceral a cada golpe e pisada que ressoam como uma catástrofe iminente. O raio atômico, carregado como um dispositivo nuclear, é uma obra-prima visual, com seu paralelo eloquente com uma explosão atômica, proporcionando uma experiência cinematográfica extraordinária. A carnificina provocada por Godzilla neste longa é avassaladora, ele arrebenta tudo em seu caminho, deixando uma trilha de destruição que eleva a intensidade e a grandiosidade do filme a níveis épicos.

No âmbito humano, o elenco entrega performances impecáveis, mergulhando os espectadores na pele dos personagens e fazendo com que sintam visceralmente os traumas persistentes da guerra. As pessoas são atormentadas por suas decisões, e essa angústia é personificada de maneira brilhante por Ryunosuke Kamiki como Koichi Shikishima. Seu arco emocional, lidando com o conflito de ter sido um piloto kamikaze sobrevivente, é comovente e angustiante, com momentos em que ele expressa sua dor gritando e chorando, buscando desesperadamente um sentido para sua vida.

A adição de Minami Hamabe como Noriko Oishi traz uma dimensão emocional adicional à trama. Noriko, ao aparecer na vida de Shikishima, revela que há algo que vale a pena lutar, ao carregar consigo uma criança órfã dos bombardeios no Japão. Shikishima decide acolher tanto Noriko quanto a criança, encontrando assim um motivo renovado para continuar sua luta. Esses momentos de conexão humana em meio à devastação proporcionam uma profundidade emocional significativa à narrativa.

O elenco como um todo está impecável e épico, transmitindo de maneira convincente a aflição e o desespero de viverem novamente outra crise. Cada ator contribui para a complexidade emocional da história, tornando tanto as crises pessoais quanto as batalhas com Godzilla igualmente intensas. A interação entre os personagens cria uma teia emocional que eleva a trama a patamares mais elevados, garantindo que a experiência do espectador seja não apenas de admiração pela grandiosidade do Rei dos Monstros, mas também de empatia profunda pela resiliência e coragem daqueles que enfrentam não apenas a destruição física, mas também os fantasmas do passado.

A ambientação do filme é um triunfo, ressuscitando o Japão do final dos anos 1940 com detalhes minuciosos. As sequelas visíveis nas cidades, a desorganização pós-guerra e o contexto geopolítico são elementos fortemente integrados à trama. A trilha sonora de Naoki Sato, especialmente com faixas como Fear, Confusion e Resolution, cria uma atmosfera assombrosa que complementa magistralmente as imagens na tela. O uso sábio do tema clássico de Akira Ifukube adiciona uma camada adicional de nostalgia e grandiosidade à experiência.

Em resumo, "Godzilla Minus One" (2023) emerge como uma jornada épica e emocional pelos 70 anos do Rei dos Monstros. Sob a direção magistral de Takashi Yamazaki, o filme revitaliza a essência do original de 1954, mergulhando em narrativas envolventes, visuais espetaculares e sonoridades impactantes. O próprio Godzilla assume uma presença ameaçadora e assustadora, com seu visual imponente e sons perfeitos que transcendem a tela. As cenas de destruição, marcadas pela violência e peso visceral, destacam-se, enquanto o raio atômico se torna uma obra-prima visual, culminando em uma carnificina impactante. No âmbito humano, o elenco entrega performances impecáveis, liderados por Ryunosuke Kamiki e Minami Hamabe, explorando os traumas pós-guerra com uma profundidade emocional comovente. A ambientação detalhada do Japão no pós-guerra, a trilha sonora arrebatadora de Naoki Sato e a integração inteligente de elementos históricos adicionam camadas de realismo à trama. "Godzilla Minus One" é uma experiência cinematográfica que transcende as expectativas, combinando grandiosidade, emoção e reflexão sobre os 70 anos de legado do Rei dos Monstros.

What's Godzilla doing in a historical drama?  The special effects are maybe half a notch below state-of-the-art (although the handling of Godzilla's heat beam is the best I've seen).  Nothing about this movie disappoints.  Perhaps Hollywood should send  some of their movie-makers to Japan for refresher lessons on how to make good movies.  Go see it!

Wow. This movie is very professionally made. Not something I would usually like, but it is excellent. It is also a very thinly veiled look into the soul of Japan, post WWII, and the crazy radical nationalists who brought their country to ruin. The producers largely stay away from pointless after-the-fact commentary on the atomic bombs themselves and move to how Japan found itself where it did in late 1945, but at the same time preserving the honor of the ordinary Japanese people, who were disgusted with where their fascist leaders took them. With no one else to help, the spirit of the Japanese people rise to fight a "real" monster, as opposed to the false enemy their nationalist government forced them to fight against in WWII. An indictment against pointless self-sacrifice but deeply committed to giving everything you have to save others, their community, and their common welfare is a refreshing theme. This movie says it is not about "me." It's about us, with refreshing honesty. Although tastefully done, it is a warning about the rise of radical nationalism today, especially in America. This is an excellent movie for our time, thoughtful, respectful, and deeply Japanese. Plus, the subtitles are easy to read for those who don't speak Japanese.
Fantastic movie! There are a few minor things that prevent it from being a perfect 5 for me, but this is really close to be the Godzilla movie ever!

With a heart as big as its kaiju, this new entry into the Godzilla series breaks all conventions and defines amazing standards for a new era of Toho's original monster while staying true to the series' origins. Though here you connect with the characters in less than 2 hours to the point of tears, both happy and sad. Not to mention a wicked G design that perfectly blends old with new. Here's to 70 more years of Godzilla! ... Minus Color proves that this is not only a landmark monster film but also a true emotional rollercoaster when the shades change.
This movie is absolutely incredible, especially with the budget that they had. This movie puts modern Hollywood to shame, and is a must watch for any casual moviegoer.

The Cinematography, SFX, CGI, and Sound are all done brilliantly and confidently. doest make this city destroying threat feel too big to overwhelm an intimate film about PTSD, Survivors guilt, and community. Even if it's a bit shallow, the heart is still there. And you can tell the filmmakers had just as much fun making the film as you will have watching it. Horrifying Kaiju and all.

The first Godzilla set the standard, and Minus One is essentially a remake of the original. Most remakes don't hold a candle to the original, but this movie improves every plot hole, and actually delivers on the terror that the original intended, but couldn't quite reach because of special effects limitations when it was made in 1954. It also delivers more emotional impact from the characters and storyline, and Godzilla is in the film at a higher percentage of playtime than the original. I imagine Eiji Tsuburaya is beaming with joy from the other side at how they brought his original vision to life like he intended it to be. Best Godzilla movie and design to date.

In this cinematic masterpiece, humans take center stage, with Godzilla serving as a captivating accent. The profound survivor guilt experienced by the protagonist is truly moving. This rendition of Godzilla is a force to be reckoned with—powerful and terrifying. The destruction of Ginza is nothing short of nightmare fuel. In essence, don't miss out on what can be hailed as the most meaningful Godzilla film ever crafted.

With a perfect balance of epic destruction and compelling human drama, Godzilla Minus One is superior to anything Hollywood could produce this year, as it works as a creature feature, war drama, and disaster movie. Not to ostracize those who don't like this movie..  but you have to be a troll, poorly traveled, or just not very smart to not be able to recognize how good this Japanese film is. The sound is brilliant... as well as the silence when needed.
What they did with less than 15 MILLION is unreal.
This should serve as a wake up call to Hollywood.  We don't need your bloated, expensive product anymore with poorly written characters no one cares about.  How can Han Solo die and you don't care?
Answer: the writing is just that bad... they should have stayed on strike.  Foreign films are up to the challenge of entertaining us and not lecturing us about how bad we are as people.

Godzilla has been Reborn!!!!

Originally Posted on LetterBoxd: This is my third time watching this film, and I… I think this has literally become my favorite movie of all time…

I love everything about this film. How traditional it is in story telling.

The elements of the films characters work so well.

Noriko as this element of balance and happiness within Koichi's life. Mr Nobu as the wisely veteraned ex-military specialist. And the Doc and Kid as the kindly side characters, one representing the old generation and the other (kid) representing the new generation. Both treated with respect.

When Godzilla arrives to threaten these characters, you feel the weight of their terror. Largely thanks to Director Takashi Yamazaki, who wrote, directed and led the VFX for the movie! His incredible character writing is what elevates this film from being a good one to being a great one.

This film isn't just good Godzilla action, this is just good storytelling.

I'm about to dive into spoilers so fair warning!

When Noriko presumably dies, everyone feels the weight of her death. She wasn't just a throw away character i. The plot, you actually feel the weight of her death because the characters feel it. And through the characters emotions, Koichi especially, you can feel the air in the room be lost.

This personalizes the fight between Godzilla and Koichi Shikishima, and what makes it so impactful. He's not just fighting to redeem himself anymore, he's fighting to protect what he still has left, and he's even prepared to die for it…

Very heavy stuff.

The ending of the film being happy and Noriko turning out to be okay doesn't undo any of that. And the way Godzilla is Defeated is both thematically satisfying and a book end to the story.

Hear me when I say that the battle between Koichi Shikishima and Godzilla will go down in history as one of if not the most iconic moment in a Godzilla Film. A David and Goliath moment to inspire future generations.

At the end of the day, this film is absolutely worth your time, and everyone who has seen it like you will all agree, this is not just one of the best Godzilla Films ever made, but one of the best Kaiju films ever made. And makes me hopeful for the future of cinema…

This is finally the Godzilla film I'd been hoping for after so many others had at best fallen short of what I felt was the proper treatment for this franchise, or at worst missed the mark completely. It strikes the difficult balance of achieving a competently compelling human plot and characters, while still delivering on the high intensity action and spectacle that audiences crave from the genre. 

The use of Godzilla as an allegory for the inescapable trauma and PTSD that completely engulfed the Japanese population post WWII was perfectly woven in, and in my opinion paid true homage to the very real human psychological origin and idea behind the creation of the monster itself. 

The cinematography and CGI work was very tastefully done, and had far better visual impact onscreen than many other recent more heavily funded offerings in the genre, proving that a budget is not necessarily a barrier to a true quality product for audiences.

Proving that it's indeed very possible to make a seemingly one dimensional franchise break out of previous limitations, I was overall refreshed and entertained by this entry, and hope to see more from the director and studios responsible. Definitely a worthy offering that stands in contrast to today's current often abysmal menu of theatrical release fare.

I took my son to see this movie and honestly didn't know anything at all about it, other than that it is a Godzilla movie. I was expecting a fairly mindless monster movie and was totally blown away by what this movie actually is. The original Godzilla movie interwove themes of the anxiety that Japanese people felt over their defeat in WWII, the fact that they were the only people to ever suffer an attack by an atomic weapon, and the betrayal many people felt they had suffered at the hands of Japanese leadership. This movie forefronts all of that, going back to what Godzilla originally was. Godzilla (the monster) is central to the story, as an implacable and all-but unstoppable force, but the centerpiece is a very beautiful and occasionally sad human story. For the first time in a long time, Godzilla the kaiju is actually scary, the people seem very human, and the story is absorbing.

A triumph!! Incredible VFX. The movie itself is stunning to view. The Japanese subtitles don't matter. You still get emotionally attached to these characters and root for them towards the end. Godzilla Minus One : Plus Two, Subtract a Fraction of Eight    RATING:: A-

So anyway, I kinda got on a bit of a Japanese kick lately because I knew this new Godzilla movie was coming out and I thought, "I never saw that last one Toho made, Shin Godzilla, I suppose I should look that up." It was only available on Crunchyroll, an anime streaming service for nerds. I'm certainly not a nerd, but they had a free one week trial.  One week was plenty of time to watch just one Godzilla movie and then cancel the anime channel. No need to waste any more time there, I'm not one of those weird anime people.

After I finished Shin Godzilla I was like, "Well, I've still got like a week anyway, maybe I'll try some of these weirdo shows with talking bananas and purple hair, just to see and then I'll cancel it." By the end of the week trial I had watched all kinds of random things from Chainsaw Man, to Sgt. Frog, along with the oddly named, "That One Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime," and my favorite, "My Hero Academia." I was literally in the middle of episode 36 when the trial went out and I was yelling at the tv to let me watch more of this Asian crack!  It didn't listen.  It chided me.  Like that time at Panda Express when I asked for a large cup of orange sauce to go.

So, aside from now contemplating my hair color and life choices, I watched Shin Godzilla from 2016.  It was terrible.  I'd rate it a D.  The online description literally says, "In the film, politicians struggle with bureaucratic red tape in order to deal with the sudden appearance of a giant monster that evolves whenever it is attacked."

… Are you serious!? Politicians struggle with bureaucratic red tape? A Godzilla film? That's your opening statement?  I don't know what they were thinking. Who wants to watch politicians do anything, unless it's slowly melting "Terminator 2" style into a lake of lava? That film felt like they had to make it or they'd lose their rights to Godzilla, like Fox's last Fantastic Four movie.  A description for a Godzilla film should be like, "in ancient Shogun Japan, three war-torn Ronin Samurai seek revenge against the newly summoned demon beast, Godzilla, who ravaged their master and village!" Make him only like 30 feet tall and have all kinds of oni and supernatural things. It shouldn't be, "Godzilla is sued by the people of Tokyo in this four hour courtroom drama." Although a Godzilla courtroom drama does sound kinda cool now that I think about it.  Godzilla is up on the stand and the district attorney is grilling him over property damage and Godzilla panics and eats him.  Then that's another charge against him, so he charges up his blue-gamma-blast and the judge tells him he's over-ruled!  This just writes itself.

So, because of the horrible Shin Godzilla, I was a bit hesitant to head out to Godzilla Minus One, but I was bored and wanted to go to the theater and I have an unlimited pass and so I did.  I was very glad I did!  I enjoyed it a lot!  For this 38th Godzilla film, they decided to go back to its roots.  It's set in the late 1940's just after WWII.  It's about a kamikaze pilot who ran from his duty.  He battles his own demons as a result of this choice and has to find his way back to honor.  This is the focus of the film.  So, you may be saying, "But I thought it was a Godzilla film?!  I thought you mocked the other one for being about politicians!"  Sure, but this one made it interesting, it was much more personal. And a redemption story of a coward pilot is much better than twenty politicians debating whether to setup a special committee to investigate a possible monster attack.  This was a character study with Godzilla representing inner demons of humiliation and dishonor. It worked for me.  If they made a Godzilla movie about me, the beast would represent the regret of eating at Taco Bell for a month straight and what I did to my master bathroom.

That said, it won't work for everyone.  It is Japanese made, not American made.  It is all in Japanese with English subtitles.  It only had a $15 million budget.  It is a period drama.  It harkens back to the original 1954 Godzilla film.  If you are just looking for a big lizard kicking over skyscrapers, this isn't the movie for you. You're probably looking for GodLizzo. If you want a cool Japanese film with a more deeply felt character arc that happens to be set around a big lizard destroying Tokyo and the Pacific, then this is the film for you.

I would recommend seeing it with the proper expectations in place.  It was cool to see it on the big screen with Godzilla huge and angry.  The whole time I was wondering what the Japanese people would have thought if this was the film shown in 1954 theaters.  It would have been a pretty cool reaction.

One of my favorite things was the integration of the original musical score into the Godzilla scenes. When that kicked in, it made my heart smile.  It was a fun time at the theater.  I've seen around 12 of the 28 Godzilla films and this was probably my favorite one.
It was really good. The meanest and most hateful Godzilla ever!! Must see. I loved it!!

This movie will have you stunned from beginning to end. Easily one of the best movies I've possibly seen this year wow, this is a must watch.
Looking forward to its release in Spain

Went to see the movie this last weekend. It is absolutely the best Japanese Godzilla movie I have seen. The story carries it. The characters are deeply heartfelt and understood. It says things about the Japanese government during the time of WW2 that I felt were insightful. And 'Zilla? Absolutely ferocious and terrifying. I think more than ever before. This is of course NOT "hero 'Zilla" this is "atomic bomb 'Zilla". And you feel the tension and you feel the intent and heart of the characters also. Its a fantastic film.

This is probably the best Godzilla movie I have ever seen. It is what I imagine the original creators would have made if given the technology that we have. If you have to have a reason to start watching movies with subtitles this is the reason.
A great Godzilla film that's always a great Post-WW2 drama. Emotional and gripping.

Excellent movie... bored of seeing Hollywood's version of more talking and less Godzilla screentime and most confusing perspective & Protoganist version of Godzilla. This Japanese version has good enough screentime for Zilla, scope for the story and characters and well directed ..it is worth watching.. it's a simple no fuzz movie..actors had a purpose too....

Godzilla minus one is an incredible movie. The story is fantastic, the plot, the effects and everything. It's also incredibly realistic looking way better than the new Godzilla movie coming out. The crazy fact is that Godzilla minus one Had a budget of 15 million and it still insanely realistic. Definitely worth watching

Godzilla minus one 

The hype is everywhere. I am a big fan of Gojira and his all his incarnations. Without spoilers, let's compare where Minus one " borrowed" from other blockbusters… 
Jaws 
Star Wars 
War of the Gargantuas 

Lots of unfinished business at the end, loose ends to tie up. What elicited the response of joy from myself was the "Gojira" theme that announced the arrival of the big guy. If you listen carefully, it pays homage to " Mothra".. 

Fingers crossed for a part 2
phenomenal, loved the movie. one of the best Godzilla movies I've ever seen.

This movie was great stuff.  Harkens back the original versions themes.  The human component is felt.  Every appearance feels purposeful without being over done.  Not the over the top action bonanza that the Kong crossover is
This is what Godzilla truly is.
Loved the movie. Everything about it was great. The story the design for Godzilla wasn't bad honestly. He kinda scared me in the beginning.

I wish I could give it more stars. This movie was absolutely amazing and is the best movie of 2023. This is a must watch like asap. The plot and the cinematography was incredible I'm not over exaggerating. Go watch now!!!!
one of the best films of the year, a stunning tale of post war japan with some of the best man vs monster movies ever
Must see movie if you are a Godzilla fan. This was the best Godzilla movie I have ever seen. It’s on my top 50 movies of all time.

This movie took Godzilla back to its roots. It was an emotional experience to see Godzilla treated so well by the director. You also felt as if you could experience the emotions of the human characters. Truly a brilliant film.
I just loved this movie. The characters are detailed and truly human. Godzilla was awesome in every minute.
Arguable the best Godzilla movie ever. Got so involved in  the movie I forgot I was reading captioning. Actually had a plot, besides the lizard, and was fun to watch. Best creature yet.

Truly enjoyed this movie.  Have been a Godzilla fan since I was 5.  Almost 5 decades. Love the throwback to the seriousness of the original and reclaim that horror feeling when Godzilla is on scene. Unfortunately he is not on as much as would like.  Almost the hidden Easter eggs through out the movie is quite impressive with respect given to past movies.  
There are a few plot angles that hold me back from giving it 5 stars but in the end it is a Godzilla movie after all and one of the best ever produced.
The best Godzilla movie since the original. Absolute perfection.

A masterful film filled with amazing spectacle, high tension, thundering action, heartfelt emotion and just an incredible story. The acting, special effects, music and directing are top tier making it one of the best entries in this legendary Gojira franchise!
Great movie in general, but best monster movie of all time.
Good movie, but the movie drags in a couple of screens.
Great movie. Even though it is in all Japanese, it still has a great plot and emotional storyline.
Highly recommended. The characters are extremely engaging and Godzilla returns to form.

I was surprised to experience a heavy-hitting emotional movie that also includes a monster with an atomic heat ray. The focus of the story being immediately during the aftermath of WWII makes for a great origin story of Godzilla alongside characters who are dealing with, not only their country being destroyed, but almost every aspect of their lives needing to be rebuilt. Theres a lot to unpack and quite a few themes that are tackled in a film where I thought I would just be witnessing a giant lizard monster flipping ships and knocking over buildings. 

There is a moment where everything goes silent, and I cant remember the last time Ive been in a crowded theater where it seemed the audience was holding their breath. There were times of cheering, clapping, and Im sure some tears being shed. What more could you want? My only complaint is despite Ryunosuke Kamiki appearing in a few dozen films but his ability to express realistic crying on screen is nearly non-existent. Overall, though, Im quite satisfied and will be enthusiastically recommending this to everyone.

A thoroughly enjoyable and interesting character driven story with all the right nods to the classic Godzilla basics.   Interesting how a Japanese movie with English subtitles, not primarily intended for a US audience, made on a shoestring budget is far better than the vast majority of what's coming out of Hollywood these days.

I have no idea how people can enjoy this movie. It was absolutely one of the worst movies I have ever seen…my wife and son all contemplated walking out at several points. The actors overact…nonstop screaming in simple conversations. It is very slow…wife fell asleep (which is why we didn’t leave). I have no idea how critics can applaud this film…strongly disagree. No logic to why Godzilla attacks and just bad dialogue throughout the film. Save your money!

It has been over a week now that I have seen Godzilla Minus One and I am still thinking about it. Easily the best Godzilla film ever made and ranks as one of the best disaster films ever made as well. The storytelling was just spot on and kept you glued from beginning to end. The movie looked amazing and it was on a $15mm budget??? Unbelievable. I cannot wait to see it again.
Best Godzilla movie ever
this changed my life

It made me cry, it made me stare in awe, but especially, it made me fear for the future of humanity. I've always been a #teamgodzilla for the sake of movie pleasure, but this time I was #teamtokio all the way. What a beautiful writing. What a great director. What a great movie

I grew up in the 80's, watching Godzilla marathons whenever they came on TV, which wasn't often, but when they did, you can bet I was glued to the TV. Most Godzilla movies were campy, made for kids, so yeah, we didn't care for the plot, we just wanted to see giant monsters fighting. The first scary Godzilla movie that I watched was Godzilla 1985, or as it was called in Japan, The Return of Godzilla. G85 is a direct sequel to the original Godzilla from 1954 and ignores all the movies from the 60's and 70's. It returned Godzilla to its roots, where he's more of a force of nature, not necessarily a hero or villain, so it was a nice change of pace of what I had seen.

 Having seen every Godzilla movie from the Showa and Heisei eras, and some from the Millenium series, I was longing for something more modern, not just a man in a rubber suit. Godzilla 1998 was an utter disappointment. So when WB/Legendary brought us an American Godzilla that was closer to the original, it was what we wanted growing up, an updated Godzilla with today's technology. Yes, it was still a bit campy, but the monsters looked GREAT! We didn't care about the human element, we never have.

That's what makes Toho's Godzilla Minus One special, they've managed to make an AMAZING Godzilla movie where we actually care about the humans. We're rooting for them all and don't want them to get killed by Godzilla. This movie will get you emotional. I'm not crying, you are. The visuals, the sounds, and if you watch it in 4D, oof, even better. I've watched it twice already, and can't wait for it to be released digitally. Might even buy the DVD/BluRay whenever its released.
This movie was fantastic! The feel and vibe of the movie reminded me of my childhood. While growing up watching Godzilla movies.  10 out of 10, highly recommend!

Must watch in 4-D!
Feels like Godzilla the ride!!! Worth it.
An emotional tale of grief, loss, grit, love and resolve set in post WW2 Japan. Oh yeah it also has Godzilla in it. This movie rules.
the human characters are actually engaging for once, and Godzilla himself is incredible

This is the Godzilla movie many have been waiting and wishing for! It forsakes the Hollywood depiction of a "saviour" and goes all-in on its' traditional Japanese roots of Godzilla as an unstoppable force of nature. Given the budget (~USD$15mil) it is certainly amazing what the production company managed to pull off with both visual and practical effects. Godzilla looks a little janky at times - but it is by no means terrible. 
And the heat(/atomic) breath! This movie nailed it!
If you're happy with reading subtitles or can speak Japanese, then I can't recommend this movie enough. 
I only hope modern Hollywood takes a page out of this book on how to write a compelling story with interesting characters.

I grew up with godzilla, my dad putting the movie monster on our tv for family movie nights are memories I'll cherish. My appreciation for the monster only grew as a learned more about the backstory and why the original film was made. I was so excited to see this film and brought a group with me some who have never seen a Godzilla movie before and some who grew up with the monster like myself. As I watched I looked at my friends faces they were all the same, shocked and on the edge of the seats as they watched. Hands over their mouths as godzilla charges his atomic breath. This movie is for everyone, and a big win for fans who have been here from the start. The film creates new fans and is a masterpiece to us G-fans. Absolutely incredible 10/10!
this is a great reboot of the original godzilla.  would recommend to any who like monster movies.
The entire movie was  an homage to the original  Godzilla with a fantastic update

How often do you watch a movie and it becomes an instant classic? I've been a fan of Godzilla for most my life, introduced to the series by my dad, Godzilla has always been a series filled with Campe, fun monster fights and terrible human plots. In a way that was the Godzilla experience, an uncut gem that was special but never succeeded at holding a narrative, even the best movies in the series never rising above mediocre in story telling.

But Godzilla Minus One, it is the culmination of the entire Godzilla franchise, as if we had only been experiencing the prototypes of the truly worthy creation since 1954. Godzilla Minus One is THE Godzilla Movie, accept no American substitutions, Takashi Yamazaki has bridged the gap that Godzilla has been lacking for so long, a delivered a truly wonderful story to go along with worlds favorite giant monster!

I could not stress enough just how moving of a narrative it is and how unexpected and delighted I was watching it. Of the nearly 20 Godzilla movies I've watched, Godzilla Minus One is the only one that made me cry. I realized in the theater that I wasn't just having a good time, I wasn't just getting a thrill but I was truly moved by a Godzilla movie. That I wasn't putting up with the human plot to get to Godzilla for once.

If you haven't yet, go watch this movie. I haven't touched on the cinematography, or the acting, or music... Etc. But it is easily some of the best in the franchise, the sound design in particular is truly to be commended.

 Takashi Yamazaki is writer and director, to a truly legendary film in Godzilla Minus One. I am incredibly thankful to him and the many other that came together to make this movie, my favorite Godzilla Movie and a truly great film!
Emotional, action packed, exactly what I anticipate from a great Godzilla flick.  If you're a fan of Japanese kaiju films, this one is a definite must see.
The first Godzilla movie where Godzilla is secondary to the human story. Best film I have scene this year.
By far one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. SO refreshing. Great story, great writing, great character development and Godzilla was  fantastic in this movie. Will  be watching it again.
Fun monster times. Nice parallel, non-monster story.
Awesome destruction. Meanest Godzilla ever. 🔥🔥🔥. Japanese Heroes. Bravo Toho.

It's truly incredible what was accomplished with this movie. I cannot possibly give it higher praise. Taking into account the budget it's even more amazing, but even setting that aside it's a monumental achievement in storytelling.

Godzilla Minus One is easily the best movie I've seen this year and the best movie that I have seen - bar Top Gun Maverick - in a very long time. I don't have the words to convey how good this movie is, or just how it embarrasses Hollywood and what they put out, but this is easily the best movie that I have seen in a very long while.

I can't believe I'm saying this but this movie has a very real possibility of getting nominated for an Oscar.

Easily the best movie I've seen in 2023.  Some of the best CGI I've seen yet, truly showing just how BIG and destructive Godzilla is.  Always trust the Japanese to get the original kaiju Godzilla correct.
Amazing score. Amazing acting. Amazing cinematography. Just overall amazing.
Best monster movie. Good human story around it. See what they can do with low budget can still produce great movie

Loved the story and how it fixed some of the holes in the original Godzilla. Loved Kiochi coming to terms with himself and Tachibana's forgiveness. The special effects were spectacular. Would gladly see at least 12 more times.
LOVED THIS MOVIE EVERYTHING WAS GREAG EVEN THE HUMANS AND GODZILLA WAS NOT WASTED AT ALL JUST GO WATCH THE MOVIE FOR THE CLIFFHANGER
Genuinely awesome - great story,  may be the greatest Godzilla move of them all!  So compelling that I didn't even finish my popcorn.
Godzilla Minus One is absolutely incredible. This movie will make you relate to the characters. It will put on the edge the seat from beginning to end. It’s a must see.
First kaiju movie that I genuinely loved and not just liked a lot.
awesome movie, i really liked how toho stepped up their game and made G -1.0, i hope they make  the sequal!.
Can't get much better than this!
Really good godzilla movie!
Maybe the best Godzilla movie of all time! See it!
I've been a Godzilla fan since watching the movies in the 80s. This was not only the best in the series but a new addition to my "favorite movies" list. Chef's kiss 🤌🏾
Better movie than the ones Hollywood and Disney are making lately. This one has a heart/soul. Worth watching!
One of the coolest looking Godzillas. Not only that but the human story lines didnt feel like they were weighing the movie down.
Best movie in years WOW
I would definitely rewatch this film over and over again.

Godzilla is back, baby! I've been a fan of Godzilla since I was a kid in the early 2000s, and I can say that we haven't gotten an exceptional new film since I've been alive. Looks like that's over now, though! The story of our boy Shikishima the failed Kamikaze pilot has to be the best human arc in a Godzilla movie yet. Normally fans complain about the human stories being an annoyance, but this time it nearly steals the show. This is helped by the interesting setting of a battered Japan immediately following their defeat in WWII. The G-Man himself does not disappoint either. I especially loved how they made his breath attack feel so powerful. Walked out of the theater with a big goofy grin on my face and come to find everyone else enjoyed it too. Hope this kindles new interest in the IP. Exceptional!
Best Godzilla movie ever made !

Thank you for this masterpiece. I love Godzilla but this movie was on a whole other level. It's always the governments fighting back which is realistic. But I always feel so disconnected from the people. But Minus One I was so engrossed into the lives of these people. First time a Godzilla film made me cry but it was so beautifully crafted. Thank you. Thank you.

Went to see this last Friday and all I can say is thus movie was absolutely stunning. For a 15 million dollar budget they did an amazing job with the effects.

The star of the show was the human characters though and the well thought story. They did an amazing job telling a story about the horrors of war and showing the struggles of PTSD. 

Really couldn't recommend this film enough
It was as a great story and the cgi was well done.
One of the best Big G movies I’ve seen in I don’t know how long!

Really enjoyed this movie.  When I was a kid, 40+ years ago, in the summer, they'd have a matinee series of which Godzilla was always one of the movies and that movie was the one I'd never miss.  This brought back all those nostalgic memories.   The Godzilla face, the music, etc...  I seldom  clap at the end of movies, but this one, my 14 year old son and I, yes.

Fantastic movie all around.  So refreshing after seeing so many duds this year.  Dragged my wife to this movie and she ended up loving it as well.  This is really a movie you need to see in the theater.  I don't think it will hold up well streaming at home.
If you’re a fan of Godzilla or just fun movies, this one’s a great choice.
I didn’t realize that Godzilla was a metaphor for WW2 America this whole time.
Amazing movie! Glad I watched it in theaters.

I went into this knowing almost nothing about it and was pleasantly surprised. Godzilla was awesome but the story here is great. Didn't know I was going to see a serious film. This movie deserves its praise and then some.
best godzilla movie ever. old school godzilla. even with subtitles was easy to watch. whole family enjoyed it.

I’ve seen it in color five times now, and this was my first time seeing it without color. Honestly, it is a significant improvement that made it feel like a completely different film. Subtle details became more apparent without color that added more depth and realism to the film as a whole, and I came out feeling far more immersed than I did seeing color in 4DX.

THIS is the best Godzilla movie ever made. Easily one of the best films of the year as well. The acting, the cinematography, the effects, the EMOTION. Such an incredible film. Cannot recommend this film enough!
Well written, fantastic visual effects I also loved the fact the original theme motif for Godzilla was introduced. My son loved it and I will probably watch it a second time.

Great movie with interesting and well-motivated characters.  Understandable human story with a strong emotional arc.  Includes a couple real surprising "gotcha" moments, which I've not experienced in movies for a long time. Excellent writing.  First movie I'll probably see more than once in the theatre.  Strong recommend!  Go see this movie and support great storytelling.
Raw emotions, insane VFX for the budget, and an incredible story. I have not been this invested in movie characters since Top Gun Maverick last year. Will go see it again and highly recommend.

Good movie.   Went to go see it with my family, and actually went in thinking it wouldn't be as enjoyable as English released movies, but it was still well worth it.   Having to read through the subtitles didn't take away from the experience.   It had a well thought out and deep story-line and was very inspiring.   Very worth-while even if you are not used to watchin foreign films.
Movie was amazing. Usually a fan of just the monster fighting like in the monster verse Godzilla’s but the story in this was amazing. Loved it! Can’t wait to see the second if they make it.
It was so stinking good. WOW.

Outstanding! Delivers as the giant city crunching Godzilla I've come to love.  Wrapped up beautifully with characters who's struggles don't take away but add to the climatic final confrontation. Brought back the true magic that exist in watching a movie of this caliber on the big screen.

At the start, it was kinda slow, but, the rest of the movie it was Awesome the human drama was good, the special effects goated, and of course Godzilla himself being iconic and terrifying best movie of Godzilla franchise and best movie of 2023
Not just the best monster movie ever, probably one of the top movies ever period. I felt every emotion to its full measure. I'm still buzzing hours after watching!
This is how a Godzilla movie should be made!
This is definitely my new favorite Godzilla movie, I especially enjoyed the use of the original Godzilla movie’s soundtrack.
Best modern day version of a Godzilla movie in a long time. Storylines was great!

I've never been a huge Godzilla fan, wow this movie blew me away. Godzilla is actually scary and inspires dread and the human plot is touching and sad, but also gratifying. There's some good commentary on WW2 Japanese era and their treatment of their soldiers and citizens. The backdrop is a recovering Japan getting basically nuked again by Godzilla and coming together to fight back.

Simple, and very effective. Godzilla also looked great- admittedly at the expense of some other effects in the movie but I'm very okay with the budget being focused on Godzilla and the atomic breath which HITS- every time. Definitely give it a watch wether you like Godzilla movies or not I guarantee most people will be hooked by it.

Really a must see if you’re a die hard Godzilla fan it has amazing action Godzilla is a menace and it’s a full movie that doesn’t have any English dialogue in it (but it does have subtitles) 10/10 a must watch

All Time Classic. For 70 years the original has stood as the gold standard. That torch has now been passed. This is a love letter to the original while also being it's own thing. Anyone who has seen the original will catch a lot of key callbacks. This has nothing but respect for it. The human characters are the best in any Kaiju film ever. This feels like Speilberg could have directed this. No character is a throwaway or just blends in. Godzilla is terrifying in this. The CGI is solid also in this. This fixes the only real issue of the original which was it was almost too unrefined and raw for it's own good. See it.

I’ve never experienced a monster movie that has such impactful characters as with this one. Of course, seeing an epic and destructive Godzilla was what I was there for… but I didn’t expect to love the human characters as much as I did. There was so much emotion and depth to the characters that you don’t normally get with a monster movie. In the end, I was rooting for the humans against Godzilla. That is a win.
Classic Godzilla  is back on the big screen. Action was on point. The human emotion  shown is just not touched by American  movies. Moving and tear jerkier
A classic. Good story telling with strong replay value.
The atomic bomb memories. Pure sadness and horror. Great direction and production. Simply one of the scariest Godzilla movies💣💥

Maybe I've grown used to immersive games with good plots (like the Fallout series) but I could only give this 3.5 stars. I might be spoiled on movies because of immersive games?

The plot was one of disgrace and redemption, with a touch of exploration of PTSD, so that was nice. The special effects were quite good,

But to me, the ending was predictable. "....and everything worked out in the end." You know, that sort of thing.

On the whole it kept my interest, and I won't say the movie was bad, but for all the 5 star, gushing reviews, I guess I expected more.

I will say, keeping the movie in Japanese and subtitling it actually added to the experience. It felt far more authentic that way.
A absolute masterpiece!

This is not something I would have seen in the theatres in all likelihood however the reviews for a Japanese language Godzilla film got me curious. This was a fantastic film and not just 'for a Godzilla movie', but period. I highly recommend just about anyone see this, and in a theatre too. One of the best if not the best of 2023 for me.
A Godzilla movie that would be a great movie even if we cut Godzilla out of the movie. But Godzilla still kicks ass when show up.

Surprisingly good. I wasn't expecting to like this movie as much as I did, especially considering it's in Japanese and I had to read subtitles - not that I really mind having to read subtitles, but those movies don't tend to make my top-movies-of-the-year list, if you know what I mean. And really, if it wasn't for my 12 year old nephew wanting to see it, I probably would have missed it. But glad I didn't!

I've no doubt that some will complain about the movie being too long, or not having enough Godzilla action, but what really made this one shine for me personally was the time spent on telling a good story and character development. I really felt like the characters were the main focus here, and Godzilla was a secondary focus, serving as a way to tell a story about honor and shame and redemption and so much more. A great cast, a way better than usual script for a Godzilla movie, beautiful cinematography, and good special effects, all helped make it work. And when we do get to see Godzilla wreaking carnage,  it has even more impact because of the deep emotional impact we can see he has had on the lives of the characters.

Small personal quibbles: Not quite sure why Godzilla had to be even fatter than what I used to refer to as the "American Godzilla" from the 1998 film with Matthew Broderick, and I wish he had ate more people, instead of just biting them in half - but then he might have been even fatter, LoL.
Amazing. Hollywood needs to take lessons from the Japanese on how to make a movie. This was tense, raw, and immersive.
My first Godzilla movie and it was a master piece ❤️
Awesome movie. Took me back to my childhood because of the type of Godzilla he was, great story as well.. Definitely worth full price admission
The best film of 2023, absolutely blew my mind how they could create such a gripping drama, emotionally and physically striking on such a low budget. True cinematic masterpiece.
This movie lives up to the word of mouth hype.  Never thought I'd ever shed a tear during a Godzilla movie.  So good and its got giant kiaju!
Amazing Cinematography, Visual effects, Emotion, story, score. Everything!
Best Godzilla movie ever
Best Godzilla movie ever. Full stop. Yes, I've seen all of them, most multiple times.
Minus One was the best Godzilla movie I have ever seen in theaters. I liked the characters, the story, and Godzillas design. I will give it five stars

I'm very impressed with this Japanese made film. A very good dramatic story taking place along with the king of the monsters attacking. This was more intense and showed people getting killed. Special effects is well done. My only complaint is that from waist down he is noticeably bigger. Godzilla has phat ass. The acting is a little over the top but doesn't hurt the film. Definitely recommend to Godzilla and monster fans.

Prepare to be blown away by this incredible film. I, too, was skeptical when I first booked tickets for Godzilla "Minus One." The title alone seemed like a turn off. And as someone who isn't a fan of excessive special effects, I was hesitant to tell my husband about the movie in fear that he may also be put off by it.

But let me tell you, this movie surpassed all of my expectations. Despite its title, which may sound unappealing at first glance, the reviews raved about its brilliance. So with an open mind and high hopes, my husband and I sat down to watch.

And boy, were we blown away. The story of Japan's devastation during World War II and the terrifying presence of Godzilla had us on the edge of our seats. But what truly captivated us was the underlying love story and the courageous kamikaze pilot who fears death.

This is not your typical monster movie filled with over-the-top special effects. Instead, it tastefully combines elements of 1940s nostalgia with 21st century technology to create a truly unique experience. The attention to detail and commitment to staying true to the era is commendable and adds an extra layer of realism to the film.

I cannot recommend this movie enough. It's not just a film you watch and forget about; it's one that stays with you long after the credits roll. So don't miss out on this beautiful masterpiece that will leave you in awe. Hurry and grab your tickets now before they're sold out!

(BIG SPOILERS) Honestly, I wasn't sure if this movie would be good when i heard it had no dubbing. That opinion changed. New favorite movie, and barely had to focus on the words because the actors/actresses did an amazing. And also godzillasaurus (I think) at the beginning was amazing. And the G-mans new atomic breath is so cool with the explosion. And the C.G.I. is freaking amazing. Also the human characters. Usually in the godzilla movies I've watched well uhhh the humans just weren't entertaining but this movie… that kamikaze plot wad very interesting. And godzilla is not like a usual godzilla… those punches were insanely fast! And the W.W.2 plot was insane. Also that remix of the godzilla theme was so good. Human actors 10/10 
Godzilla 11/10
soundtrack 9/10 
plot 11/10
Overall 98.5/100 
my favorite movie. Ever

(Beat previous favorite movie (Jurassic Park) by a long shot)
A perfect Godzilla film for everyone. It blew me away!
Best Godzilla movie better than American ones
Absolute best Gojira movie OAT, the characters had amazing acting and the speaking of Japanese sold the show. Absolutely flabbergastingly amazing.
A must see. Truly emotional, frightening, And glorious.
Movie was a bit slow in the first half, but then it picked up with deeper emtions and actions in the second half.
Wonderful storyline with good special effects. An instant classic that I would watch over and over again. It's the best movie of the year!!!

This is one of the best Godzilla movies I every seen , I was nervous during the initial movie but in a good way , if my younger self watched this movie he would be proud and happy to see how Godzilla movies evolved into the masterpiece of cinema
Excellent examination of postwar japan in an above average kaiju movie
Movie was well put together.  With the story of loss a more. Great action as well. Godzilla looked amazing! Re-watch worthy!
The Meanest Godzilla Ever!
I've never had such a strong, emotional reaction to a monster movie before. The human story and message were very powerful and Godzilla himself was legitimately frightening to behold.

Effects and sound were fantastic!  Characters were well-rounded and I found myself actually caring about their journey.  The plot dragged in some places, but the action scenes really made up for it.  Great movie overall!
Best Godzilla movie.
I have been a huge Godzilla fan since my childhood, and imo, this is the greatest Godzilla film ever made.
1st Godzilla movie that made me care about the human storyline!  It was all I could do to keep from crying and the classic music took me right to my childhood.
Great film!!!! Loved the human story! Godzilla is a menace!! Best Godzilla film I’ve ever seen.
Probably the best movie of 2023. It was the first Godzilla movie that brought tears to both me and my wife's eyes. LOVED IT!
A true Godzilla masterpiece from the original
movie was so good that it actually made me shed a tear
Liked it. Thought the old school models and lack of crazy CGI to be a welcome change. Absolutely worth seeing for any Godzilla fan or even a former fan.
Amazing! Best movie of the year, possibly.

This movie was fabulous. Great story, great character development and phenomenal effects.  It's 2 hours but doesn't feel like 2 hours.  The creators of this movie delivered in every way shape and form.
This is a great Godzilla movie. It is how they should be made. Great story. Fantastically done.

It was absolutely great! Great characters and, of course, Godzilla! I didn't give it 5 stars because reading the subtitles took away some of the viewing experience but I'd prefer them to dubbing. It took my two teen boys also and they also thought, "that was really good!"
A really good story. My son and I agreed that the movie being in Japanese with subtitles was a great experience.  This movie was a A+

A film that made use of excellent camera angles and shots to give a great feel of the scenes. Music was well used to capture the tone that each scene was giving to the audience. Godzilla truly came off as a terrifying creature that the human protagonists had to find a way to overcome. Most importantly, the human characters had struggles and arcs that I was invested in to seeing through and even got emotional, being moved to tears as events transpired. I recommend this film not because it is a film with Godzilla, but a truly excellent film that overall is an incredible package all the way through.
This movie is a triumph beyond belief, absolutely loved literally everything about this movie. See it in IMAX!!

I went in thinking this was just another Godzilla movie without seeing any trailer or hearing any reviews and wow! It blew me away. I laughed, I cried. It was far more than just a big monster of destruction film. my hat is off to everyone who worked on this masterpiece.
Not only the best Godzilla movie I have ever seen , and I've seen all of them 100s of times . It was the best movie I have ever seen period !

Halfway through, I whispered to my friend, “This is the best Godzilla movie I’ve ever seen. By the end, we were both exclaiming that “Godzilla Minus One” is one of the best movies we seen. Period. A real art piece. Had me in legit tears. Even when you could seen the narrative beats coming a mile away, the tropes were so well executed that the payoffs still ended up being worth the journey. Bravo to the Japanese studio for showing the world how monster movies should be done. Wow.
One of the best Godzilla movies yet! So nice having characters to care about  & a plot that kept you on the edge of your seat.
Best Godzilla Movie I Have Ever Seen.  PERFECT!
An amazing experience watching this movie! Definitely exceeded my expectations.
Not a single moment in that movie are you bored or waiting or anything. Everything from the acting, the action, the cinematography was on point. This movie really set the bar high!

I loved this movie.  I have seen every Godzilla film from the original 1954 Godzilla to Godzilla V Kong.  This was the best one I have seen to date, HANDS DOWN!!!  The story is amazing and you attach yourself to the characters.  You feel what they feel, you see what they see and you experience what they experience.  The special effects are on par, if not better then any of the Hollywood versions. Godzilla is the best I have EVER seen of him.  Great job, TOHO!!!

probably movie of the year.  Its not perfect but entertaining.  Good side story of the character you care a little about.  Amazing they did this on a 15 million budget.  There was homage to the old ways of Godzilla.
I went in with HIGH expectations after seeing all the reviews. They were met.

🚨Godzilla Minus One should sweep the Oscars and win the Academy Award for Best Picture 🚨 

Yes, this is a foreign (Japanese) film with English subtitles but,
Godzilla Minus One is a stunning masterpiece that will leave you breathless if you give it a chance! This gripping and heartfelt film takes us back to the aftermath of World War II, where the legendary monster wreaks havoc on a war-torn Japan.

The film's exquisite cinematography captures the raw emotions of the characters and the sheer terror of Godzilla's presence. The special effects are top-notch, making the monster's appearance all the more terrifying and awe-inspiring.

One of the most striking aspects of the film is its exploration of the human condition in the face of overwhelming adversity. The characters are complex and relatable, and their struggles will resonate with audiences long after the credits roll.

In short, Godzilla Minus One is a must-see film that is a masterclass in stunning visuals, powerful storytelling, and an unforgettable monster to create a truly unforgettable cinematic experience.
Possibly the best Godzilla movie ever. Great story with interesting and likable characters.
Great story with stunning visual effects. You don't even notice the subtitles after the first few memories. This is a movie you have to see in theaters to fully appreciate.

Wow been watching Godzilla since i was a kid in the 1970's on basic television back in the day, i have all the G dude's  dvd's from japan and this is the best one yet that makes you think and feel everyones pain  , it is great human story that makes you want to buy another ticket and watch it again

The best Godzilla movie since the original 1954 version. Finally, a monster movie where the human characters are interesting and not used for exposition. The movie shows that you do not need a big budget to make a great film

Best Godzilla movie Iv seen in recent years. This movie was just amazing plan and simple. The story is well written and Godzilla is chilling to watch in the best way. The pacing is great, and charcuterie development, I actually cared about the characters.
Outstanding film with spectacular special effects and a touching story line.
A harrowing, poignant & emotional triumph for this colossal titan gracing cinema for 70 years.
Great story and well done!
Godzilla excellent movie !!
Very well done, Godzilla was definitely scarier than past incarnations. Definitely got my money’s worth.
My favorite film of the year!

This movie was a breath of fresh air. I love how it remained true to the originals and provided a message for humanity. One huge message was how war not only affects veterans, but also civilians was extremely powerful. I could go on and on about the rollercoaster of emotions but I might reveal spoilers.

Disney, take note! This is how to make a movie!

I've seen every single Godzilla film multiple, multiple times, and having seen Minus One in the theater twice, all I can say is wow. This film is perfection. The acting is immaculate, the special effects sequences are stunning (that Takao battle!!!), and the emotions are so real. Ranks with the original Gojira as the finest of the franchise.
I’m lost for words, amazing
The most powerful, most intimate Godzilla movie ever.  Others are popcorn, this was true drama.  Not for the feint of heart - one family had to leave after the first scene.

This film has a great story with great effects for a tiny budget. Well done. There was at least one poorly edited scene at the tail end of the film and a very unnecessary underwater scene which undermines the hero's journey and leaves the story open for continuation. The film would have worked better as a one-off film with an completely resolved ending.

This is a really good movie and the best use of large scale action I've seen in a long time - way better than Marvel, other Godzilla movies, better than apocalypse movies. Godzilla is 200 feet tall but frightening & devestating on a human level and tightly bound to the inner struggles of the characters.  There were times I said "Oh my God" to the devestation or was really moved by the courage, struggle or triumph of the characters.

The writing & direction is the difference.  In many movies of this scale you see CGI robots, monsters or indestructible super heroes knocking over CGI skyscrapers from miles away.  In this movie the writers put a 200' monster down at the level of people and there's geniune suspense & dread in the action.  The shots of huge events like Godzilla's nuclear breath make you feel like you're inside it instead of 3 miles away. 


We really enjoyed this movie. Hopefully Marvel & other studios take note and start producing gripping, involving action movies that leverage CGI instead of what feels like a series of boring demo reels from computer animation studious.
Slow at times, but this movie gives you the old age Godzilla vibes
An interesting take on Godzilla Minus One -- it works better in some scenes and more poorly in others. Still, it's an interesting experience.
What a great version of a Godzilla movie!  Evan with subtitles I was hooked.  I could ramble on a variety of thoughts but better off to say go see it and form your own opinion.  Cheers!
Best movie I’ve seen all year.
The best movie of 2023!!!!  Must see in theater and in Imax!!!

Thoughtful and engaging story with Godzilla!!! A lot of homage paid to the old movies.  The effects weren't overdone and blended into the movie perfectly.  Best movie I saw in the theater this year!!!
Fantastic. I wish Hollywood would lean from the success of great movies with great stories.

This is film is a must see movie that covers multiple genres from drama to historical to psychological to sci-fi to war, and that's without Godzilla. Enter Godzilla and this becomes the greatest Godzilla movie of all time. 

Go see this movie.

One of the most beautiful cinematographic masterpieces I've ever seen. Far beyond just a Kaiju movie but it delivers true to the original Godzilla formula on every front while being interesting, fresh, and beautiful as a film.

The movie is visually beautiful - one might even call it spectacular in the way it portrays post-war Japan (and related naval machinery) in its decay and rebirth of Tokyo. This is not your 1960's campy Saturday afternoon matinee portrayal of Godzilla movie but instead a dark and though-provoking spin on this age old story.  The use of Akira Ifukube's classic Godzilla soundtrack in places is a nice touch too. And consider staying through the final credits for an auditory omen.  :-)

I was truly impressed with this film! Thanks to careful pacing, thoughtful writing, and brilliant acting, characters feel like real people with genuine emotions rather than archetypes cast to fill a role. Godzilla's face needed some extra care; his eyes were always wide open and his mouth had a permanent smile, which was distracting at times. However, that's honestly the only critique I have for this otherwise refreshing film.

I am a bit of a military/naval history nerd, and this movie was better than I could have ever hoped. The ships that appear in the movie are accurate for the types of ship they are, all of the warships are ships that actually survived the war, and the named former captain is of one of the warships famed for surviving numerous engagements with little-to-no damage or casualties - which is thematically appropriate to the end of the movie.

Besides all that, it is emotionally powerful and visually spectacular, and I highly recommend it to anyone and everyone.
This is the best Godzilla movie by far an emotional roller coaster, and post WW2 setting that allows you to connect with the cast

I've been watching Godzilla and Kaiju movies for over 5 decades. Best description I've heard for the the film as follows; "Godzilla Minus One is not a great Godzilla film. It's a great film that has Godzilla in it." 
It's not a 'feel good' film. It's not an action film. You won't cheer. You shouldn't cheer. It's an allegory for the absolutely horrible things humans experience, endure, and overcome. 
Oh ... and it has the greatest movie monster in cinematic history in it. Perfectly demonstrating why Godzilla is the greatest monster in cinematic history.
Different perspective than most Godzilla movies. Jurassic Park-like scenes of people being munched or squashed. Great acting and special effects. Highly recommended!

Everything was amazing. Plot, acting, sound design and music. Design and use of the Godzilla character. As someone who has since nearly all the Godzilla films going back to the first from 1954, this is probably the best film and rendition of the character to date

Wow. What a fantastic piece of cinema. Although it doesn't really mean much considering I've only seen the MonsterVerse Godzilla movies before this, this is easily my favorite. Godzilla is menacing and scary, and unlike the MonsterVerse movies, the human characters are just as good, especially the main character. He has plenty of development throughout, and you actually care about him and the other characters. This movie is perfect in my eyes, and because of that, it's my second favorite movie of the year, just behind Oppenheimer, although those two are switching all the time. Oh my goodness this movie changed my whole entire life. There has not a single movie that has moved me more than this film. You won't believe it when I say how much this movie has changed me. It has significantly altered my life. After sitting through this two hour film, I happened to get a raise at my workplace. I got a promotion yesterday morning when I walked into the building. I was baptized at my local church. My birthday went well 
and I celebrated it early this year in honor of the Godzilla.

One of those "greatest movie of all time" contenders. Everything about Godzilla is phenomenal. It's an experience. Love, respect, admiration. A monumental masterpiece. And I had ZERO interest going in. Hollywood, take notes.

Brilliant movie - the combination of action and emotion was something I wasn't expecting but certainly found fitting. I wasn't expecting to shed tears but all well worth it, I think. It captures Godzilla in his perfect, unpredictable, nature. Mind you, the staccato movements remind me of the earlier movies, but it didn't deter from his capabilities at all. If anything, fit the timeline and felt like an ode to..  Don't sleep on this movie, especially if you're a kaiju fan.
