The move is just incredible. From the visual effects to the music to the human story, it is just……….Beautiful
An absolutely fantastic, breathtaking and emotional film.

As a Godzilla Fan since the 90s this is pure gold Godzilla is a Menace from Start to finish. Human element was the best over EVER SEEN. You actually gave a damn especially with it begin post world war 2 you see everything and I couldn't be happier for THE REBIRTH OF THE KING OF THE MONSTERS GODZILLA
Great movie. Enjoyable, exciting and a very good human story as well!!!

Godzilla Minus One thoroughly defied my expectations. Every single scene feels weighty and impactful (not just the ones that feature the titular monster destroying Tokyo). 

I never once found myself impatiently wishing for the real action to begin, because the movie actually gave me reasons to be invested in the characters. It's an excellently crafted experience. The themes permeate all throughout the storytelling, the characters are relatable and well written, Godzilla is terrifying, the performances can be heart-wrenching, and it is just incredibly evident that the director, Takashi Yamazaki, had a real vision for this movie. Anyone that worked on this film absolutely deserves to be proud of their work.

It's great and I'm eagerly awaiting whatever Takashi Yamazaki does next.
Best Godzilla movie in a long time. Not just a masterpiece monster movie, but a great story and characters. Go see it now and on IMAX if you can!
Best Godzilla film as far as story. Truly a great film by TOHO and can't wait for the next film in this series.
I loved the Godzilla franchise ever since the first Godzilla movie came out. This film was phenomenal and deserved all five stars. A must see movie before 2024

Toho once again shows us how a truly substantial and beautifully written and compelling movie in Kaiju cinema can be! Takashi Yamazaki clearly shows dedication and excellent film direction with his characters and plot, which are both easy to follow. Godzilla, in over 7 years since Shin Godzilla, has once again showed brutality and a dark atmosphere to the original Godzilla film. While the characters and the overall tie to the original film is clearly showing, I do wish that a certain character had a bit different character arc. I also wished for a little bit more destruction to Japan, nonetheless, Minus 1 is a must watch for any new or old Gojira fan!
Incredible movie, it feels so refreshing not to see agendas, politics and Wokeness, just a pure human story with an amazing horror element in form of THE BEST GODZILLA the world has ever seen.

Overall, Great film! If you can support this type of movie!

Fist of all im not a 'Godzilla/Monster' fan, i remeber watching the campy 'man in a suit' smashing modles as a kid and never really got in to it. More recent big budget movies like Kong/Godzilla didnt do much to spark my intrest. However this one is well done and with a reported budget of 15million it makes just about all the recent movie budget seem completely unreasonable!
Look it's fine, not great. For me I don't think I could pick up on the metaphors or essence of some cultural aspects
I liked the movie but not enough of GODZILLA and it was too easy to kill him. I was happy to see more ocean battles, but not enough land battles.  But in all the best TOHO MOVIE yet.
Not only an excellent monster movie, also just a very good movie. Look, pictures, the music and how it is used. Great movie!

Wife and I saw Godzilla Minus One the first weekend and totally recommend it. It really is the best Godzilla film ever made, from a human and dramatic standpoint.

The film is not really about the monster, it's about the people struggling to survive in post-war Japan. There are heartbreaking moments that don't have anything to do with Godzilla.

The monster isn't in most of the film, but when it appears, good god. The effects are amazing. This isn't a guy in a rubber suit kicking toy cars around. There are some moments when Godzilla is attacking warships that just took my breath away.  And this film was made for $15M?  It raises the question, how did Hollywood lose the ability to make compelling films on a budget?

It had some nice touches, like the US allowing Japan to re-arm some of their ships to deal with the menace, and post-war tension between the US and the Soviets comes in to play.  It's not a monster movie, it's more like, what if Godzilla happened in the real world, at the tail end of World War II?

There's a heartbreaking moment, where a former Admiral addresses a room full of emotionally scarred combat vets, trying to raise enough volunteers to fight the monster.  These people are all emotional wrecks, completely exhausted, defeated, and for many, with their families destroyed, but somehow have to pull themselves together to meet this new challenge.  It's a very compelling scene and would work in a variety of genres, not just monster films.

It's just a really good film. Like Scorsese had done a monster film.  Go see it!

My understanding is that there will be a competing Godzilla film released next year, and there's some kind of contractual thing where they both can't be in theaters at the same time.  So end of December 2023 Godzilla Minus One has to leave theaters.

The real tragedy is that this film is popular, and theaters could really use the business.
The best film I've seen this year by far!
It was incredibly well-balanced. The action is captivating, the emotional journey of the protagonist is engaging and relatable, and the effects (although wonky at moments) are absolutely stunning.

I give it 4 & half only because Godzilla didnt have as much screen time as I wanted, but thats just me loving the monster. Its a good touching drama story plus the action scenes, totally worth it! And the ending, WOW! No regrets and it wont be for you either! Im glad I saw it on the big screen. Thank you again Godzilla creators!

This is a good movie--but not great.  Upfront I am not a huge Godzilla fan but this was very well done.  It has subtitles and while I typically HATE subtitles they actually improve this movie and it would been worse if it had been done in English.

Unlike the other Godzilla movies I have seen in the past, they made the characters compelling (something their competitors the Marvels, New Hunger Games, and Wish failed to do).  

I have pity for the failed and flawed male lead (definitely not a Mary Sue).  My heart went out to the female lead as well.  Both of them have compelling character arcs.  Their goals and life choices are logically consistent with how they were presented by the director.  Moreover the director presented traditional Japanese culture in a thoughtful way without unnecessary negative commentary. 

This is a Godzilla movie so do not expect to see accuracy in science; this is meant to be fun not technically accurate.  If you demand technical accuracy this is not the movie for you. 

In sum this is a fun and novel twist on an old tale that did not need to "Current Day" the story.

Well worth your time.
Perfect, a work of art if you ask me.
This move was so good if you can watch it in IMAX you will not regret it

The movie was well made. Even though watched the movie in Japanese with subtitles, the main theme and story was easy to follow. Many plot setups had good pay off at the end. The monster was shown as scary and had real consequences for that world. The special effects were good. WW2 backdrop for the movie made in more interesting where the weaponry was limited. Overall must watch.

I still can't believe what a magnificent film this is — it's the first time in 50 years that I loved the characters and wanted them to defeat Godzilla, who is truly terrifying. I was rooting for them all, and actually cried twice! Themes of anti-war, loss, self-forgiveness, family — and a country joining together for a cause they believe in — all of that is here, plus a spectacular monster! We all cheered and applauded at the end. Thank you Takashi Yamazaki and the wonderful cast.

This movie was great.  Although Godzilla only had a few moments in the movie overall, his presence was felt in every scene.  The attention was set mainly on the human cast, and you end up building a connection to the actors, and begin wanting them to be okay.  It probably the first Godzilla movie where I enjoyed the human story as much as the monster story.
This movie captures the spirit of the Japanese original and is the best Kajui movie in decades.

This was movie was not what I was expecting. They managed to make a Godzilla movie, and give it a heart wrenching story dealing with a lot of heavy themes. This is the best Godzilla movie ever made. Best movie aside from Oppenheimer so far.
The underlying story was fantastic, with Godzilla thrown in :) Was well done all around, got the right amount of Titan scenes and a very well put together post WWII story.
Incrível, por mais que eu ame o Legendary Gojira, esse filme foi uma obra prima !!!

This is the best Godzilla movie I have seen since I watch the original (staring Raymond Burr) with my dad back when I was in my single digits.  That they made this a story with a human protagonist on the hero's journey, with the monster Godzilla driving the action, was refreshing, brillant.

I went into this thinking it was going to be like those old B Godzilla movies with the bad dubbing. I hadn't watched any trailers or read any reviews. And WOW. This was not at all what I expected. It was a roller coaster ride from start to finish. I only wish it had been in 3D because Godzilla was big, realistic and terrifying! One of the best movies I have seen all year.

Expectations were met as a fan of monster movies. Loved the setting and character development. I'm personally not much for subtitles however worth it. Atomic breath was incredible!! Recommend seeing it in theaters for sure!

I have been watching Godzilla (and things like Ultraman) since I was a kid. I think I saw my first Godzilla film on Bob Wilkin's "Creature Features" on Channel 2 out of San Francisco. I know I saw Godzilla vs the Smog Monster (Hedorah) in a drive through theater which probably was around late 1972 as it took a while to get to the U.S.

Anyway, I can say this is, hands down, the BEST Godzilla film. However, a caveat to that is what makes it so good is BECAUSE it is a reboot. This is how you 'reboot' a film. You take the essence of the original story(ies) and repurpose it. This wasn't a blatant nostalgia-est like the last 3 crap Star Wars films. This was them using the tropes perfectly. The scientist with the weird hair, the hardened old soldier, the stern military guy (with no neck) and on and on. It was perfect.

I like to say the people my age have Star Wars music in our DNA. Well listening to the music shows I have Kaiju in the blood as well. The music was almost a character itself. Plus, there is so much I can say about this but won't for space reason. I will say this is one of the few Godzilla films I've ever seen where the human story is just as good as watching Godzilla do his thing.  AND THERE WAS NO ANNOYING KID SIDEKICK!  Thank the Maker.

Go see this film right now!

I have seen all the Godzilla movies, I have watched the recent ones with avid fascination of the overly explosive and cheesy plotlines and soaked in every monster fight, rooting for Godzilla, mourning for Mothra…Godzilla Minus One made me almost hate Godzilla! This movie was heart wrenching and humane, barely breathing in some parts. The budget of this movie was 15 million dollars and it's worth is well over that.The best Godzilla movie I have ever seen, something that will not be surpassed. Rooting for the unseen is what makes a director, the absolute best. I will see anything he puts out from now on.
Mwa perfection🥇10/10 W

It's difficult for me to explain how much raw joy this movie made me feel. It's been a long time since a Godzilla film made me care about the people it followed. Shin Godzilla had the perfect approach where it was less about individuals and more about how a government would handle a kaiju situation, while Godzilla Minus One focuses hard on a small group of people, it also makes you want to stay with that group.

The movie has a perfect blend of classic Godzilla, terrifying in its raw power and primal motivations, while also showing you a tale of redemption, honor, grief, and love.

If you've ignored most Godzilla's thinking, they were campy schlock (I'm looking at you 2014, 2019, 2021) you wouldn't be wrong but please do not pass on Godzilla Minus One!

*This movie does not treat the audience like idiots, nor does it have the feeling of smirking at its intelligence, truly perfect.
THE BEST GODZILLA MOVIE EVER!

One of the best made and handsome productions in the Toho franchise of Godzilla.
The story centered more on one man and his experience s of being in WW2. Godzilla was the catalyst for the film.
On a modest budget the film did capture the grandiose feel of  a larger film, but it's the limited use of Godzilla himself that achieved this effect. 
And while exceptional in it's use, it didn't have the over all scale of a Hollywood production. Maybe that's better, maybe that's worst. It's kind of how scifi fans compare the difference in the Star Wars franchise and  the Star Trek franchise.
Less is more, more or less.
It was amazing! The best Godzilla movie since the first one!!

Film’s character development and monster appearances hit every single beat that not only recall the classic Godzilla films but also remind us the human element behind the shock and awe. Godzilla fans should rejoice!
One of the best movie in years. You actually care about the human characters.
An incredible 70th Anniversary for Godzilla.

Can we just let TOHO do all Godzilla movies from now on? Because (Shocker) they seem to understand how to do a Godzilla movie more than what Hollywood has been attempting to do for more than 30 years. For the first time in a long time, I'm actually caring for the human characters in a Godzilla movie.

Godzilla minus one truly captures not only the nuclear aftermath of WWII but also the determination of the Japanese people/culture. Japan suffered a devastating loss and the fight against a force of nature such as Godzilla creates another war (also with nuclear repercussions) for the nation. The character connections felt genuine and even though Godzilla only had about 40% of the screen time, it created an atmosphere of fear but also a stage for the human cast to shine. Best film of 2023, well done Toho

A fantastic Godzilla movie that connects you with the human characters. It has intense and emotional scenes, making it a great Kaiju film. Godzilla's action scenes were at a whole other level, especially considering the 15 million dollar budget. I would definitely watch this film multiple times."
I would have laughed a few times if I wasn’t already crying throughout the whole entire movie…

The best Godzilla movie in the last 40 years without question and it is not even close. Godzilla Minus One is one of those films that just makes you appreciate storytelling and stays far away from all the political nonsense that is being forced by movie studios today. Godzilla Minus One is an instant classic as director Yamazaki knew the assignment and delivered BIG TIME bringing back the Kaiju King aka Godzilla. This is the Godzilla you've been waiting for and it was spectacularly done on a small budget.
10/10 movie this was really good and cinematic

I had all but given up on monster movies until I saw Godzilla Minus One! Godzilla Minus One brought back my passion for monster movies and has proven one thing, no one does it better than the Japanese when it comes to Godzilla, their true creation! This is an absolute must see and it is an instant classic. In my opinion, one of the best monster movies ever made and one of the best Godzilla movies ever made.  This movie truly pays homage to the original Godzilla movies!
The story-line was very well crafted and tied very nicely together to fit the general story of Godzilla.  The characters were very well developed. All the emotion, suspense and thrill you would expect to see in a film like this were there. 
If you are one of those people that has lost your zest for monster movies, and you are looking for the magic that the classic Godzilla movies of old had, then Godzilla Minus One will definitely bring you back from the depths of the Sea of Japan to love Godzilla movies all over again!

After almost 70 years, Toho studios show that they still have great, compelling stories to tell in their Godzilla series. Godzilla Minus One was a fantastic film that recalls the big G's origins from the 1954 film, an anti-war parable of a creature mutated by nuclear radiation. The story is well filmed, terrifically acted, it has great cinematography, a rousing score, and impressive special effects. For a film that was made for about 15 million, it looks significantly more expensive. While the bulk of the film focuses on the story and human characters, this aspect is so well done and keeps you engaged, so that when Godzilla actually shows up, it has greater impact. What you get is an emotional, compelling, thrilling story about regret, survivor's guilt, PTSD, redemption, and what it means to be a family. Not only is this one of the best Godzilla films ever made, it's also one of the best films of the year. Godzilla Minus One is a stunning achievement.
totally enjoyed the movie besides having to read sub titles the whole time.

You really have to admire the attention to detail. From the original tanks, never mind if only two units ever saw the light of day, to the fighter planes, again, only two were made, to the original destroyer(the only survivor of its line & given to Taiwan) and the heavy cruiser(in real life, ignobly sunk as a target ship by the Brits).
This isn't the standard Godzilla film with which we are familiar. All the hype is legit. Anyone can enjoy this film, it transcends what it is. Enjoy it on a big screen while you can.

Old School perfection, even shed a tear or two, a human story, but with the King, with a blast never to be forgotten, Tokyo will never be the same or will you after seeing this movie 5++++ Oscar material no joke

Sure did like the "guy in the suit" vibe on this one more than the straight-up CGI vibe tho.
   Also-hat's off for Toho making this for 10% of the typical crappy Hollywood versions👍
  Really didn't mind the subtitles, either.
Might need to go again, this time in Imax instead of the "projection on the sidewalls" theater, that gimmick didn't do much for me, at least on this movie. Might be better on a space opera sci-fi film.

This movie is the reason alone I started a RT account and what was missing from Oppenheimer, primal fear in the face of nuclear power. This film recaptured the missing elements of previous Godzilla films that inspire both fear and awe. The incredible storytelling of guilt, passion, and redemption was done by incredible actors. Thoroughly enjoyed every minute of the intense action and drama. This is a film worthy to return and share at home.
Movie is AMAZING! From beginning to end. The best Godzilla movie I’ve ever seen.

Awesome movie. Godzilla is King
This movie kicks ass

One of the best movies I've ever seen and possibly THE best Godzilla film out there. Every aspect of this movie delivers: the acting, writing, camerawork, use of lighting, sound, and lack of sound - ALL of it comes together to create an incredible film that anyone can enjoy. Godzilla fans are rewarded with the use of - as well as the subversion of - tropes that are staple to the franchise. Familiarity with the series isn't needed to appreciate this film, but it can certainly enrich it. Every second of screen time is used to its fullest, the human story is compelling and evocative, and the balance of tension, dread, and relief are expertly handled. I have never before experienced a film monster or creature that so effectively instilled a sense of fear and visceral threat. Godzilla appears as every bit the metaphor he was originally intended to be, enriching the human narrative while encapsulating the totality and indiscriminate, animal nature of atomic warfare. The original creative team would have been so proud and so honored by this work. An excellent addition to a 70 year old franchise. And when that iconic theme finally drops? Chills. Whether you've seen all the films or none at all, do yourself a favor and see this one.

This movie is so much more than a monster movie. At it's core lies tragedy and loss on a nuclear level in a post war torn Japan. If you find yourself rooting for the humans it's perfectly okay. Godzilla minus one is a perfect way to celebrate 70 years of Toho/Japan and of course Godzilla.
By far the best of them all.  Often the human story in the movies is the weakest part.  That is not the case here.  10/10.
Really really really really really good movie

Absolutely phenomenal. This is the Godzilla film I’ve wanted to see my whole life. I suggest seeing it on the biggest screen  possible. I saw it in IMAX at the Metreon in SF, and the visuals and sound knocked my socks off. This felt like a passion project. The acting was sensational, characters you care about, and the pacing perfect. And you see so much of Godzilla. I’ve never seen destruction of this scale portrayed so beautifully. You can see it all, up close, with nothing spared. I was floored by the execution. I stand firm that this is the best Godzilla film ever made. The bar is now set and I can’t recommend it enough. 5 stars

It's a fantastic movie all around. Seeing Godzilla and being actually scared of him is something you don't see anymore. There's a scene in this where 4 men are in a small boat when Godzilla shows up. It reminded me of a scene from Jaws. The sound effects blew me away and it has such a great score. I cannot believe this movie only cost 15 million dollars! Go see it.
Beautifully written and directed film.

This is the BEST Godzilla movie I have seen as an adult.  I expected a good to great movie, but this movie is just awesome.  They deliver what you want from Godzilla intertwined with a story with characters you actually care about in an epic drama spanning a period of years.  Please make sequels, but don't rush them and meet the bar you've set with this one!

One big thing I love about the film is that it doesn't feel like Godzilla was CGI at all. I heard that it was CGI but it looks so good that it makes me believed that it wasn't lol. I thoroughly enjoyed the film, highly recommended this film.

I went to watch the film a second time. I love it so much. I took my sister with me and she said she really enjoyed the film. This movie makes everything seems so right because I've seen other Godzilla films and this was one of the best of all time among all those films. Go watch it! Let's support this film together!

This film has it all!  If I read it correctly, the budget was $15 million??? If so it was well spent.  It’s kind of funny when you see studios spend over $200 million and the cgi looks worse.  Great film and has heart!!!

What can I say about this masterpiece of kaiju cinema? I was left speechless when the credits rolled, hell even after. This film has everything a monster movie lover needs and then some. In addition to the truly horrifying presentation of Godzilla and the destruction he wreaks, there is a very human story that tugs at the heart and captures all kinds of emotions amazingly. Hope, despair, love, fear, an astounding amount of emotion can be found here and the actors display them excellently. The original soundtrack is also an unexpected treat. While the movie makes use of the classic Ifukube theme, much of the movie makes use of original compositions by Naoki Sato. These inspire such vivid feelings of helplessness, an overwhelming power hellbent on the destruction of whatever stands in its way. And on the other hand, tracks like Resolution raise you up, filling you with hope as the characters are determined to fight and beat this godly force. The effects are amazing as well, giving us one of the best looking Godzilla movies to date. While returning to his more classic look as opposed to the charred visage of Shingoji, this Minusgoji is still one of the most terrifying incarnations of the lizard with piercing eyes and tremendously physical performances of strength. All together, this isn't just a perfect Godzilla film. It's also one of the best films of the entire year. Another win for Goji.
Best film I’ve seen in a minute. Definitely recommend to see in theaters. Cannot wait for the second one. Fingers crossed.
Instant classic, near-perfect movie. Must watch.

This is the best Godzilla movie since the original. I knew the special effects would blow me away but I had no idea the story would be so strong. The dialogue was wonderful, the acting terrific, this movie should be nominated for an Oscar as best picture of the year. You could take this story about a coward's redemption, with it's war is not glorious undertones, eliminate Godzilla altogether and have a tremendous film left. It's a Godzilla film but it's also a human story about life and how precious it is.

It's just incredible from start to finish. Story, acting, Godzilla & all the action. What an amazing latest installment to a 70 year old franchise. If I could give it 6 stars, I would.
Hands down best Godzilla in a long time. I never usually get invested in the characters but this one did it so well. Must see!

This movie is an absolute masterpiece, and is very Impressive for it's low budget. If you are a Godzilla fan, this is a must see. The movie take during/around world war 2, and is supposed to be like the original. The story is great, the human characters are built well, the movie looks amazing, and it might make you cry a little in some scenes. The best part of this movie is probably Godzilla, he not only feels like a god but also is a true monster like in the first movie. America is only mentioned in this film and never appears on screen, but it makes the whole plot of the movie much better. Overall, this is a just about perfect movie, and a dream come true for many Godzilla fans.
A loving tribute to the original movie.  Well done.

' This is a Spoiler Free review '  How good was this movie?  Ask yourself, when is the last time you went to a theater and at the end of the movie the audience broke out into applause?  The pacing was excellent. In a remarkably short time frame they did so much character development.  Every main character was well rooted and extremely believable.  You couldn't help but feel their joys and sorrows throughout the movie.  The action sequences were perfectly timed, well organized, never dragged out for the sake of some cheap gratuitous violence or shock.  It all fit together so well, I can't think of a single point where the movie dragged.  The setup and payoff were so well done and so satisfying.  Partway in my friend was looking at his phone, I was kinda like wft!  After the movie I found out it was because of his watch.  It monitors his heart rate and it posted an alert basically asking him if he was ok because his heart rate was so high.  Yea, the movie was that kind of edge of your seat exciting.  This was clearly patterned after the original 1954 Gojira original.  And no offense intended to the award winning cinematic masterpiece that the original was, but I think this might have been better than even that.  Go See This!!
Many scenes played homage to the orginals films. The model/toy trains and tanks, were perfect. Thank you, ToHo!
The Best Years of Our Lives meets Jaws meets Top Gun meets Godzilla. It was absolutely wonderful. Heart, soul, and monster stomping action.
Awesome movie,  better than the American versions. Classic!!!!
just watch it he big lizard :3

I've never been frightened during a Kaiju movie before but the sense of menace this one inspires is truly awe inspiring. Don't let this leave theaters without seeing it.
I loved it. This is a true Godzilla movie. Captures the essence of the first Godzilla movies from the 50’s. Godzilla was what he’s supposed to be…TERRIFYING!

This is hands down the best Godzilla movie and my personal favorite. I wouldn't go as to far to say this is the best movie ever made, but 10/10 as far as Godzilla movies go. This is an absolute must watch for anyone, not just Godzilla fans. The only small nitpick I could even say is there are some scenes where the animation feels a bit stiff.  I can understand majority of people not wanting to sit through a subtitled movie, but if you are one of those people, please just give it a chance.

Can’t say I’ve ever really been a fan of Godzilla, but my god has that changed! This is everything a Godzilla movie should be. From the writing, acting, special effects, character development, the score, it’s all perfect. The sound design is so immersive and awesome you feel like you’re right there with the main characters. I was mesmerized throughout the whole film not only with the incredible action sequences and godzillas awesome heat ray, but with the characters we get to spend time with in between. Both honestly equally riveting. I didn’t want anyone to die! Even the random patrons in the background. And that’s because our main characters are so fleshed out they make you feel and really sit with the fact that Japan just finished WW2 and now they have a giant monster terrorizing their country and you just can’t imagine what that’s like. But they’re all willing to fight and sacrifice for their families and a better future for Japan. It was awesome. Highly recommend. The first time we see the heat ray Godzilla has, WOW!! One of the coolest things I’ve ever seen on film.

Watching this piece of extraordinary Japanese filmmaking is the closest I've gotten to the spine tingling delight I received when as a young boy I first saw the original ‘50s Godzilla film on TV. But unlike the Americanized, Raymond Burr-ized genesis of the franchise, this astounding film draws you in with deep emotions delving into the tragedy that was post-war Japan in the immediate aftermath of WWII. The characters really matter - for the first time in a Kaiju movie - and make you care about how to defeat the ‘nuclearized' Big Bad, which in this case is the scariest Godzilla ever witnessed onscreen. Icing on the cake are the music nods to the original, especially the excitement of the march-like musical accompaniment to the creative, 1940's-era efforts to put a stop to the seemingly unstoppable creature at the end. Bravo!
Best Godzilla movie! You know its a great movie, when it makes you love the characters.

I really enjoyed the storyline, this was a sophisticated exploration of postwar Japans state of mind after World War II. Godzilla was a commonality of experience, and the movie explores the call to action each must answer. Im a history student, so the story was very important to follow, even if Im a kaiju fan.
Amazing movie! Took my whole family and we all enjoyed it! 11/10! Always, and forever! Long live the King!

If you are a Godzilla fan 10/10 go see this movie.  If you are not a Godzilla fan 10/10 go see this movie, seriously.  Godzilla Minus 1 is an a well made film that honors the original 1956 release.  Similar to the original, the movie is about human characters dealing with the insanity of a giant monster attacking and laying waste to their homeland.  In Minus 1 they are real people you can connect with which shows quality writing considering it takes place in 1940's defeated Japan.  This is what sets it apart from the recent Hollywood Godzilla releases where the humans detract from the film every second they are on the screen.  Minus 1 in contrast has real people experiencing extreme conditions following the war.  The pain Shikishima deals with connects with the the audience.  He is a flawed man dealing with losing everything it is hard not to feel for him.  Yes this is a monster movie and the humans are adding to the overall film.  The monster scenes are shot well the special effects are well done.  Sound and music score are excellent as well.  See this in a good theater with a good sound system.  
The only caveat is for some people it is in Japanese, and with subtitles.  Even so give it a chance, after a while you don't even realize you are reading them as you get engrossed in the film.  Considering the lack of quality films in the theaters lately, this one stands out.  Is it perfect?  No, I would never say that.  But it sure is worth your time and money to go see it.

By far the best Godzilla movie I've experienced. A real story with characters you care about and terrific special effects. Closest comparison to me was, Jaws. Recommend you see it in a theater to enjoy the full experience.

Best movie I've seen in theaters in YEARS. I was fully invested in the human story and blown away by the scenes with Godzilla. Hands down, this is now my favorite Godzilla movie to date. The musical score was spot on as well. You could hear a pin drop during the quiet moments of the film, and it was a fully packed theater. 10 out of 10.
The best Godzilla movie since the very first IMHO.  This movie was made for the price of a single A lister's pay for a single movie in Hollywood and is easily 10x better.

It is absolutely a Blockbuster movie! Shows the pain and suffering and death of people at the hands of Godzilla! Everything for me was absolutely perfect. I watch Godzilla in 1962 with King Kong and I loved it then. This is a can't miss movie thoroughly enjoyed it and it was absolutely spectacular

It was so AMAZING! Watching Godzilla chase the humans on the boat was intense. the focus on humanity, between the lead and his ghosts of regret, the natural relationship with his roommate and adopted child, the metaphors of the war, ptsd, building back only to be brought down, the classic score mixed with modern score was near perfection!  Watching this made me feel like a kid playing with my toys back in the day, but now as an adult I can see the horror that comes with the devastation. Several times I watched in awe at what Godzilla can do and the devastation he causes to citizens. I didn't like the short arms or the way he walked on land but I understood this is classic toho Godzilla. And though the cgi on land during sunny daylight was noticeable, it can't be faulted with such a low budget. It excelled at night and in the water. Overall, this movie was beautifully done!

"Godzilla Minus One" stands out as an exceptional addition to the Godzilla franchise, earning a resounding 9/10 in my assessment. Shikishima's performance as a kamikaze pilot adds depth to the film, showcasing his versatility in portraying a range of emotions. The connection between Shikishima and Noriko adds a human touch to the storyline.

The film introduces Godzilla in a compelling way, with a notable power-up that sets the stage for an intense narrative. Scenes of destruction, including a powerful event in Ginza, deliver the expected Godzilla spectacle. Tachibana's role, transitioning from an Odo Island survivor to Shikishima's ally, adds an intriguing layer to the plot.

"Godzilla Minus One" skillfully plays with audience expectations, maintaining viewer engagement in the characters' journeys. The supporting cast, including Noba, the captain, and the kid, significantly contributes to the overall narrative.

What distinguishes this Godzilla installment is its meticulous attention to character development and exploration of post-war themes. Shikishima's internal struggle and the film's exploration of life after war elevate it beyond typical monster movie fare. The music scoring, featuring both original compositions and nostalgic Ifukube moments, enhances the emotional resonance of the story.

The climax, involving a daring plan to confront Godzilla, is executed with precision. The film's creativity shines through in the use of unique elements during the battle.

In conclusion, "Godzilla Minus One" is a standout Godzilla film that combines monster mayhem with thought-provoking character arcs. The hints at the end leave room for future narratives. Without diving into specifics, I strongly recommend this movie as the best Godzilla experience I've encountered. It's truly an amazing cinematic journey that both Godzilla enthusiasts and general audiences should not miss.

Spoilers and here's my spoiler review!!!


"Godzilla Minus One" is an absolute triumph, earning a solid 9/10 in my book. Shikishima's portrayal as the conflicted kamikaze pilot adds depth to the film, showcasing his range in expressing emotions from fear to triumph. The dynamic between him and Noriko is compelling, adding a human touch to the Godzilla narrative.

The power-up of Godzilla, with menacing dorsal spines and the imminent threat of his devastating beam, keeps the audience on the edge of their seats. The destruction of Ginza and the subsequent scenes, including the powerful explosion, deliver the expected Godzilla spectacle. Tachibana's evolution from a survivor on Odo Island to Shikishima's reluctant ally adds an intriguing layer to the storyline.

The film cleverly toys with our expectations, especially regarding Tachibana's escape pod, keeping the audience engaged in the characters' fates. The supporting cast, including Noba, the captain, and the kid, contribute significantly to the overall narrative.

What sets this Godzilla installment apart is the meticulous attention to character development and the exploration of post-war trauma. Shikishima's internal struggle, combined with the poignant themes of choosing to live after the horrors of war, elevates the film beyond typical monster movie fare. The music scoring, featuring both original compositions and nostalgic Ifukube moments, enhances the emotional resonance of the story.

The climax, involving a daring plan to sink Godzilla and the subsequent showdown, is executed with precision. The use of freon bubbles and CO2 balloons adds a unique twist to the battle, showcasing the creativity in the film's storytelling.

The finale delivers an unexpected emotional punch, challenging our perceptions of sacrifice and survival. The salute as Godzilla's body disintegrates is a powerful visual moment, reinforcing the themes of the film.

In the end, "Godzilla Minus One" stands out as a standout Godzilla film, blending monster mayhem with thought-provoking character arcs. The flash of Godzilla sinking, starting to regenerate, hints at the potential for future narratives. This movie not only pays homage to the iconic franchise but also pushes its boundaries, making it a must-watch for both Godzilla enthusiasts and those seeking a deeper cinematic experience.

When we talk about the historical presence of Godzilla, we talk about his beginnings. This movie is full of intense suspense and emotional dialogue. From great visual's to immense sound, Godzilla Minus One is a true gem among all Godzilla and Kaiju movies. What you need to know is that this doesn't just base Godzilla in a world war 2 time period, it's the restart of his new era. This movie is so good, with characters you can enjoy to follow along and feel for. Something most Godzilla movies don't have. Then you got Godzilla himself, a mean, nasty and scary force of nature, that's out for blood and terrorizes the country of Japan alone. See it if you can, you won't be disappointed.

This film made me cheer for the human side, which I rarely do in a Godzilla film. It's primarily because of how well-written the human characters are, and made me care for them and their struggles.

I've seen every Gojira Movie many times over.  I've seen every monster movie produced in Japan.  This is by far the best one ever made, by far. Good Character development, great story going back to it's roots.  I had to watch this in every way possible, imax, 4Dbox, and XD AMAZING!!!

Worthy of a watch, but not worthy of the hype. At times the plot survived on coincidence and the decision-making of the characters was questionable. In the final chapter of the movie, there was a complete indescribable lack of urgency that only existed to help drive the plot. The acting was, well, acting. The CGI was really impressive. While weak at times, the general story kept my interest. If anything, this is a lesson for Hollywood in how to make a decent movie without spending the GDP of a small country.

This film is a masterpiece. This film is a towering achievement in tokasatsu cinema. For fans of Kaiju films (Japanese monster movies) this film tops the list of must-see cinema. For those who are not monster movie fans, this film has such a heartfelt, moving plot, that you will not be bored when Godzilla isn't on screen. This film has the best characters I've seen in a monster movie since the original godzilla film "Gojira" of 1954.

Like other great films, this movie bends genres a little bit. This film is a monster movie, but it's also a family drama, a tale of surviving war. This movie bends several genres of film into one, emotional story that makes the human characters incredibly engaging, and Godzilla seem down right evil. In many Godzilla films, we find ourselves rooting for Godzilla. Not this time... In this film, there comes a moment where it becomes clear that Godzilla has to be stopped. There is a point where Godzilla's malevolence is so clearly a threat to our characters, that you actively root for his defeat.

Please go see this film in Japanese with English subtitles. I saw this film yesterday and I plan to see it again before the week is through. 10/10 Greatest monster movie ever made.

Fantastic! I would highly recommend it as an entry point for newcomers to Godzilla. A real emotional story that truly shows the devastating impact Godzilla has on the lives of humans beyond buildings being destroyed. This is an excellent disaster film on top of being a giant monster movie.

This is by far the best Godzilla film I've ever seen and it's not even close. The only thing that could have made this film any better, if it was in English. Even with the subtitles, the movie was easy to follow. This is the Gold Standard of how Monster movies should be made.

Best Godzilla movie in decades. The visuals were done well on a mere $15 million budget from Toho. Instead of portraying Earth's savior like in the American versions, Godzilla goes back to his roots as a terrifying menace for the citizens of Japan. What really separates this movie from all other kaiju films is the human storyline. Instead of dealing with science fictional topics such as aliens or creating a basic story with forgettable characters, Godzilla Minus One gives us characters with solid backgrounds and throughout the movie you build an emotional connection with almost every one of them. They also tackle very difficult subjects to talk openly about in society,such as PTSD, survivor's guilt and depression. Overall Godzilla Minus One is a mixture of the original 1954 film with a tone and character arc similar to Jaws, while also mixing in tidbits of Jurassic Park. All bias towards the Godzilla films we grew up watching put to the side, this could very well be the greatest kaiju movie of all time.
Refreshing. Some plain good cinema

Best Godzilla film, because it has a good solid believable plot and characters with depth.  Godzilla is terrifying, but serves as the catalyst for the Koichi Shikishima confronting his own war trauma and guilt and cowardice, leading to his redemption.

(See on biggest scene!)To be clear I have not seen every Godzilla nor foreign film. This is not only my favorite Godzilla movie I've seen but this is my favorite foreign film I've seen. It action packed, it felt genuinely terrifying at points, and the drama between the human characters is incredibly well written to the point where I got misty eyed multiple times. Go see this movie in IMAX, the sound alone is worth seeing it on the biggest scene possible.
Great film, it made me care about the characters, and Godzilla was actually almost scary. There was great tension. Must see movie.

It is a surprisingly emotional movie, and the focus is on recovering from the war. Time is spent exploring the motives of the characters and it even has a surprise ending. I thought it an excellent movie.

Wow, such an amazing movie.  The Director did a fantastic job.  How they did so much with such a low budget - puts many of the latest marvel movies to shame.  A great mix of drama, a love story and then the mahem that Godzilla brings.  One of the scariest Godzilla movies out there.

No Spoilers!

My favorite Godzilla Film by far! To be fair I haven't yet seen Shin Godzilla, but I'm extra motivated to now. 

Minus One hits on so many levels and really brings back the magic of the film medium. 

The alternate history (Post WWII) setting in Japan is very much real and alive in the story and you are immediately pulled into the struggles of the recently defeated Empire, with their own unique cultural and material hardships as experienced through the fantastic cast of compelling characters. There are multiple moments where I had realizations that I'm not used to seeing these stories on film the post WWII Japan stories and struggles. 

This movie is heartfelt and thematically rich. 

And the monster....truly a monster and a "Force of nature" is a good way to describe him. They did re-shoot some of the scenes of the first film, but also added some new tricks and fresh ideas with innovative moments. I especially like that some of the movement of Godzilla seemed to be an homage to the original suit movement and it totally worked. At other times he does move in a much more menacing and agile way. He's fierce. 

The score worked amazingly and whereas I'm usually like a corpse watching movies...I actually had some reactions to scenes with this one because it was super easy to react in concern or celebration for the characters. 

This thing is epic and gripping and I haven't ruled out a second viewing this coming weekend.

The only reason I gave a 4.5/5 rather than a 5/5 is the occasional over-the-top Japanese acting made me laugh during serious moments throughout the movie. Other than that slight detail this is hands down one of the best, if not THE best Godzilla movies I've ever seen.

One of the best films I've seen all year. The story touches your heart while the action elevates it. Expertly balanced with humor, the film also avoids 99% of the pitfalls, shortcuts, assumptions, and story holes that sink most films of this genre. And that atomic breath ... oh my!

I saw it in Japan and was blown away. I don't understand why Toho didn't market Minus One as a remake of the original film, which it is. They've updated the metaphor and it really works. This is at center a human drama with Godzilla there to represent war and regret and guilt and it really works.

Out of the 21 Godzilla films I have seen, this is the best one. A problem with most Godzilla films is that all their human story’s suck! Even some newer American ones. But this one’s human story is great! I’m glad Toho waited until they could really do CGI great because it paid off! Over all it is a great movie and I’d recommend this movie to everyone it’s just that great. I saw it at my local B&B and I’m going to see it again at IMAX

The movie was great I would go to my grandparents house as a kid and would watch the original movies. To see it done with modern technology this movie is very awesome. A sequel to Shin Godzilla, this was not. The acting was not great most of the time, with but a few actors doing a decent job. The characters could have been pretty good, but their arcs never paid off in a way I felt satisfied by. Godzilla was not around in much, and I know thats often the case in these movies. However, the REALLY good entries do a great job of keeping Godzilla present in your mind, and as a source of tension while he isnt on screen. SPOILERS: Godzilla was too fast and nimble. Godzilla was surprisingly small for some reason (maybe to make it more believable that hed be so fast and nimble?). The movie was too long with too many scenes with characters I didnt find very compelling. The child probably could have been erased from the script, to cut some fat off the runtime AND make the character motivations a bit stronger. SPOILER END
I heard in a director interview that the goal was to make the scariest Godzilla yet, but I was underwhelmed by the design choices for the creature. And if they were trying to make the movie itself the scariest yet, I wish more inspiration had been taken from Shin Godzillas visual style. 
The best part of the movie was definitely the music. I just wish it hadnt been wasted on this film as it did most of the heavy lifting. I understand its a very Japanese film, made for Japan. So I hope Japanese audiences enjoyed it, and I hope the true fans of the Godzilla franchise got something they wanted out of this one, but I was disappointed the whole way through.

It is a fantastic movie. One the best story driven Godzilla movies ever made in my humble opinion. Amazing effects even for a Godzilla movie. It is a period piece that takes place in post WW2 Japan. This is where some disconnect happens with American audiences. I am of Japanese decent and my parents experienced post WW2 Japan. There were many heart felt scenes that demonstrated suffering with Japanese cultural sensibilities that struck a chord with me that left others around me in the audience audibly snickering. If you lack empathy for those suffering with PTSD and survivors guilt in other cultures that are not your own, then this movie is NOT for you. Because it is the primary motivation of the main character throughout this movie.

Godzilla Minus One is a compelling post WWII Japan period piece that could stand on its own two legs without the titular character. Kaiju fans fear not as  the king of monsters cements his place on the throne.

Yamasaki's reimagining of Godzilla as allegory for personal and collective wartime trauma is a worthy companion to Honda's original classic. 

There's enough spectacle for casual kaiju fans, compelling characters for those who aren't, and plenty of thematic weight for those who want it. Yamazaki threads a tight needle and succeeds in making one of the franchise; as well as of the genre all together.

If you require your special effects and acting perfect to western standards, this movie isn't for you.  It has a ridiculously lumbering and "thick" Godzilla, and bad "overacting".  That being said, if you loved the original Japanese Godzilla movies, as corny as they were, you'll love this.   It shares a lot in common with the original Godzilla movie.   Despite it's foreign sensibilities that some western audiences my find lacking, their are some surprisingly deep and resonate themes at play--like the shame and trauma of a soldier for instance.     It's a Godzilla movie, so don't expect every aspect to be logical--like how long it would have taken to attach all those tugboat lines to the warships during the climax.  lol.   My only complaint  was they broadcast the twist in the ending a bit too much, and I would have preferred the less happy version of the ending.   ...but overall loved it.

I loved the acting and the plot was a different take. It's easily the best Godzilla Movie, I've every watched. I wish Hollywood would learn something from this and start producing quality movies again. They won't of course. That would be too much like right for them.

Another Absolute Masterpiece from Toho Studios. Comparable to the original in terms of story and the modern effects are of high quality, better than most movies that have come out this year. As a die-hard Godzilla fan I thoroughly enjoyed this film and absolutely loved how the beloved character was remastered for today's audience. I HIGHLY Recommend this film!
Movie of the year? Loved every scene almost cried, perfect movie

Godzilla Minus One stands as an unparalleled masterpiece, redefining the landscape of monster movies. In this cinematic triumph, Writer-Director Takashi Yamazaki delivers a modern moviemaking masterclass, surpassing any Godzilla or monster film emanating from Hollywood since JAWS. TOHO Films, under Yamazaki's helm, has elevated the genre exponentially. This is not just a Godzilla movie; it's a testament to the potential of genuine character development and storytelling in the colossal world of kaiju. Hollywood should reflect on the profound impact achievable through true moviemaking artistry. Don't miss out on the cinematic event of the holiday season; gather everyone and experience it on the grandest screen available!"

I first became a fan of Godzilla in 2014, when director Gareth Edwards directed the aptly titled "Godzilla." I remember the crowd cheering when the MUTOs head was taken off by Godzilla's heat ray. So imagine my excitement when I hear Director Gareth Edwards had seen this movie and revealed his thought, and it was of envy. He wished he had made a movie as good as this one. Let me tell you folks, he's not wrong, because this may be the best since the original, which is my personal favorite. 
The 1954 "Gojira" became my favorite Godzilla as soon as I saw it, and has never been contested... until now. "Godzilla: Minus One" is most definitely the best since the original, but is the only one that stands to rival it in quality, heart, narrative, acting and themes. Godzilla himself is at his most brutal and violent in this movie, targeting individuals with intent. The devastating effects of Godzilla's rampages are both an awe and terror to behold. Also, let's not forget the modest budget that was less than $15 million, yet the film achieves fantastic visuals and set design.  I was immersed in this heartfelt, somber, yet hopeful story. I've seen this film twice over now, and I recommend everyone to see this film in the cinema as many times as you can, not only because it's amazing, but we need to support amazing films such as this in a time where $300 million plus movies are delivering us subpar quality. 

In short, "Godzilla: Minus One" is a spectacular blockbuster, and my favorite movie of the year.
Great movie, definitely one for fans of the franchise. Only take away, would have liked to see more of Godzilla.

Great fun, surprisingly moving and never dull, this stands heads and (gigantic, deadly) tails above any attempt at the series by Hollywood. Toho knows what makes these movies work, and it hits the stride, with only a few cliches to bog down scatted moments. Highly recommended!

Absolutely brilliant. A Godzilla movie that actually focuses on story and characters while still delivering on heart pounding, spellbinding action.

Perhaps the best in the entire franchise since the 1954 original.  I was both surprised and deeply moved by the intricate and powerful human storyline; usually the people in Godzilla movies are little more than point-and-scream fodder, or play out soap opera tropes in what is basically padding between scenes of rampage and destruction.  In Godzilla Minus One, the characters are faced with constant struggle but manage to endure, and there was nary a dry face by the time the credits rolled. Another great aspect of this movie is the ground-view perspective of Godzilla's attack against the cities.  They're well-rendered to be absolutely terrifying.  I went into this movie fearing the franchise had run its course, and there was no way to make it fresh and vibrant after 70 years...but Toho Studios has delivered an incredible masterpiece, and one that I plan to see over and over.

Best Godzilla movie ever, including original.  American directors please watch this to know how to make a Godzilla movie.  They got everything right, the story, special effects and for us fan boys the King is awesome.

I won't talk about the 40 minutes of hoopla one has to sit through at Regal theaters...ugh. The movie was not what I expected. The backdrop is right after WWII. You seemingly are taken into a Tokyo devastated from the allied bombing. The story is immersive and compelling. You like the characters. The time period is amazing. The sets & special effects all add to the story telling. This is the best movie I have seen all year! I'm really glad I went. I was not expecting it to be this good!

This is a beautiful movie about courage in the midst of trauma, fear, and grief. The acting, directing, and cinematography combine for a powerful movie experience. Our entire family loved it.
nearly a perfect movie!!
Amazing movie must watch

Godzilla Minus One is incredible. Can't believe it only cost 15M to make. Godzilla is like this rampaging angry injured animal that does not have peace.  His war is never over.  

For a split second I thought they were breaking the rules of Godzilla and he was eating people.  But then he shows that he has no care whatsoever to eat someone and only wants to kill people and destroy stuff.  And if there was any doubt he shows it again. 

Beautiful, horrible  destruction. He is so bloodthirsty that he doesn't think and is hyper focused at times. 

There is no marvel move bullcrap. No annoying comedy relief sidekick. No string of quippy one liners during action sequences. No one sided politically motivated preaching. 

Just the undeniable truth that war is a totally horrible thing and all lives matter. No one is disposable.

One of the best - if not the best movie of 2023 - Godzilla Minus One. This movie contains many layers - historical, culturally, romantically, and last but not least the best monster and Godzilla movie of all time. With a budget of only 15 million, Godzilla Minus One looks more like the best 220 million Marvel movie. This is better than most Marvel movies. The pacing of the movie is fantastic. Lots of action sequences that tie perfectly into the story line like pairing your best chocolate and red wine. The surround sound makes you feel like you are in the midst of the action. My daughter - age 6 - was frightened but excited by the sheer magnitude of Godzilla's force. She wants to see it again. This is one bad monster. Move over John Wick - there is a new Sheriff in town. See it on IMAX.
Can't go wrong with a Godzilla movie. A little slow in the beginning but I thought the movie was awesome
There's not much I can add that others have not already said. It's an excellent movie and you should go out of your way to see it.

Best Godzilla movie ever! My one minor nitpick is the rationale for US not being involved in the fight at all, as not wanting to rachet up tensions with the USSR. I get why, as it wanted to focus on the Japanese aspect of the movie, but the movie was set in 1945-1947 or 48 in the middle of the American occupation of Japan when the US already had tens of thousands of troops stationed there and with Gen. MacArthur's occupation HQ smack in the middle of Tokyo.  Think the US would've at least sent up a few fighters to harass Big G...  Also, Japan was demilitarized at the time with no army or navy.  However, I can get pass the minor historical nitpick and just enjoy the awesomeness of the movie!

Very refreshing to see Godzilla return as a tragic character that embodies the emotion and struggles of post-war Japan.  This seems to be the perfect mix of human characters that you actually care about, story development, and great action scenes without going over the top.  I have seen every Godzilla film at least 3 times, and this one is now right up with Godzilla (1954), Godzilla vs. Destoroyah, and Shin Godzilla (unpopular opinion, but it's one of my favorites). Do yourself a favor and see it while it's still in theatres.
Wow the best Godzilla Film I have ever seen.

Excellent. Truly amongst the best, if not the very best, Godzilla movie. Inventive, fresh take on godzilla, but more importantly, an often unseen (in the US at least) look at life in Japan after the war, and what it did to the people there. First Godzilla movie in a long time I really cared about the characters and wanted to see them not only survive, but have a happy ending.

First off, I'm not a Godzilla fan and not a fan of subtitles and I don't write reviews. I feel this one needs some exposer since it's so good and I'm worried people will miss out.  This year's movie releases have been so bad I hadn't even gone to the theater in 2023. I heard a ton of buzz about this movie and decided to give it a chance. I have watched some classic subtitled Japanese movies like 7 Samurai and it was worth the watch but I'm generally not a fan of subtitles.

Back to the point, "Godzilla Minus One" was a great flick. I decided to see it in the theater because I've never seen a Godzilla movie on the big screen and I thought the subtitles would be easier to read. I was right. The theater sounds and the big screen made it heart pumping. I don't remember the last time I'd felt an actual adrenaline rush watching a film. The subtitles were much easier to keep up with also and didn't feel like a slog keeping up with the dialog. There was young girl with her dad sitting near me and she did have trouble keeping up with the subtitles so keep that in mind if you're taking your kids and they're maybe not the fastest readers.

I think I might have liked the history aspect a little better than the monster but again, I'm not a Godzilla fan. There's a very good love/history story that's integral to the plot. I use the word "history" a little loosely since it's modified a bit but generally it's correct and would be helpful to know the basics prior to watching the movie. The Monster is just a force of nature in early postwar Japan and the effects were great. I've heard they're practical effects but I don't know if that's true. I couldn't really tell so if they are practical effects they did a great job and generally looked better than what Hollywood has been pushing out for the last few years. Plus, you actually get to see the monster in good light doing things. Not cut shots and in the dark to try and make him scary but save money on the effects.

I'd really recommend seeing this. It's so different than the Hollywood Godzilla movies it's worth it just to see how it's interpreted by the nation that created him.

It was fine.  On the plus side, the visual effects were pretty good most of the time (esp. considering the small budget), and Godzilla was scary and had personality.  The immediate post-war setting of this film lends the metaphor of Godzilla more weight, and it has an overall uplifting message while being critical of government.   

Unfortunately, the human element of the story was excessively melodramatic, the movie hides information from you to generate fake tension that none of the characters themselves feel (because they know something you don't), and plot contrivances abound with characters inexplicably finding each other in chaotic crowded locations that make no sense.

It was a completely fine movie, but I'm not quite sure what all the fuss is about.
Was blown away. The Ginza scene was one of the best I’ve seen in any movie. The score and story were fantastic. Definitely worth the price of admission!

First Godzilla movie I have watched where I was not hoping that it would kill off all of the main characters. Go figure, it is possible to create a Godzilla movie without including a bunch of annoying characters who you want dead. If this movie cost 15 million to make as it is reported, than Hollywood is wasting buckets of money on the garbage they have been spewing out for the past decade. Highly recommend it though you will leave with a renewed appreciation for just how bad such projects as Apple's Monarch: Legacy of Monsters truly is.

This movie does it all. And in a budget of $15 million? Hollywood should take notice! You could make 16 of these films for the cost of one "the marvels"…

The best movie I have seen in 2023, and one of the best overall films I've seen in the last five years. Few films have moved me emotionally like this one. Film is supposed to touch us on an emotional level, and this movie did that and more.

The one thing I felt was missing was inner motivation of Godzilla, it serves as an instrument, a metaphore.

Really recommend it.

The film sadly contains some flaws but they can really be boiled down to timing issues that take away from the stakes and inconsistencies in how Nuclear bombs work. Overall this film understands what it needs to be, and delivers.My favorite Godzilla film by far.

Excellent and even intense in parts. Acting was really good and the story was a lot smarter than the last 2 monsterverse movies. If you like godzilla at all, you will love this movie. I have seen it twice already with my kids who also loved it.

Godzilla Minus One (2023) is a great kaiju film, and a worthy addition to the Godzilla franchise. It is a respectful and nostalgic tribute to the original Godzilla film, and also a fresh and modern take on the genre. It has a strong and emotional story, a likable and relatable cast, a majestic and menacing Godzilla, and a stunning and realistic visual effects. It is a film that appeals to both fans and newcomers of Godzilla, and it is a film that celebrates the 70th anniversary of the franchise. It is a film that deserves to be seen on the big screen, and it is a film that will make you feel a range of emotions, from fear and awe, to sadness and joy. It is a film that will make you think and feel, and it is a film that will make you appreciate the king of monsters
Lovely film with a big scary monster!

Great movie! Human characters were compelling and well-developed. Loved the post WWII Tokyo setting and the characters struggling to cope with the shame of listing the war and the struggle to rebuild and move forward. Also Godzilla was a truly terrifying force off nature (THOSE ATOMUC BLASTS 🤯). Only negative was that I would have liked a little more of Godzilla destroying Tokyo, but what you get is truly win done.
Loved the movie but guest in the theater were loud and would not stop talking

I guess you could call me a G-fan. And if you too are a G-fan, then you too must watch this movie.

Of the 38 Godzilla films out there (Japanese + US), I've seen 36, but I own them all and have for a while now. Most G-fans know Shin Godzilla (2016) was a high point for the TOHO Godzilla films. We really wanted to see a sequel come off of that reboot for the franchise. Well TOHO had other ideas and decided to make Minus One instead. 

This film plus Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire sort of makes up the 70th anniversary of the Godzilla franchise. Along with the Apple TV+ MonsterVerse series.

This movie had a significantly smaller budget than you're used to, not only for a Godzilla movie, but for movies in general. $15 million is difficult to fathom in modern times. And for the most part, the movie looks very competent. Shin Godzilla (2016) had set the standard for Japanese Godzilla film effects, but Minus One bests it.

This film also has a much smaller scope than you're used to for a Godzilla film, but for me was a good point. Arguably when of the best human stories ever for a G-entry. This also go well with a miniscule budget, and this time you actually care for the protagonists.

At 2 hours 10 minutes, this exceeds the typical kaiju sweet spot of 90 minutes to 1 hour 45 minutes. There were some quiet/dialog scenes that dragged a little for me and for the first 2 thirds most events were fairly predictable. What I was NOT expecting were developments that came in the third act, which I will not spoil.

The score utilizing the iconic OG Godzilla theme is off the chain. Most of the movie is not booming loud, but scenes featuring the original theme blew me away sonically and then some.

As a nice chaser, if you are also a G-fan of the Legendary Pictures MonsterVerse movie, I would also recommend the Apple TV+ Monarch: Legacy of Monsters series.

My quickie review on this movie and more can be found on our movie review podcast: Prognosis Negative, wherever you listen to podcasts.

https://prognosisnegative.libsyn.com/site
An absolutely wonderful blend of emotion, cgi, and weight this film brought. Absolutely recommend for anyone, not just long time Godzilla fans.

The Godzilla monster also looked incredibly epic.

I went expecting a good old campy monster stomp and in the old tradition, and instead I got an intensely emotional human-focused story about the Japanese experience of defeat after WWII, survivor's guilt, a chance for redemption, and the choice to live.  The story was set in the ruins of Japan after WWII, when their country had been largely destroyed but their society had not, and it used the experiences of a failed kamakaze pilot as a proxy for the entire nation's struggle to redefine duty and purpose in the new era.  The existential threat of Godzilla was a chance to prove that Japan's people could stand on their own, even against a creature that clearly represented echoes of the country's very real nuclear trauma.  One of the most satisfying parts of the film was the very clear character arc that the main protagonist goes through, which included sensitively portrayed moments of PTSD and the importance of relationships in recovery and life purpose.  I cannot praise the writing, casting, and acting highly enough, this was without a doubt the best film I have seen in a very long time.  Both my buddy and I got up from our seats teary-eyed.

There are five things that potential viewers should keep in mind: 
1) This a Japanese film about Japanese people having an experience in a distinctly Japanese historical and cultural context.  It's not diverse, it generally doesn't have an agenda, and it does not apologize for the story it is telling.  If you need your stories steeped in caveats and humble acknowledgements of tribal land, the patriarchy, imperialism, or whatever else occupies people these days, this is not your cup of tea.  It's a serious story about realistic people, not a university kumbaya session.
2) The version of the film I saw, and to my knowledge the only one, was in Japanese with English subtitles.  This doesn't bother me at all, I would rather have the real acting and voices with subtitles any day of the week.  Some people don't feel the same, though, so if you really can't handle subtitles then this may not be for you.  Although I really suggest you put in the effort so you can watch The Seven Samurai and The Hidden Fortress...
3) The budget for this film was not large, and if you're expecting special effects on par with a $250 million USD Disney blowout you're going to be disappointed.  It was obvious that nearly every wide shot, especially the ships, was entirely CGI.  If you're a stickler for the most believable visuals and any doubt of realism ruins your experience, that might be a deal killer.  That said, because the special effects existed in service to the plot and not as the centerpiece of the film, they were absolutely good enough.  Hollywood take note, if your writing and acting is good, you don't need to spend the GDP of a small country on asset creation and rendering.
4) In certain parts of the film they made liberal use of low-frequency sound to amp up the drama and anxiety of a scene.  Legit strategy, but it seemed a little overused sometimes where I felt silence would have been better.  On the other hand, it made the silent parts of the film more impactful by contrast, so maybe they made the right choice.
5) This story is far better if you have some understanding of Japan's experience in the prior century leading up to WWII so you understand the context.  If you're interested in that, I recommend you take a look at Dan Carlin's Supernova in the East episodes, part of the Hardcore History podcast.  If you're willing to put 30+ hours into the learning process, you will be rewarded with a great appreciation for what Japanese people went through and the forces shaping Japanese thought in that period.

This is by far and away the best version of the Godzilla franchise that I have seen in a very long time. In fact, even better than the 1950's classic original. The key is the wonderful human element added. The plot is just as much about one man's redemption as it is about Godzilla on a rampage. Another original aspect is the timeline. This version of Godzilla is post World War 2 in a devastated Japan. What an original plotline, a Kamikaze pilot loses his nerve, (and who could blame him) and guides his plane to a repair facility on an island claiming mechanical failure with the plane. Then Godzilla appears on the island and starts squashing the solders like bugs. This haunts the pilot and causes his own personal war. 
    Now let's talk about the monster! I love this version of Godzilla. This is not a version that wants to protect humans, this Godzilla wants to squash humans and cause general destruction and chaos. An evil fiend indeed, like a mindless zombie who just wants to feed, Godzilla just wants to destroy. Fantastic effects as well. Very realistic in the destruction scenes. 
    How Godzilla was eventually rid of is one of the more original ideas in this type of genre.  The only reason I did not give it a full 5 stars is mainly I thought the pilot played by Ryunosuke Kamiki had a serious case of William Shatner overacting. 
  Otherwise, the best Godzilla movie I have ever seen! Could save the franchise.

This movie was genuinely terrifying, not only was it one of the first godzilla movies where we actually cared about the main characters who aren't giant lizard monsters, but it provided one of the best casts of characters I have seen in a new movie in a while. It goes to show that with good writing, good acting, and a good message, a low budget cannot stand in the way of a good movie.
Amazing. While I didn't think the ending was that believable with some of the characters, it made me happy that it happened anyway.
Is this how movies are in Japan? I have to look more into that, it reminds me of movies made back in the 80s, when they spawned beloved franchises they are failing to remake 40 years later.

I went in to this thinking most movies suck and Godzilla Minus One has to be at least average if nothing else. Great movie and I al planning to see it again here just two days removed from the first viewing!

This is easily one of the best Godzilla movies since the original. I have been a life long fan of Godzilla. I have seen them all. Even the '97....thing. The Movie was amazing.  The characters were well developed and their back stories were compelling.  You almost forget you are watching a Godzilla Movie. This film was fabulous.  Not only was it a monster movie, but it was one that focused on depth of character of the key people.  It had a great storyline and was exceptionally well written.  I really felt for the characters and it seemed like I was there in the movie with them.  This was the best movie I have seen in years.  Highly recommended.

Great movie!  Saw it twice opening weekend.  Great storyline and the subtitles were timed perfectly. My only concern is why Noriko was the only one with radiation signs and not Shikishima, when he had more exposure.  We really enjoyed the movie.

Bare bones review to avoid spoilers: I normally dislike romance/human drama in my Kaiju films, but Godzilla -1 made me actually care about these people.  The humans were definitely the center of the film, Godzilla seemed very much the B plot unless he was actively stomping around and, wow, on the one hand the model on land seemed very clunky, little to no mobility with teeny tiny arms... but on the other it had PRESENCE.  Like, yes, Godzilla can't do a backflip and is walking with a train dangling from his mouth like a dog's chewtoy, but that slow forward momentum was UNSTOPPABLE.

And, as previously stated, the humans and their own internal struggles are the heart of this movie.  I especially loved the Doctor who came up with the plan to stop Godzilla (which seems very pie-in-the-sky but MOVIE LOGIC) because he reminded me of my Uncle.

I was disappointed because Godzilla was only in it for a very short time and he was not the focus. IT was a war character drama. Godzilla could have been swapped with any monster or enemy. There's no lore or personality for Godzilla.
