This was a great film. Not just a good Godzilla film, but an overall enjoyable experience. The characters and storyline drew you in as audience member, and you couldn't help but root for them. We'll put together, suspenseful and thrilling.
I love the human aspect and Godzilla is just a force of nature.

Saw this as a group of 3 men aged 16, 45, 55. Full price tickets at an OK theater with food & drinks, all regular adult prices. Godzilla Minus One is easily one of the most fun popcorn movies in recent years. It is teriffic fun to see Godzilla stomp his way across the big screen in big, earthshaking Dolby surround, but this movie is actually a good movie in its own right. I cared about the characters and rooted for them. The writing, acting and special effects were three or five cuts ABOVE the CGI "content" flushing out of the Mouse House. Tons of destructable models and old school rubber suit stuff. Fun to watch, and technically well done. Godzilla was a monster of a main character in his own movie, not an afterthought. We got to see him in (seriously) terriffying full size, in good light, with full body shots and close-ups. Just awesome. The movie was just over 2 hrs long, in Japanese with English subtitles. We were hooked in the first few minutes, time flew by, and the subtitles were fine to watch. Bottom line: Godzilla Minus One is a popcorn movie worth every penny. No hidden agenda BS, no politics, and every full price ticket supports all the great people at Toho who made this masterpiece on a shoestring budget with just sweat equity and a love for Godzilla movies. Loved every minute, will pay full price to see this again with my grown kids later this month, in an MX sound theater if possible. Go to the theater with a friend, and have a great time. Encourage people to make great movies like this again.
True to origins - excellent plot - well done!

Absolute genre defining masterpiece. Will make you cry, will make you feel fear. Grabs a hold of you in the beginning and takes you on a ride. Go see this movie. You may never see another like it in this lifetime.

Absolute cinema. Thought it was going to be just another cheesy monster movie, and while yes Godzilla is definitely the reason I saw it, the human characters gave the story so much weight. There's meaningful character growth in multiple characters that are dealing with themes of PTSD, survivors guilt, acceptance, forgiveness, loss, hope, despair. This movie will make you feel feelings. It's also a legit disaster movie and is not afraid to pull any punches. People die. Horribly. And those that don't have to deal with that fact. There are many parallels with the original Gojira, but visually updated for 2023 without looking like a video game. Not a depressing movie at all, but at the same time if you go into it expecting the cheesy camp from some earlier Godzilla titles you are in for a rude awakening. Highly recommended. Go see it as soon as you can.

Loved almost every aspect of this.  Godzilla was actually rendered in a way that his presence really was menacing. Setting it in post-WWII Japan was a great choice. The backstory of the main character was compelling, and I was totally engrossed even when Godzilla was no where to be found.
Best movie of 2024!!!
By far the best adaptation of Godzilla! This movie is a rollercoaster of emotions that will have you wanting more!

So so good!
Not the typical Godzilla movie.
Great story line, outstanding acting.
Hope its nominated for the Japanese production
The best Godzilla film I've seen! The story, the action, and the horror! It all blends in so well!
Better than the last three Godzilla movies. Please make more Godzilla movies like this

"Godzilla Minus One" is one of the year's finest blockbuster films and quite possibly the best "Godzilla" film I have ever seen. This is a movie that understands how to create an emotional attachment to characters and thus raises the stakes when the action is going down. Speaking of the action, it is some of the most spectacular stuff you can see in a theater in 2023. This movie is pure entertainment and has plenty of heart and a good story. To me, it feels like it captures the soul of the original film and flourishes it with modern-day special effects, and it reminded me a lot of the 2005 "King Kong" film in that way. Overall, this is a thrill ride that has plenty of moments to wow the audience, while also remembering to tell a genuinely engaging human story.
Best Godzilla movie EVER!!!
Godzilla is back in true form wonderful movie

This is the best Godzilla movie I've ever seen and it's because of the attention to detail in building the characters through important emotional moments. Their journeys are everything. The film is also a great vision of postwar Japan that movie audiences rarely get to see. American audiences might have objected to seeing the devastation that the Japanese people had endured as a result of American attacks on their homeland, but in this new century we're in now, everyone loves Japan and we're ready to see their story. Godzilla itself is a kind of avatar of nature enacting vengeance for violence against the natural world in this genre, but but this film also uses the monster to help the audience to empathize with Japanese victims of war. All the moments are well-earned, the monster is truly furious and terrifying, effects and cinematography are great, and there's also an adorable baby. I highly recommend this movie.

Minus One is the biggest experience I had with a Godzilla movie. Everything is outstanding beautiful and also very tragic. It's about the human will to face the worst possible situation happening at the worst time possible. The characters are awesome with deepness reflecting the horrors that the Japanese people lived through post WW2 Embodiment by the creature that is tearing everything apart and criticizing both the Japanese and US government decisions smartly. even if you are not a Godzilla fan this is a MUST WATCH.

Hands down the best Godzilla movie ever. It clicks on all cylinders - story, acting, direction and SFX. The Japanese monster movies have always had a subtext of the national trauma of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. By setting this story at the end of the war and making the central character a traumatized Japanese soldier the film moves the subtext to the front brilliantly. And for the first time I can remember, the monster itself is terrifying. Kudos to Toho Studios for making a film light years ahead of anything else they have ever done.
Possibly the best Godzilla movie ever. Saw it with my fiance, we both cried. 15/10.

This movie is brilliantly done. Absolutely no fault can be found with it. This is not just a monster movie. The script is a truly deep and well written story. I certainly hope that they don’t cave and dub because the subtitles is part of the perfection. A not to the origin of this monsters history.

For watching godzilla movies all my life, this one has the most impact and story driven I have seen, you can feel the fear from the people with godzilla. The redemption and chemistry with the characters. The action was not lacking and bringing back the musical score to top it all off brings it in.
Very emotional thrilling rollercoaster

This was not only a great Godzilla movie, this was a great movie period. Even non Godzilla fans could find enjoyment from this movie. This is one of the best installments in the franchise since its birth. To the core, the movie is a human story and one that adds so much emotion that is usually missing from most Godzilla movies. What a phenomenal film!!

Godzilla Minus One had a profound and lasting effect on me. The film was undeniably remarkable, as it skillfully demonstrated Toho's mastery in crafting a truly terrifying Godzilla. However, what truly set it apart was its ability to evoke deep emotions through its use of disturbing imagery and heartfelt moments. This combination of expertly crafted horror and genuine emotional connection made the film a truly unforgettable experience.
It's a truly great movie, much less the best Godzilla movie ever. Believe the hype on the one!
Best Godzilla movie of all time!!!!!!!!
the best Godzilla movie Japan ever put together!
Good movie, really loud action. If watching make sure you are prepared to read the subtitles, the entire movie is subtitled/translated but overall a good movie.

Godzilla Minus One does an excellent job at balancing its character focus with the Godzilla action and carnage.

Definitely one of the best movies to come out this year! Simple storyline that made sense, great characters, and really well made even though it had a very small budget. It's in Japanese and has English subtitles, which I was not aware of, but wasn't an issue for me. It might be difficult to enjoy if you're not a fast reader.
Best Godzilla movie by far👍🏼. Godzilla was terrifying in every scene he was in. Great pacing and character development. Definitely buying this movie when it comes out on blue ray.
Great throwback to the 1954 original

Heart and spectacle done right. Great story and effects. Works as a monster movie, works as a WWII period piece. Fantastic movie experience.

This movie was spectacular.  I have never seen a Godzilla movie where I really cared about the people so much.  Usually the story was only Godzilla, but this was different.  The main characters shame, sadness, rejection and pain all turns around and he has a redemption in the end! The Godzilla scenes in the water were just amazing.  In some places Godzilla did look like a man in a suit, but in most places it looked so good that you were awestruck!  I loved this movie!

Probably the best godzilla movie I've ever seen and surprisingly, it's for the exact reason tht usully bogs down most godzilla movies (especially the American ones). This movie genuinely has the best human story of any godzilla movie I've ever seen we also checked it out in cinemar's new D-box seats and while fun (in a movie like this) it is not worth an extra $10+per ticket.

Brought all the aspects of the original Godzilla movies and more. Made him terrifying once again, packed with big explosions along with a great plot. I'm satisfied see if/how this storyline continues.

One of the best Godzilla movies out there even the the American version ones and Im a big Godzilla movie fan.  I highly suggest this film for not only die heart fans but also novice.  This is a great intro movie for the general audience.

Best Godzilla movie since 1954. I actually cared about the human story! All characters had a compelling story and arc. Godzilla was angry and scary. Post war Japan focus on the trauma of war made this movie an original. Japanese Godzilla movies are the best!!!

More than once I shed a tear, and more than once I found myself scared for the residents of Ginza and Tokyo. 

Additionally, Godzilla himself was epic. There were so many things done well. The detail was incredible. From his epic power up sequences to the close ups on his face and body, never before has he looked so incredible.

Its got a great classic monster vibe. Great story, excellent acting, and amazing effects! If youre a true Godzilla fan you HAVE to it!

A true return to form with Godzilla as a terrifying force of nature and genuinely likable human protagonists. Godzilla Minus one accomplishes what few kaiju films have, making the audience care and root for the human cast while enjoying the spectacle of mass destruction.

Godzilla Minus One is fantastic. The action is spectacular, the acting is great and I really loved the story. It was nice to watch a movie that cared about the characters and the complications they faced from this truly terrifying unstoppable monster attacking just after such a demoralizing war. Its movies like this that remind us how awesome the theater experience can be. This is an old fashioned popcorn movie at its finest.

I've seen 4 movies this year: John Wick 4, Sound of Freedom, Oppenheimer, and Godzilla Minus One. This one was the best out all 4. Its crazy this only had a production budget of 15 million USD. You could take anyone to see this movie and they would enjoy it. The acting is superb, no woke agenda, just pure, fun, entertainment. Something I don't see very often. The strength of the human spirit to not give up in what are seemingly insurmountable odds shines through in this movie. You will leave feeling satisfied, and motivated to take on your own Godzilla. 

5/5, go see it!

It's been a long time since I enjoyed a movie so much! This movie wasn't JUST a monster movie--it was a personal glimpse into the lives of the Japanese people following the 2d World War, and follows a man with PTSD, through his guilt to his eventual redemption.  It has everything a great movie has--action, suspense, romance, and a unique story. Hollywood used to make good movies, but they have wrecked every franchise I used to love. If they have a brain cell left, they need to learn from this movie. If they don't, Hollywood is done, and nobody is going to miss them.

Best Godzilla movie remastered for the modern audience. Takes a heartfelt look into post-war Japan and the struggles of Japanese citizens to find a semblance of normalcy. When our characters found a sense of happiness Godzilla shows back up into the picture to destroy the lives of thousands of people. We get to watch the struggle of never leaving the war zone and needing to put your life on the line to wanting to live for your family. Our characters have heartfelt moments with a glimpse into our humanity. Out of more than 35 movies to Godzillas name this is by far one of the best stories out to screen.

At $15 Million this tops any $200m blockbuster this year. With a less is more approach to storytelling with a human focus this is probably the best Godzilla film in the 70 year franchise. This is a film fans and a general movie goer could appreciate. It’s not a non-stop Marvel CGI action fest, but when the action does start it is exciting. Amazing visuals and tense action make this a must to see in the largest format theater you can, with 4DX and IMAX making this an incredible experience that only a cinema can deliver.

Excellent movie! Hollywood should take notes on how to create a monster movie from this. The human element and characters made you feel what they were feeling. You actually care for them and what happens to them. Characters are flawed and not the unlikeable, perfect, invincible, strong characters that Hollywood seems to be pumping out lately. There is actual tension when Godzilla shows up due to these stakes. Unlike Hollywood Godzilla movies, the focus is not just on the monster alone and special effects galore. There is an actual good story here. There are people that you care about in the film that you get attached to. The characters are actually likeable and relatable throughout.

Godzilla Minus One is absolutely fantastic. 
They give you characters that you actually care about, deal with themes of loss, grief, and guilt (particularly survivor guilt) in a powerful way, and the effects are absolutely first rate. The fact that anyone could make a film this good for only $15 million is unbelievable. 
The movie is a period piece taking place right after the end of World War 2, and transforms the theme of the original Gojira (1954) from a story about the horrors of atomic weapons into a story about the horrors of war in general.
Definitely see this movie on the big screen if you can. It's well worth it.

A great movie (I don't mean that as great-for-a-godzilla-film). movie was absolutely amazing. puts anything hollyweird has made recently to shame.

70 years have been building to this. Minus One stands as not only the best Godzilla film, but likely the best in the genre. All elements in this film come together in perfect harmony, from the animation (so good at times you'd swear Godzilla was real) to the music to the outstanding cast. The writing is what really makes this movie. Godzilla action is always fun, that's why this franchise has survived for 70 years, but all previous films have suffered from characters who are boring. (and in some cases, downright hateful) Minus One doesn't have that problem. The characters are very well written, and the story with them is fantastic. They grow and face their challenges that mirror the larger conflict of Godzillas rampage. The story tackles grief, PTSD, survivors guilt, and forgiveness in a moving tale that can bring audiences to tears.
Do not miss what I can honestly say is the best movie of the year. See Godzilla on the biggest screen you can and enjoy the ride
The storytelling and the pacing of the movie kept everyone focused.  And the correct Godzilla to  human interest screen time ratio. But most importantly, Godzilla is the villain once again.

Godzilla is great but you find yourself really caring for the lead charachters and the family and relationships. You become invested with these charachters which clearly defines Godzilla as the villian in this and you want to see his demise for their safety.

One of the best films in 2023 hands down, I really like the approach that was taken with this film and the message it delivers about national pride, the horrors of war and the effects on its people. If you are even contemplating seeing this film do yourself a favor and go see it.
loved it, maybe the best of all the Godzilla movies

Absolutely the best Godzilla movie of all time! At first it does the hardest thing to pull off in a Godzilla movie and you actually care about the human characters. The throwbacks to the 50s original with soundtrack and plot points are blended in seamlessly. I saw it in an MXC theater and it is the loudest film I have ever heard sounded as if Godzilla actually roared in my face. It also has horror movie aspects mixed with heartbreaking moments. 
An instant classic!

70 years later and Toho still knows how to make a phenomenal Godzilla film. I imagine the way the 1954 version of Godzilla left a lasting, on the edge of your seat impression to audiences for the first time, this film will provoke the same reaction.

Generally, you can separate the Godzilla movies into several categories… the eras in which they were produced, the American/Japanese films, etc.  I tend to divide them up into categories in which Godzilla is the "hero" (often the films where he battles other kaiju) and the ones in which Godzilla is a threatening presence. In the latter category, the original 1954 film will always be at the top.  Shin Godzilla (2016) was an interesting entry, and brought a sense of horror with the political commentary, but my two favorites after the original are still Godzilla Returns (1984) and Godzilla Minus One (2023).  Minus One's human interest story was full of heart, and truly moving, with themes of shame, guilt, forgiveness, redemption, and ultimately, life. And this incarnation of Godzilla was terrifying.  Definitely in my top five Godzilla films.

The movie is by no means perfect, but this comes pretty close.   Disney should be embarrassed with their 200-300 million plus flop films that was released recently.   This is movie is an overall great movie in general!  Even if you are not a Godzilla or Kaiju fan,  this will appeal to the wider general audiences.

It had a perfectly paced build with a satisfying climax and conclusion. Another positive is that even though it is a foreign film and it had subtitles, it caused me to have to pay even closer attention to it which made me appreciate the film that much more. At no point was I bored or wanting it to end but on the contrary it kept me invested and wanting more.  With only a budget of $15 million, this film used it effectively. Did it have its flaws? Yes at moments however they made it work and put out an amazing film. I am going to rate this film a 9.5 out of 10.

Godzilla Minus One is arguably one of the best Godzilla films. Not only does it bring Godzilla back to its roots regarding the post-World War nuclear metaphor, it also creates a stirring narrative about national (and individual) trauma. This, paired with incredibly stirring characters, a cohesive plot, and riveting musical score, Godzilla Minus One is the Godzilla film many have been waiting for.

I had been waiting to this for one full year and was not disappointed. This Godzilla film fully explored the human angle and employed very skilled actors to take the audience in. There are moments that will shock you and will make you cry. The sheer devastating affect upon the people is overwhelming. The director is more than just a director wearing the hats of director, special effects creator, and writer. This guy knew exactly how to make this film, and this film most certainly rival the lassie of all classics, the original Gidzilla, King of the Monsters. This is not a "monster" movie. It is a movie where people have been brought down to their knees, and then pushed into the ground... and how they respond to those circumstances. Dramatic, terrifying, exhilarating, and oddly realistic, you should see this film.

I feel that our criticism of graphics in movies has led "hollywood" to think that is all we want for entertainment.  This movie is so much more than graphics.  It has a storyline we can invest in, characters we care about, lots of action for entertainment, a very good music score and the best iteration of Godzilla to date.  For me it checked off all the boxes.  One of it not the best movie I have seen in years.

A beautifully shot tragedy, grounded in historical fiction. At times it feels like you're watching Dunkirk or Oppenheimer. Often Godzilla movies leave you feeling impatient to get past the human-centric side of the story. That was not the case with Minus One. Its heartfelt characters elevated this film from spectacle to existential. It has been a long time since someone was able to fully and deftly capture the allegory for the horrors of war, that is Godzilla.

Ever since the short 30 second teaser came out in July, I've been hooked on this movie and couldn't wait for it to come out. Now after already seeing it twice, all I can say is that this movie is a masterpiece. Godzilla in this movie was genuinely terrifying and really brought back the vibes of the 1954 original. The human characters were perfectly written and Takashi Yamazaki really makes you care about them, and whenever Godzilla is on screen you fear for the humans because you don't know if and when Godzilla could kill them. Yamazaki's Godzilla Minus One is easily in contention for movie of the year and is an instant classic.

This is a powerful and deeply moving war drama that happens to have Godzilla in it. The characterization and storytelling are handled masterfully by director Takashi Yamazaki, and his complete vision comes across beautifully. The concept feels wholly unique within the existing Godzilla franchise, as well as within the modern cinematic landscape. This movie showcases some of the franchise's most endearing characters, incredible visual effects, and potent commentary on the human condition. All of this on a budget of $15,000,000. Unbelievable!

I could see the obvious progress of quality from "Shin-Godzilla" and other Legendary's Godzilla series. It's no doubt thanks to all new creators' mindset to try to outperform the previous works, based on and standing at the established brand "Godzilla". All the successors can benchmark the prior ones and analyze their successful points and failures. Yamazaki learned a lot from Anno's work and made some improvements and corrections particularly on the point that it couldn't catch on overseas. One of them is the music. He succeeded in taking on Naoki Sato, who is the graduate of Tokyo university of the music, paying respect to the alumni and predecessor Ifukube and understanding his music deeply. In this film, vision and music are fantastically synchronized. And of course, the main character is Godzilla, but Yamazaki has done well in letting him act simply as a fearful object. Therefore, we can empathize fully with characters competing with Godzilla. Yamazaki who has suffered a streak of bummers in making films looks to be recovering his confidence, and is expected to deliver another sequel of Godzilla film, in which we can see a "real" duel with monsters like Ghidra or Mothra.

A breath of fresh air amidst all the cookie cutter comic hero, politically motivated, and regurgitated remakes of stories once loved. There is the obvious elephant in the room  in concerns to how the war came to an end but was done in a way to not cheaply push ideals onto new and younger Godzilla fans by simply displaying the disconnect of the value of life from world leaders to the everyday lower class person struggling to get by. Having spent some time in Japan personally and was able to admire how the Japanese people hold values such as honor and respect above all, it was great seeing how someone may have survivor's guilt when failing to carry out a Kamikaze attack and how the people's perspective could change and evolve to value their lives and neighbor's lives above the honor of duty. This perspective ultimately changing in the end with them willing to sacrifice themself when forced to come together to face a devastating threat such as Godzilla. The movie was perfectly shot and edited to pay homage to the original films and just knocked it out of the park in every aspect from the model  and even the movement of the monster as he destroyed the city. *Chef's kiss* The effects and animation was fantastic blurring the lines between practical and computer generated imagery. I saw the film in the new and expensive theaters in 4DX where the seats violently jerked and rocked while air and water misted over us with flashing lights on the flanks to simulate explosions and gunfire so let's just say I got ultimate Godzilla experience. If you're looking to take the kids to see a movie of which you can actually enjoy with them, look no further. This movie is must see in my book and if I'm being honest would trade more of Hollywood for what Japan has to offer. Go see it!

Feels like Sunday afternoon Godzilla when I was a kid in the 80s! The characters are unforgettable and when Godzilla appears he's shockingly destructive. The best Godzilla film in years.  Go see it with the biggest group of people you can!  A MUST SEE!

Godzilla Minus One blew all my expectations away — what an incredible film! It. Freaking. Rules! It isn't just an amazing Godzilla film, but one of the best films of the year! This truly puts Hollywood's versions of Godzilla to shame. I'm by no means a Godzilla expert, but this was easily the best Godzilla movie I've ever seen! I haven't seen an audience this excited and visibly satisfied by a movie in quite some time! This film showcases how to make the perfect Godzilla picture with a compelling human ensemble and breathtaking action that's savoured from start to finish.  Plus, it truly takes Godzilla back to being a truly horrifying monster! (And has the coolest use of the Atomic Breath I've ever seen!)

The action is incredible and brutal, and the VFX work is insanely good. I also really loved the cinematography and the killer sound design. Plus, the score is excellent and uses Akira Ifukube's iconic Godzilla theme to great effect.

But the reason this film stands out is because of its combination of great storytelling mixed with great technical achievements. There's reason to care about the characters and a deeply emotional side to this film that makes the monster even more haunting. This is a monster film where the human conflict is just as compelling, if not more so, than the tremendous action sequences. I loved the exploration of the traumas of war and cultural destruction in Japan following WWII, and the ways the characters connected to these themes made for such a strong emotional core. This film has the perfect blend of massive monster mayhem and compelling human drama that really worked. It's so good that you could remove Godzilla from the film and still have a great film. This is a moving, thoughtful Japanese character drama set in post-war Japan that also happens to have a giant horrific monster in it. People are gonna talk about Godzilla Minus One's amazing production and filmmaking, but what surprised me the most was the script. Every character has an arc and serves a purpose, and there are no wasted beats. There are so many great dilemmas and dramatic questions. Also a perfect example of using the monster as a greater metaphor. The result is a thrilling epic that feels grounded and meaningful, and so, so good. 

Godzilla Minus One is a nigh-masterpiece. Not only is Godzilla terrifying again, but the film itself is a powerful drama with some daunting imagery, plenty of emotional moments, sound design to rock the theatre, and a moving character study on post-war guilt and PTSD. It's a genuinely exciting, riveting, emotional disaster flick, delivering drama you care about and thunderous action spectacle. See Minus One on the loudest, biggest screen you can possibly find and enjoy the ride — it's incredible!

(I gotta add… it's like Act One is Jurassic Park, Act Two is Jaws, and Act Three is Dunkirk. Just such an awesome movie!)

As a longtime fan of Godzilla movies, from the earlier films to the modern era, I have been part of a fanbase that has endured both gems and dumpster fires, but I can honestly say this is the best of the modern series started from the 2010s . The IP has the Hollywood-produced Godzilla film of 2014 to thank for the renewed interest that convinced both Japanese and American studios to release a series of new movies, with now three of them playing with the reboot concept. As far as Japanese produced live action theatrical movies, this is the second one after Shin Godzilla in 2016. 

While Shin Godzilla was an interesting and engaging film set in present-day Japan, using the 2011 Tsunami and nuclear disaster as the backdrop, one could definitely feel the Evangelion-inspired direction from Hideki Anno. It even included the same music from the Evangelion composer, Shiro Sagisu. It had an almost exhausting plot that is dialog-heavy that meshes the human suffering, trials and failures along with the politics of managing a situation if such an event were to happen in reality. Although flawed, it is a decent Godzilla film with plenty of over-the-top monster action coupled with a solution that might be possible to pull off in the real world.

Godzilla Minus Zero uses WWII and the start of Postwar Japan as the setting, just as the Japanese faced defeat at the hands of the US, we follow the story of a Kamikaze pilot who must deal with his situation when he chooses to neglect his duty, not willing to die for something he sees as pointless. As he chose not to die, he feels that "his war is not over," and this message is what drives his story. 

His path crosses the famous monster at a relatively early stage of its development, and is described as a dinosaur-like monster, which was interesting to see. The events that follow our small group of characters is a series of highly relatable human struggles as the Japanese citizens try to recover from the war but are faced with another threat in Godzilla. The familiar origin story from previous films of island-based nuclear testing causing mutations in Godzilla is the main cause for its massive size and abilities, including the heat/atomic breath and regenerative properties.

The movie is smart enough to give a very plausible method of defeating the monster, even though we as an audience know it will work in the end, the way it is presented seems possible with the WWII technology of the time. There is some doubt on if it will actually work against the monste, even up until the end of the film. We even get cameos of some famous Japanese warships, so fans of naval history, Kancolle or Azur Lane might get a kick out of that, like I did.

The CGI effects were mostly believable since we're past the point of a man in a rubber suit the play the part of Godzilla. The design and some of the effects of this version of Godzilla reminded me of the 2014 movie, along with some Shin Godzilla elements. This is probably the best Godzilla has looked in any of the modern movies. Godzilla takes up just enough screen time so that you're not bored out of your mind seeing the monster destroy countless buildings, which doesn't actually happen as much as you'd think. Also, we get to see the creature clearly enough, so it's not completely shrouded in mystery.  Regarding Godzilla's attacks, the famous atomic breath is seen as highly devastating, equal to that of an atomic bomb explosion, that is actually used sparingly, and the effects that are presented when Godzilla uses it were impressive. 

Overall, as someone who has seen most of the modern live-action Godzilla movies, this one was the most enjoyable with a believable plot and highly relatable characters. It takes the human element of people struggling to survive in a postwar environment coupled with the unknown threat of a seemingly invincible monster. It is brilliantly directed with actors that truly convey the weight of their situation that never crosses the line of something superhuman to overcome the threat in Godzilla. Using subtle visual effects, excellent cinematography, a smart script along with some of the classic soundtrack of the old Godzilla movies, it does feel like this movie could have been made in the same period as those old movies. There's no attempt to go overboard and give the audience sensory overload to convince them what they are watching is a good film, like with modern superhero movies.

As a Godzilla movie, it is probably the best and out of all the movies this year in 2023, this is one of the best, if not THE best.

Godzilla Minus One is a masterpiece, not just an incredible Godzilla movie but an incredible science fiction film. The plot is dramatic, you connect to the characters, and the action, the action is something else. The destruction caused by Godzilla is done in such a way that feels realistic but doesn't scale back on Godzilla's power. Godzilla comes across as force of nature. Overall, no complaints if I'm not nitpicking.

Arguably, if not, the best Godzilla movie hands down. This will take you on such an emotional journey, and the give you a sinister feeling of when, and what Godzilla will do next to the people of Japan in its most vulnerable state after WW2 is over. Go support this movie! Toho knocked it out the park with this one.

An amazing film from start to finish. Keeps you engaged with all the main cast and Godzilla is terrifying. Highly recommend to those not familiar with Godzilla as a fresh beginning. Will be watching again!

This is an absolutely incredible movie! I love every aspect of what was done with this. Godzilla's new look and horrifying temperament made for one terrifying big screen experience. The music was very well done  But there were also plenty of moments that had very heavy atmosphere where there was no background music or ambient sound to distract you from what was on screen. In the aftermath of all of godzilla's destruction the lingering silence was very eerie. The way they did his voice and overall temperament, In this case aggression towards mankind was incredible. The way Godzilla developed throughout the movie as a result of atomic radiation was amazing to see.  Some of the aerial scenes from an airplane perspective had me just about jumping out of my seat as godzilla was snapping his jaws at the pilot. I watched this twice in the d box at megaplex and both times felt like this was almost like a ride and a movie because the seats would move in conjunction with the waves affecting the boats on screen. Because this is a foreign film I do not know any of the actors but the entire cabsolutely nailed it and did a fantastic job. In some godzilla movies the human element leaves much to be desired that is certainly not the case in this masterpiece of a movie. This is probably the best godzilla movie I've ever seen and I have seen them all.  If you're looking for a fun thrilling movie I highly recommend you go see this while it's in the movie theater to enjoy it and all of its majesty on the big screen!!!

The only aspect of this movie that may be considered a negative by some is that it is a pure Japanese language film, with only English subtitles; given the subject matter here, however, I felt that this was a brilliant choice that really added to the experience of the film. This is an amazing post-war story, one of tragedy, love, and loss. The main characters are believable and you feel their anguish and pain. It's a very smart, clever film that will grab you and not let you go. The audio and soundtrack is perfect. The sets and special effects are nothing short of astonishing - the best we've seen. This is a tremendous movie, and the best part is that it's a Godzilla film for the ages. Not only is it the Best Godzilla film we are likely to ever see, but it's also one of the best monster films ever made.

"Godzilla Minus One" is one of the best Godzilla movies ever made! I should know. I've been watching Godzilla movies since I was five years old. It's essentially a reimagined version of the first Godzilla film released in 1954. 

This is a Japanese movie with English subtitles that kicks things off at the end of World War II in war-torn Tokyo. The plot is definitely man vs. monster. This is not a multi-monster extravaganza and Godzilla is not a good guy this time around. Facing impossible odds, our protagonists (Japanese Navy veterans and civilians) employ science and ingenuity to take on a seemingly invincible, radioactive creature from the deep. 

I'll admit, the film drags at times between battles and attacks, but a good plot means you can't have non-stop action or the audience would be exhausted. What will really blow your mind is that this film was made on a shoestring budget of only $15 million. I guess when you have a good story, you don't need $200 million in CGI and special effects. Directors and Producers all over Hollywood need to take a good look in the mirror and question how much money it actually takes to deliver a movie with a good story.

"Godzilla Minus One" should definitely be in the running for best foreign film at the Oscars. I loved it and I think you will too. I give this film 3 1/2 stars out of 5.
The story was amazing and so were the portrayers. Good screen time for the big G. Loved it

Absolutely Awesome!  Edge of your seat movie, deep story line, every emotional

I could see some who just wanted mindless action might not like the pacing. I thought Minus One did what it's predecessors have all failed to do, it offered up a compelling story for it's human characters, I was invested in their stories, I cared if they lived or died. Godzilla looked great and by far the best atomic breath of any Godzilla movie. Don't let the subtitles scare you off, you want the theater experience for this one!

Hands down, movie of the year. This movie had everything. I was expecting a cheezy monster movie, but it was a spectacular vision of the plight of two young people devoted to each other in the midst of a disaster movie.

A masterpiece of emotional storytelling!

Wonderful characters, action, and music! This is what cinema should be! ✨

Masterclass of a film. A brilliant reimagining of a beloved classic, and one of the rare instances of a Godzilla film having great human protagonists. The stakes were high, the visuals were outstanding, Godzilla was menacing, and the acting was top notch. An absolute love letter to the franchise and its fans. To think this film was created on a budget of $15 million. Not a dime wasted.

This film is an emotionally impactful human drama set against the backdrop of a devastated post-WW2 Japan and the emergence of an existential threat in the form of Godzilla. 

Godzilla Minus One is focused on a young soldier wracked with guilt over his actions during the war. His struggle to accept LIFE and allow himself to love again is very moving.  Godzilla is the threat to those he cares about but also the opportunity to resolve his crisis, assuage his feelings of guilt and redeem himself.

The special effects are impressive despite an almost unbelievably small budget. There is a reality to the devastation that was never achieved post the original film. Add to it that one CARES about the characters.

The score is very affecting and unusual for a Godzilla film. There were wonderful callbacks to Ifukube's score to the original (earlier) films too.

Artfully directed, well written, earnestedly acted by a convincing ensemble cast...this is, surprisingly, one of the best movies of the year.

The film that leaves you wanting more. The build up of the human story is the driving force behind the movie, and Godzilla is a force to be reckoned with. You almost don’t want it to show up but when it does, it’s horrifying and intense. Great film, the best this year.

The film never loses pace, whether or not Godzilla is on screen, and the film is shot so as to keep the viewer constantly mesmerized by what is happening on-screen. You can tell that the cast and crew set out to craft a very powerful film that has much to say on the themes of life, perseverance and the quest for identity in a changing world. This is truly a film that is sure to be enjoyed by both casual moviegoers and fans of the franchise.

Absolutely incredible. I plan on seeing it again in theaters.

Amazing experience in IMAX!  The way the movie is shot is beautiful and immersive.  Loved the human story and really shows a part of post WW2 Japan and the scars of war.  Loved that G man was basically a personification of the nuclear devastation.

Together with Shin Godzilla, TOHO brings back the original premise of 1954 Godzilla to a global audience: A human centric story where the citizens work together to have a fighting chance against Godzilla, a walking unstoppable monster that brings the nation to brick of annihilation, even if the government fails them. 

What's shocking is the amount of risk Toho taking with the setting: A post World War 2 Japan, with the protagonist being a Kami Kaze pilot (If you aren't familiar, these are the suicide jets that flies straight to high value targets without any means of escape)

I am pleased to say the movie does not glorify the WW2 Japan, it's a movie about survival, wanting to live, wanting to move beyond the haunting past that has drown the nation.

The movie says a lot about how Japanese felt during post-war Japan: the anger, nihilism, sorrow, makes it difficult for some to even accept the joy of life. Some eventually did, some are still living in the past.

Godzilla, being the "villain" of the movie, brings in yet another complete destruction that valuable rebuilt progress. Sounds familiar? The constant Earthquakes in Japan, the "lost decades of Japan" after the economic crisis. For a nation that tries so hard, it seems the odds are always stacked against them. The glimmer of hope just never stays.

The plot spends a lot of time and effort building up its characters, which are exceptionally well crafted and the relationship between them are organic and easy to like.
This gives every scene that we used to cheer for, Godzilla appearing/using heat ray, an entirely different atmosphere. 

We see the level of destruction closely on the ground, and the amount of damage being done to the precious rebuild effort is heartbreaking for the audience. And of course, how the loss of lives and rebuild effort destroyed extinguished the hope and optimism along as well.

It also does something rarely seen in western cinema nowadays, where plots are mostly in the extremes: "Look at how mighty our nation is" vs "Look at how terrible and shameful our past is" (the former is vanishing even)
While not saying these movies don't have their importance, but very rarely do we get any movies that brings the nation together through collective pain and bring in positivity despite all odds.

While some would call this an Anti-war movie, this is more about existentialism which is a common theme in Japanese works, and ironically this philosophy originated from France/Germany post world war 1 and frankly has vanished from most western literary/cinema. 

Overall, for the average audience, this is a great movie with great sound track/sound effect, decent visual. For Godzilla fans, this brings back the horror and OG Godzilla feel. 
For movie lovers, this is a great work about humanity and Japan's spirit, a reminisce of the peak Japanese movie decades from the 70s.

Japan is on its path of economic recovery, with great results in sports/arts etc in the past few years.
This movie and Shin Godzilla are love letters to the Japanese people, for their resilient and willing to take responsibility for a better future despite all the flaws from the system or the past.
For a movie that's at a disadvantage and this is the BEST movie of 2023 by far!

I'm a 48 year old, life long Godzilla fan.  I believe that Minus One is the best modern Godzilla film since 2001's  GMK.  Besides a few non distracting nods to the 1954 film, Minus One is very different from the rest.   It has a very strong and compelling human story.  It probably has the best writing of any Godzilla film in that regards.  It may be set in a post war Japan, but it is far from being a remake of the 1954 film.

Fantastic movie for $15 million.  The effects were good if not perfect, but you hardly care because the movie is engaging. Lots of emotion, and as a family man, there were some genuinely touching moments. The set up was good, character growth all around, and the finale was well-earned as a result. You should see this movie if you don't mind subtitles. Oscar- worthy.
It was absolutely amazing. It had great action scenes, and an actual engaging human element. I would recommend this to everyone. It was tense, fun and also, at times, very touching.

The movie was absolutely great. No movie has ever brought me to tears like this one. I loved every single moment. If you have a chance watch this movie not just once , but twice! This movie is unforgettable and a masterpiece!

This is hands down the BEST movie I've seen this year. It's Oscar-worthy, and that's not hyperbole. The script is perfect. The themes explored are deep and heartfelt - the post-war trauma of an entire nation, survivor guilt, shame, PTSD, what makes a family, love, redemption, forgiving others, forgiving oneself, the value of life, and choosing to live in the face of terrible odds. You'd never think a movie about a giant monster stomping on stuff would make you feel for and root for the human characters, but Godzilla Minus One does just that.  I can't say this enough - go watch it. If you were ever a Godzilla fan, go watch it. Even if you were never a Godzilla fan, go watch it. This movie is easily one of the best movies of 2023.  And all for a very modest 15 million-dollar budget, compared to the hundreds of millions Hollywood pours into its (often disappointing) blockbusters.

This was the best Kaiju Film ever! Period, end of story. The blending of history and the start of Godzilla's evolution/Mythology was amazing. The acting wasn't overwhelming and it served as a guide through the destruction of Godzilla physically and mentally.

But those looking for the definition of CINEMA, will be rewarded with thrilling action sequences, special effects that beat out every Marvel and DC comic universe entry to date, an epic film score, stunning cinematography, and most surprising of all, a heartfelt poetic story supported by a stellar and earnest emotional cast performance.

For me, it's one of the best, if not THE best films of the year. Movies in Hollywood recently have shifted a-bit away from what a good movie is about. For a small budget of 15m$ this movie was a masterpiece. Godzilla was great, human characters were great, story was great, CG was great. So if you ask me about my complaints, I do have two small ones (that aren't really complaints actually): I would appreciate a little more Godzilla sequences, and the CG did look a bit rough on the edges in some really rare occasions. That said, I enjoyed the whole thing and even if the G-man wasn't on screen all the time, I was still invested in the human characters, which is rare in a Godzilla movie these days. Two hours went by without me noticing, because I didn't get bored. Granted, not all people will connect 100% with the movie, it depends on wether you are a Godzilla fan or not for example, or if you have some knowledge of how Japan suffered from WWII ect. But I do think that every viewer will enjoy at least some parts of the movie if not all of it. I really recommend seeing it, even if it's subtitled, you won't even feel it like an issue anymore after the first 5 minutes of the movie, because you will be invested. Great story, great performance, emotional at times, and GODZILLA.WAS.AWESOME.

OK, normally a Godzilla movie, especially made by Toho, is always pretty cheesy, with the guy in a suit stomping Tokyo.   Yeah, it is Godzilla, but there's most likely never going to be an Oscar for the actors.  

I just got back from the newest Godzilla movie... "Godzilla Minus One".   It is excellent, and this is one that should be seen in the theaters.  

Now, how do you tell an epic story, and make it a great movie too?  You do it not by telling about the main event, but about the people who are in the main event.  A good example of this is "Saving Private Ryan".   If it was just a regular war movie, showing nothing but D-Day, it would have been OK, but just mediocre.   However, it was a great movie because it focused not on D-Day, but on one character... Private Ryan... and how to get him home.  

So, narrow the story down to one person, or just a few.  

"Godzilla Minus One" has done this.  It is the story of a Japanese Kamikaze pilot, who chickened out, and due to this he has massive guilt.  Something else happened (no spoilers) where he chickened out again, so now he has to go home to a devastated Tokyo, that was destroyed by the fire bombing campaign at the end of WWII.

The story focuses on him, and his new family, and about him trying to get over the PTSD of WWII.  


This is why the new Godzilla movie is excellent, because it has a great story.  It is not just about the giant lizard who shoots nuclear beams.

Godzilla is terrifying. I love that they keep finding ways to keep the story fresh. In this one we see the beginnings of Godzilla from the point of view of the ordinary people. I wish we would have gotten a bit more Godzilla action but what we got was new and awesome. More please.

Fantastic.  I cried THREE TIMES.  

Imagine feeling like an ostracized outcast for not sacrificing your life on two consecutive occasions.  You would feel completely alone and worthless.  How do you even come back from that?  Do you sacrifice your life the way everyone seems to demand?  What happens to your kid if you do?  Do you sacrifice yourself for her?   What happens to her then?  

I won't spoil any more for you, but that's the kind of stuff the main character deals with.  It's an all too common story for so many these days, and it really hit home for me.  

That's the kind of deep drama that has been missing from theaters for far too long.  American cinema is dead.  The Japanese just proved it.

Most sci-fi is far fetched. This movie could even be called a period piece. It was of the times reminiscent of post-war Japan. The costumes, the setting, the people and their struggles were rooted in realism and those times. Well acted, great special effects, a sense of reality. A monster movie that works. Godzilla Minus One is a masterpiece that the American Monsterverse should take note of.  This movie is like the 1954 original movie. Very dark and makes Godzilla scary as hell. The CGI has a few issues, but that is from what I hear. This movie only cost 15 million to make, and if that is the case, it's one of the greatest movies ever made. The Story is very similar to the 1954 just set right after World War II, which was a great idea. 
Kamiki Ryunosuke, who is Koichi, gives an Oscar performance as a veteran who is living with PTSD. Along with Minami Hamabe, who is Noriko gives you Characters that feel real, not like the American versions. 
The people really sell this movie. They are so good, every one of them. As a Veteran, at some point, I even cried. The way everyone portrayed the aftermath was so gripping. This is not a typical Godzilla movie. This is truly and one of a kind movie that must be seen. Oscar containers all around on this movie.

As a Boomer I grew up with Godzilla and understood very well he was a metaphor for the Atomic Age.  Then over time he devolved into  almost a joke.  His rebirth in the 2014 Godzilla was amazing if you love the monster and a decent enough movie overall but I cant tell you that until today Ive seen an actually great piece of cinema in the entirety of the catalog - the 1954 original being maybe the closest.  Well I have now.

This is the Godzilla we have all been waiting for, where the monster is a monster, he is not a "good guy" and is not interested in being a friend of the people, as we have been led to believe in the most recent incarnations.  Good storytelling, fast-paced and a whole lot of fun to watch.

Return to classic Godzilla horror form, without a large portion of the cheese. The story about the humans around Godzilla was much higher quality than most other Kaiju films, but you absolutely miss the big man when he's off screen and still manage to hate his guts when he's on screen.  The second to last scene feels a bit like a cop out of some earlier decisions in the plot. I'd say it's mostly an improvement from Shin Godzilla across the board. They took what they learned from Shin and really honed it in, easily putting this in the conversation for best Godzilla film ever.
Absolutely fantastic.
One of the best Godzilla movies to date. Goes back to its original roots and gives us a fresh new take on Godzilla.
Great movie. I felt invested in the characters. Value driven story arch. A few nit pick criticisms but on a different level than standard studio drivel.

Just got home from the Cinema and i have to say, the movie is really great. It has a really good story and the King of Monsters has actually quite a lot of screen time and when he‘s there, oh boy. I highly recommend to go and watch it for yourselfs. I am actually mad at our local Cinema that they aren‘t showing it in imax and/or 4dx.
best godzilla movie ever

The best Godzilla film in my opinion. Toho knows how to deliver its golden boy to the world. Keep it simple. Godzilla attacks Japan and also at sea. He is unforgiving and destructive. The original roar! The human storyline was refreshing and performed perfectly. There were scenes that paid homage to the original film. I love this movie. It brought us back to why we all became Godzilla fans. Legendary started off this way but eventually lost its way as it is no longer the Monsterverse, it’s now the Kongsterverse. Thank you for this well made film, Toho!

I did not expect such a good film in this day and age of big budget disappointments. A human story in a monster movie? It is possible - makers of this movie have proven that. At moments, it felt like live action "Grave of the Fireflies", it's that gripping… Go see it while you can!!!
Hands down the most compelling human story in a Godzilla movie of all time. While, at the same time, we get one of the most ferocious and destructive Godzillas of all time. An absolute must-see

Wow, what a great movie. Very well written, a humanistic view of what would happen if Godzilla attacked. Loved how the director pulled this off. Pays homage to the franchise. Grate story, and grate animason and music and the famely drama made it hit oooh so harder go and enjoy gojira

Amazing Display of using your little Budget where it matters how is it possible that this movie looked better with its budget of 15 Million than Godzilla 2014 with its 160 Million, the movie is Atmospheric, looks great, great Human Characters, Epic Score and a Godzilla that is with Shin Godzilla probably the most Scary and Evil Version that Japan brought to the big screen. Give it a watch one of the best movies of the Year, and definitly one of the best if not the best modern Godzilla movie !

Just like with Shin Gojira, we finally have another director that *truly* understands the meaning behind Gojira.

The horror and trauma of war completely front and center of the plot and driving force behind the story. Gojira is back as he was originally intended; a true manifestation of what the civilians of Japan endured in WWII, from the actions of *both* the Japanese Government and United States. From the Japanese Government abandoning their civilians to starve, sacrifice and waste away, to the bombings from the United States. We can also see this by just witnessing the countless deaths we see on screen.

This is a true force of Gojira and the unstoppable threat of his mere existence. The American Godzilla as an idea is nothing compared to Gojira.

The only thing holding me back from a higher rating is a few instances of poorly-handled visual effects, and the terrible choice for a title name.

Godzilla: Minus One is an AWESOME movie if you can handle subtitles.

It has a great story with complex human characters.  I don't eant to give to much away, but the writing and storytelling is incredible.

I DEFINITELY recommend it, but it is a subtitle movie.  The dialog was clean enough that I had no issue keeping up with reading.

This is the best Godzilla movie I've ever watched, and I've pretty much watched them all. Even those who aren't Godzilla fans and simply watch it as a high concept disaster movie will be entertained.

As a long time Godzilla fan I would say this ties with the original for best Godzilla movie for me. Not just the best movie of the Toho franchise, but a fantastic movie in general. If there is not a best foreign film Oscar nomination, the system is broke.

This is truly one of the best movies I've ever seen. Godzilla is absolutely terrifying and the humans are equally as compelling I have no words for how amazed and happy i felt leaving this movie. I'm a life long Godzilla fan and seeing a Godzilla movie this good was so refreshing.

The best modern godzilla film

I struggle to think of anything that I dislike about this film. 

Despite my 5 stars, this isn't a perfect film, make no mistake.
I wish we saw more Godzilla. The water effects at times were a bit meh... Especially regarding the foam. 

But I left the cinema feeling happy and satisfied. This is a great film that I have to nitpick to find fault with it. The acting was incredible, the characters were likeable and fleshed out. I felt for the characters!!! Godzilla's actions were terrifying.
I felt like the characters were on the precipice of death - without feeling overwhelmed and smothered by hopelessness - in fact I felt the opposite - hope... a really powerful message - which perhaps towards the end gets a little obvious - But my oh my - This film earns it's ending!

5/5 - A must watch for Godzilla fans - a Must watch for Monster Movies fans.
Awesome movie. Especially liked that the story was more about the people than Godzilla. The special effects were great.

It is officially the golden age of Godzilla. Never before have we had such consistent, quality Godzilla content. It's been building since Godzilla 2014, and it just peaked.

Godzilla Minus One is perhaps the greatest Godzilla film since the original. There is an argument for it being considered the best, better than Godzilla '54. This Godzilla fires on all cylinders, not just as a creature, but the movie as a whole. Godzilla himself is perfect, but everything else in the movie is held to that same standard. There is no "weak part". The humans are just as important as Goji, and their stories are MORE compelling than the giant radioactive lizard. At one point, I genuinely forgot it was a Godzilla movie, and I had to remind myself Goji was going to return, and bring death and destruction with him.

This version of Godzilla is like nothing we've seen before. He is not an animal. He is not a force of nature. He is worse. Pick any god of death, destruction, and/or annihilation and he is that idea brought to life. He is malicious at every opportunity. He is the most menacing we've ever seen Godzilla. He is more powerful and destructive than any previous versions of Godzilla. Any scenes with Goji attacking are outstanding. Nothing is held back. And surprisingly, the effects are done so well they stand up to AAA Hollywood films. His "heat ray" is breathtaking. It's so beautiful and destructive. Seeing this in theaters is a must. The sound design and visuals do a fantastic job making you feel the sheer power being unleashed.

Everything about this film hit. I've never been so proud to be a Godzilla fan. The story, the plot, the acting, the characters, the themes, the action, the destruction, Godzillas design, the sound design, the soundtrack, everything for this film is done with care, with effort. Nothing falls short. You could take Godzilla out of this film, and everything else would still stand tall on its own. I genuinely think this will win awards and will usher in a new age of Japanese cinema. Hollywood should be taking notes on how to make lower budget movies. It's mind blowing that a Japanese film with a 15-20$ million budget was better than any 200$ million Hollywood film that came out this year.

I could praise this movie for days straight. I'm going to go see it again and bring everyone I can with me to the theaters. It's hard to rate a movie as perfect, but this movie is as perfect as any movie has been this year.

If you like Historical Dramas, go see this film.

If you like massive destruction sequences, go see this film.

If you like Godzilla, go see this film.

If you like good movies, GO SEE THIS FILM.

DON'T MISS MAYBE THE BEST MOVIE OF 2023.
One of the best Godzilla movies I've seen!  The characters were so well done and definitely the best atomic blast ever for Godzilla.

new favorite godzilla movie. so done with the modern 'oh, it's a monster, better send in the marines and maybe a nuke! 'merica, hoorah!' we got characters we really care about, not just if they live or die but if they can work through their trauma post ww2. it's never so dark we can't see the action to save on cgi.  civillians not governments taking care of business.  it's goofy, it's tense, it's got heart, it's got a killer boss-battle soundtrack... yeah.  watch this one.

An epic, yet emotionally grounded and heartfelt film. 
Easily one of my top three favorite Godzilla films of all time.

If you can, see it in IMAX!
Amazing. Awesome. Great movie. Thanks!
Main story very good with multiple excellent sub-plots.
The best Godzilla film to DATE!!!!!

A truly phenomenal film that manages to be on par with the original 1954 film. The film was able to give us a great story and human characters that you actually come to care about. With a budget of 15 million this film gives us beautiful effects that put the higher budget films to shame. If you are a fan of Godzilla do yourself a favor and go see this movie asap.
An excellent story with developed characters and clever themes.
Very satisfying. The movie has a story line that is strong and maintains its connection to its roots.
One of if not the best Godzilla movie I have ever seen. Along with that it is an amazing tribute to the Franchise.

I was born in the early fifties and remembered the first Godzilla movie, this was a fresh remake of the original with a great story line.  I related to the line up of actors in a way which made the movie even more enjoyable having spent time in Japan.  Definitely would recommend.
One of the best films to come out of this year! 10/10
Amazing!!!! This is the Godzilla we ALL have been waiting for...well worth the ticket price, will see it again on the BIG screen.

A phenomenal and heartwarming movie of redemption. The story of survivors guilt and dealing with PTSD should hit home and inspire. And BTW Godzilla was in it. The action scenes were more engaging and realistic than any CGI or digitized work could ever capture. One truly feels the horror and destructive power in each and every encounter. Absolutely the Best Godzilla movie I have ever seen, and one of the best movies period in the last 25 years. This one should go in for Oscar contention under at least best foreign film, but more appropriately under Best Film. I would pay to see this at least a couple more times.

An excellent film due to fine acting of characters the viewer truly relates to and cares for.

IMAX is wholly unnecessary for screening because of that. A theater room with strong audio may aid in evoking emotional response, but so could one playing in mono.

And such an impression extends to visuals. A larger screen does not at all evoke response. Acting does. Visually, at one point a viewer may wish that director Takashi Yamazaki had put someone in a rubber Godzilla suit, letting the viewer's imagination further work. However, one begins to see that the creature's CGI, deliberately made to look as if someone is in just such a rubber suit, is thoughtfully done in respectful homage to the original 1954 *Godzilla* film. Yamazaki proves that creativity can and does exist even when barraged by current digital special effects and at less expense than that spent by the US film industry.

The storyline and dialogue also could be anime -- right down to the happily ever after(?) ending -- yet truly fit into the classical kaiju mold, in which they brilliantly portray the life of a young family and post-WWII Japanese community.

And this film is edited well. Never once does one wonder how much time remains before credits.

Overall, *Godzilla Minus One* is a jubilant shock at how enjoyable a movie  can be after years of drudging superhero special effects stories where "this...changes..." nothing but one's pocketbook.

Excellent! The Japanese prove that Hollywood studios should just stop trying to make these movies. Godzilla Minus One has a ton of heart and will make you care for the characters, Godzilla tearing up a city and sinking ships is just a bonus.

One if not the greatest Godzilla movie by far. Shin Godzilla had brought back the original concept for the monster and honestly I never thought they would have made a similar movie since legendary was currently making the newest series of Godzilla movies. Toho really went back to the drawing board to make Godzilla the terrifying creature he once was back in 1954. He's not your hero or anti-hero in this film, but a monster of pure terror and destruction that symbolizes the immense power of an atomic bomb given life. It had a compelling story with some good action with Godzilla. The best way I can personally describe this movie is that its a war movie feeling the aftermath of WWII and the country now had to defend itself with whatever army it has left against an unknown creature that came about from the attack of the war itself.

I won't make a super long review here because I think I can sum this up in a few sentences. Godzilla Minus One is the best Godzilla to date, it holds its own against Hollywood's version visually, its got the best story with touching moments and wonderful actors, the best version of Godzilla and gives you a very satisfying ending IMO. Go see this immediately and support Goji in Japan and in America, I believe both are amazing and I can't wait to see what the sequel might be. Godzilla Minus One is second to no one. 9/10 final score and the best movie I've seen all year! Goji is BACK and better than ever in Japan!
Film was amazing! Toho did Godzilla justice, as one would expect of Toho! Bravo!!

Godzilla Minus One is a competent, well-shot addition to the series.  Although it's much better than any of the drivel produced by Legendary Pictures, it still leaves much to be desired.  Good acting is offset by terribly written dialogue, and there's plenty of dubious CGI on display throughout the film.  The human drama is at the forefront,  with the titular kaiju taking a backseat to what is a decent, although ploddingly paced, story.  Overall a decent film, and easily within the top half-dozen Godzilla films, but it can't contend with a masterpiece like the 1954 original or a gripping contemporary take like Shin Godzilla.   Not bad, just severely overhyped.

This movie gives us a peek into Japan after WW2 that we rarely get to see. The mix of defeat Japan had after WW2 and the search for a identity brought together by the need to Defeat Godzilla who is rampaging throw a country finding its identity. The clash of war and peace, identity and obscurity to build a new Japan as reality of what happened moves them forward to a new Japan. As much as this is a story about a monster it is also a story about the people trying to grow past WW2 and the culture during the war to achieve self worth again for a bright future of Japan. Godzilla represents victory of achieving this goal of a new identity by doing it better for a brighter future.

I can only find very minor nitpicky things wrong with this movie. Outside the 'monster' story, the movie holds up as a well-told, compelling story of post war Japan, PTSD, and post war recovery efforts in a devastated society. This would have been enough, but they added a giant angry monster, and it's awesome.

The small moments of homage to the original are sweet reminders to us Godzilla 'veterans' and an amazing introduction to all the new fans this movie will bring in.

The acting is top notch, the effects are flawless when they need to be, and the pacing is how a big budget monster movie should be. Once again, Japan takes a film genre, and establishes a new baseline for everyone else to reach for.

As a following of Godzilla as a kid and having watched every possible media production, the film is the single greatest and terrifying Godzilla film produced. 2023's Godzilla Minus One- Is essentially a faithful remake/retelling of the 1954 Original. Keeping & instilling the message & morals of the original film. Whereas the original film focused more on Godzilla & the destruction of Japan, with the struggle & emotions of the Japanese people being more the backdrop to the main characters of the original film (i.e. Godzilla & the city itself) Minus One however subverts this expectation and focuses more on character development with the human characters themselves. The screen time we do get of Godzilla rampaging throughout Japan & the destruction he causes; though more breif than I was wanting, is a sight to be hold and leaves a significant impact. Just wish there was more of it!
Love this movie!!! Love, love, love it!!! My favorite Godzilla ever and I am 49! Beautiful work!!
great movie highly recommend 👌🏼

This may be the best movie I’ve ever seen. And I don’t speak a lick of Japanese! (I was unaware the movie was only in Japanese and subtitled for English). I was shocked at the heart of this film, as I was expecting a run of the mill monster movie. This movie has such great acting and emotion and heart to it. I’m recommending this to everyone. Excellent score as well! This movie is powerful!
Excellent movie great cast good story
A wonderful monster movie! I really compelling human story as well.
By far the greatest Godzilla movie since the 1954 original.  Great human story terrifying monster story.

If you are a godzilla fan then this is a must see movie. 
Be warned, it is a fully japanese film with subtitles, so if you arent into that you may want to wait for a dubbed version but the film is worth watching this way if you can do it. 

While the film is not perfect, theres quite a few things lost in translation and there are a few choices in how it is put together that I would have done differently, its still a great movie. 
If you just want a mindless monster movie, like the legendary pictures godzilla, you will likely not enjoy this one as much. This is more of the thinking mans godzilla like the original. 
But if you are a fan of godzilla's classic storytelling and solid themes that are heavy in morality, emotion, and thoughtfulness then this is a film to see in big screen. 
This one evokes the best format of godzilla, the eminent threat to, and enemy of, humanity that we have to struggle to deal with, and it touches at the heart and soul of the original film and all its successors into shin gojira. 
The characters and archetypes are fun though predictable, but they are more about carrying the message and theme of the film rather than being fully fleshed out entities. 
The visuals are gorgeous and really nail the time period feeling and make godzilla feel threatening and savage, theres some truly awesome moments in there and some legit tense scenes. 

The main drawback I have is with the pacing, especially early on as we dont really get to know the characters they simply drop in which is a bit of a letdown and sometimes confusing. 

Overall I would definitely give this a recommend, I would have been more comfortable with a 4.5 star rating but I felt it deserves more than 4 for what the director, cast, and crew accomplished.
Absolutely amazing.  Best Godzilla story of them all, incredible acting, cinematography, music, and so realistic, you didn't feel compelled to look for things that looked fake.  Wonderful story line

Yet, most of the movie is more of a character study with Godzilla as more of an afterthought at times.  I mean it is about people living in Japan right after WWII.  It's a decent movie but not a hard-core kaiju one for me.  One thing about it is that the Japanese military isn't in it much.  After WWII, they didn't have much working weapons and, as part of the treaty, were required to remove weapons from vessels etc.  So, Godzilla goes up against homemade stuff vice the laser cannons etc. from previous movies.

Second, it shows a gripping story about human characters in a monster movie that add to the plot rather than just be there for the ride, thus succeeding where many monster movies fail. Third, it is an absolutely awesome monster movie and a phenomenal modern rendition of the original Godzilla movie with all the horror and despair that the original created, just with the addition of modern day cinematography capability’s. If you can, do watch it, as it is worth it.

I have been a Godzilla fan for over 31 years at this point. I have seen every film in the series. I've been lucky enough to see Godzilla '98, Godzilla 2000 Millennium, Godzilla '14, Shin Godzilla, and Godzilla: King of the Monsters in the cinema, so it was a genuine treat to see Godzilla Minus One. I live in the middle of nowhere so it was an hour long drive. But the drive home was good thinking time. 

This movie has opinions. It has very clear things to say about war, valuing life, and individual people's role in society. It has "big acting." Huge displays of human emotion. Consider the collective strain and trauma and how overwhelmed you'd been in these situations. 

Luckily for us the "big acting" is attached to legitimately interesting characters who you don't want to see get squashed by Godzilla, because for the first time in a long time, Godzilla is a dick. This verison of Godzilla reminds me of "Godzilla, Mothra, King Ghidorah: Giant Monsters All Out Attack" (2001) in how much he just hates. If he sees a person that person dies unless they get away or at least out of sight. He will tolerate none in his way. 

To continue, I echo much of what you've probably already read: impressive visual effects, especially for the budget. The plot is good and you have characters you like. The score is not overly dependent on Ifukube but the expected themes are there and they are exceptional updates. The original music is generally good with a few haunting themes I liked. The sound design was great actually, and I liked when the film chose to slow down and be quiet for a few minutes. 

Fans of the Godzilla series will probably notice the nods to the past... and I feel that it was done well, with the easter eggs being fairly subtle, rather than overtly shoved in your face. 

If you're only familiar with the Legendary MonsterVerse Godzilla, this movie is very different. This is a post-WWII antiwar drama about survivors guilt, PTSD, found family, and the value of human life. There just happens to be some incredible monster scenes and exciting action scenes. But it's a drama. I loved it. Go see it while its in theaters.

This movie has a beautiful story and at times you almost forget you're watching a monster movie. The actors are fantastic and some scenes are very emotional. Godzilla himself is more terrifying than ever and there is plenty of action to move this movie along.

OH MY GODZILLA!!!!

I'm utterly speechless, this movie was amazing in every possible way imaginable for an audience wanting to be entertained. The Human characters were very well written, the acting was outstanding, the emotions were strong with loss, pride and hope. The main cast were perfect together as a group, even the minor characters were amazing. The music, Oh My God the Music was conducted to fit every scene it was in and the OG theme was incredible to hear in a Dolby theater for the first time. Akira Ifukube would be proud, May he Rest In Peace. Lastly it was very educating in a way to see what Japan was like immediately after the War following the Atomic Bombs. The hardships they went through just to rebuild was very emotional to watch, but the way they climbed out of that pit of hopelessness would inspire any viewer to the franchise both Long Time along with Newer Fans

Now to the matter at Hand, the Star Himself, GODZILLA.

The King of the Monsters is more terrifying in this movie than any other in the 69 year history of the Longest running franchise in the World! Every time he appears on screen he strikes fear into your very soul and leaves you in Awe at the same time. His destruction was unrelenting, the action out of this world, his Power Godly, his portrayal Very Real. At times you almost feel sorry for him because what's happened to him wasn't his fault. I haven't seen a monster movie this well done since Peter Jackson's King Kong (2005) and Cloverfield (2008).

My solid review of this movie is a 10/10, and I recommend save notifications of any kind for when this movie hits the Home Media market because I sure will.

Honestly I don't think I've ever watched a movie this perfect before
