Lifetime Godzilla fan here. As I've grown older, I still love the franchise as a whole, but unfortunately, as soon as Toho realized you could make money putting the focus on the giant monster versus battles compared to the human drama, it just hasn't been the same. However, this movie manages to give us a compelling and well-written AND well-acted story, with some of the best monster action to the date. Gojira has been my favorite for a while (GMK a close second), but Minus One is, for several reasons, my favorite, and I'm excited to take the whole family to see it tomorrow.

For me this film was the best of the best Godzilla films ever made! I rank it with the original Godzilla 1954 for being the best! I thought the acting,storytelling and the music was spot on! As a full grown old man I cried because of the characters were so intense in their roles! Hats off to Toho and the Japanese people in making a grand masterpiece!👍🏻👍🏻👍🏻👍🏻👍🏻 100%

This is the first Godzilla film from Toho since 2016 and it was honestly worth the wait. It hits you with every emotion especially sorrow and I cared for the characters so much I didn't want them to die. You feel for them throughout the film and want to cry with them. The incredible score adds to it. Godzilla surprisingly feels more scarier than Shin Godzilla which I thought was a high bar to reach but obviously I need to reevaluate my bars. The director is obviously a Steven Spielberg fan as well because Godzilla felt like Jaws. He was a force of nature unlike most Godzilla films. Godzilla Minus One is worth seeing on the biggest screen you can and I highly recommend you see this spectacle while it's in theaters.
excellent story! the acting was phenomenal! best Godzilla ever!
Best Godzilla movie ever.
Fantastic Godzilla film 👏
It held true to the old Godzilla movies while still being a thrilling and absolutely terrifying experience. You could see the passion from all of the cast and they performed so well.
Not only the best Godzilla movie, but one of, if not the best movie in recent memory. Fantastic on every level

Godzilla Minus One is so much more than at first glance. Godzilla Minus One is a modern cinematic masterpiece that harkens back to the original Godzilla. The acting is top notch and the setting of post WW2 Japan is very somber. The overall theme of the story is one of survivors guilt. The visuals of the movies are amazing considering the budget of the film is a fraction of a Hollywood film. It may sound crazy but Godzilla Minus One should be considered for best motion picture or director at the Oscars.
Awesome movie, really true to the way Godzilla is portrayed. Spectacular cast aswell. Effects were amazing, overall a 10/10 experience for me.
Minus One is the best Godzilla movie of them all so far.  I was surprised by the depth of the story-telling and the poignant struggles of the main character.  Metaphors abound.

Its simple - best Godzilla movie ever made. Its budget (15 million dollars) with its quality, both production and acting wise, puts to shame all Hollywood blockbusters. Go and see it - you will be very pleased, also by a surprisingly good and engaging human story.

I thought Godzilla had peaked once more with the amazing Shin Godzilla, and would be untouchable for years to come, but I was so wrong, and happily so. Godzilla Minus One is THE BEST Godzilla movie imo, and easily, one of the best movies of this year. It does something the western Godzilla movies fail to do, and that is have a captivating, compelling human element amongst all the destruction. You'd do a disservice to yourself not to check out this movie in theaters.
The best Godzilla movie I've ever seen perfectly blends monster action and human drama

I want to sit with it and see it again but this might be the greatest Godzilla movie of them all. i know its bold statement but WoW..... if you're any sort of Godzilla fan you owe it to yourself to see this on the biggest screen with the best sound system you can find. Best Movie of 2023 for me. I found nothing to nitpick. I cant really give any higher praise than that. everything works the actors are all top notch the cg was perfect the score amazing.... just wow

A great monster movie with a very strong (and surprisingly emotional) human story! Feelings of terror, hopelessness, sadness, joy, and triumph made this a very welcome part of the Godzilla franchise! An absolute must see

Im a lifelong Godzilla fan (okay, obsessive) but believe me when I say that this may be the best in the series since the 1954 debut, and a film that can, and should be, appreciated by anyone. Everything works in this original, inventive film - the visuals and creature design, the believable story (given the irradiated monster in the middle of it), and the human drama that is so often the boring bits between atomic destruction.  Even if you have franchise fatigue, book your tickets for this one - well be talking about it for years.
Absolutely spectacular! Best Godzilla to date! An absolute must see!
phenomenal movie, godzilla is insane and the humans in the movie are fantastic

When Godzilla arrived at Tokyo for the first time and his main theme started playing, everyone in my theater lost their minds, It was so nostalgic hearing Godzilla's main suite playing whilst he was destroying Tokyo! Godzilla's atomic breath scene was also one of the coolest things I've ever seen in a movie. His atomic breath is literally like a nuke exploding! One of my favorite parts of the movie was when Godzilla got half his head blown off, and he instantly regenerated it. Another cool part of this movie is when Godzilla "dies" and it cuts to a shot of a piece of Godzilla flesh regenerating, teasing a potential sequel. I forgot to mention how awesome these human characters are, I actually cared for these characters and I was worried for them throughout the movie ( Unlike past Godzilla films ). Also, can I mention how awesome the human story is? This is possibly the best human story I've ever seen in a Godzilla film. The plot to kill Godzilla was so creative in my opinion, sinking Godzilla to the bottom of the ocean so the sea pressure would crush him, and then when they bring Godzilla back to the surface to finish the job, it was so dang awesome! One of my favorite things about this film was the fact it had so many references to the old Godzilla movies, I noticed at least a few dozen references. I found out after I watched this movie that this film's budget was 15 MILLION DOLLARS! For reference, Godzilla vs Kong's budget was 155-200 million dollars! Getting to see Godzilla be the "bad guy" again was a nice breath of fresh air. I simply cannot put into words how much I enjoyed watching this film. Arguably the best Godzilla film ever made!

If you are a die hard Godzilla fan if you've not seen this what the hell is wrong with you this movie in my eyes is a prequel to The original Gojira and is worth 10 million stars out of 5

Not just a great Godzilla movie, it's a great movie period! Great story about war and the cost of war, friendship and family. The last line of the movie hit pretty hard especially if you or a loved one has served in the military. Plus it has Godzilla! Highly recommended!

I recently watched the original 1954 Godzilla movie and found it a great balance of monster movie and emotional drama. I'd suggest that the time and the movie culture of Japan in that time made the latter aspect a difficult challenge, but they did manage it. Subsequent Godzilla movies that I've seen have not provided this for me, but I fully acknowledge this isn't a franchise I've devoted myself to, so there are likely many that achieve this.

So that said, I struggle to remember a movie that I was more impressed with or enjoyed more. It was astonishingly good, with personal grief and emotion, seriously frightening scenes of devastations, and actual "I'm not crying, you're crying" moments (In a Godzilla movie!!). I really felt this wasn't a movie of monster devastation, but boy howdy was there monster and devastation, but a movie about people and how the heck would they deal with this catastrophe just shortly after the war that they'd barely survived.

You'll hear a lot about this film. Go see it so you can be the one who saw it first (okay this might be a little marketing).

*****

I've tried to avoid saying it's the best movie I've seen in years, but others are saying similar things. 

Like Forbes Magazine for example. "…the latest reboot Godzilla Minus One is one of 2023's greatest films." and "The result is that Godzilla Minus One is the best Godzilla film ever made, and a masterpiece of kaiju cinema"
Wow... he was angry, and just, wow! TOHO nailed it this time.
Perfect Godzilla movie!!
THAT SCENE WHERE THEY PUT THE BOMBS AROUND GODZILLA AND THEME PLAYING MY LORD IT THE BEST MOVIE THIS YEAR BY A LAND SLIDE

Didn't think I'd say this about a Godzilla movie but I really cared about the humans! Well crafted characters that actually had you emotionally invested in them and their relationships, not only to each other but also to the star of the show himself, Godzilla. This is also the best looking and most realistic Godzilla ever and I remember thinking multiple times "wow, they really put a lot of money into this movie." Then I found out the budget was only $15 million! That made the movie even more impressive than it already was. Don't see this movie at home as your first experience....see it in the theatre! It's not only a love letter to Godzilla fans but a great film for all movie fans in general. Not doubt "Godzilla Minus One" is in the Top 3 Godzilla films of all-time if not the greatest! 5/5
This is how a Godzilla movie should be done! I love this movie so much!

This film is an absolute triumph. The human protagonists elevate rather than reduce the quality of the story, a quality that is missing in many Godzilla films. The story is thematically dense, thought provoking, tragic and yet uplifting. Whether you are a longtime fan or have never watched a Godzilla film, this movie will blow you away.
I  loved the story line , and the pace of the movie. Definitely top two movies of Toho.  I am seeing again tomorrow. !

This was a great version of Godzilla.  It's not just some monster movie - it has a good plot and heart-breaking personal stories behind it. It spins a story that older people will absolutely relate too, and the sci-fi/visuals are top notch.   If you are into all that cookie cutter comic book movies or think the masked singer is great forget this movie.

To be honest, I have only ever seen the American Godzilla films. Which is why I was really excited when I heard this Japanese production was getting a wide release. And, as someone new to this franchise, Minus One floored me!
The acting is fantastic, the characters are endearing, the cinematography is gorgeous, the music is awesome, the effects are fantastic, and Godzilla is terrifying!
I have but one spoiler-filled flaw with this film, and that's it!
This is a staggeringly fantastic blockbuster! It delivered so much of everything that I wanted as a newcomer to this franchise, that I can only imagine how ecstatic longtime Godzilla fans will be watching this film!
Absolutely fantastic!

Un film su Godzilla in cui il mostro passa in secondo piano. Non fraintendetemi, è il miglior "protagonista Godzilla" della serie, davvero maestoso, esaltato dai moderni effetti speciali, un'accurata fotografia e la sua classica ed inconfondibile colonna sonora. Semplicemente la storia umana narrata nel film, e le riflessioni sulla cultura giapponese a cui questo porta, sono davvero incredibili per non farle passare in primo piano. La maestria del regista Yamazaki nell'abbinare a tutto ciò un buon vecchio stile cinematografico, ne fa il (mio) film più bello di questo 2023.

I have never seen another Godzilla movie before this but you don't have to. This movie is a stand alone Godzilla film that is perfect. The human story had me emotionally invested to where I was not bored when Godzilla was not on screen. When Godzilla was on screen I feared that he would kill our main character's. The acting from the cast is some of the best I've seen. I would recommend seeing this movie no matter who you are.

Generally I don't like to watch movies where I have to read the captions, but in this movie, it didn't interfere AT ALL with either watching the movie, or reading the captions. The story is very dramatic.  The Godzilla monster is absolutely vicious when it comes to killing and destroying.  The special effects with the Godzilla renders were excellent. Sometimes off when it came to navy ships.  The movie was not fast paced, but it did move along and didn't leave me bored at any point.  I enjoyed the story and the movie as a whole.  This movie proves you don't have to go all 200+ million dollars to create a great movie with top tier special effects.  If you like  great drama, great acting, and a great monster movie, this is the one!

From surviving WWII to encountering Godzilla, the main protagonist goes through hell. Over the past 7 decades, the Toho Godzilla series has offered everything from somber horror, to camp, to thrills, to almost arcade-like action - and I've enjoyed (pretty much) them all. This one takes us back to the beginning, and I swear Godzilla has never been more terrifying, or the human elements of the film more engrossing. This film will take hold of you emotionally more than any previous installment, and more than the vast majority of cinema has ever managed. It is a bit slow to set up, but it pays off. If subtitles bother you, I'm not sure a dubbed version is showing - but I also doubt a dub could do some of these performances justice.

I'm honestly surprised by all the glowing reviews. I was really excited to see this movie after watching the trailer, but it was a huge letdown. I'll admit, the opening was one of the best Godzilla segments I've ever seen, and Japan's Godzilla is way more terrifying than Hollywood's. But aside from the intense and terrifying Godzilla scenes (of which there were few), the film suffered from pacing issues and unlikeable characters. During one of its many slow sequences, the man next to me literally yelled, "Just move on already." I'd suggest just skipping to the Godzilla scenes when it comes out.

Godzilla Minus One is most likely my favorite movie of the year. The strength of its storytelling and special effects are immense, but on a scale far more grand than the modest budget might have you think. The film is an interesting alternate take on the story of the original 1954 film, with many characters and scenes in homage to the classic, while also delivering amazing new ways the giant monster has not been perceived before and with a ferocity that can actually generate fear. Highest recommendation to any moviegoing fan, not just the genre junkies like me.

A movie that goes back to the series roots while taking a new perspective to the approach. Lively characters that are entertaining through the humor and the drama, and a ferocious relentless take on the Japanese beast. Haunting scores to go along with his appearances accompanied by fantastic acting. This film will remind you how haunting this time for Japan was.

Best monster movie I've ever seen.  The human story would have been good as a standalone story and fits in with Godzilla so well.  You can tell they paid homage to the 1954 origin too!

Something rare that Godzilla movies do is make you care and be interested in the human characters. The emotional feeling from the original 1954 film is recaptured here. You get attached to the main characters so much that it makes you wish that nothing happens to them. Godzilla is scary, and his performance in the film probably out beats the rest. This is not the hero that restores balance, or "just an animal", this is monster Godzilla. The writing is spectacular, and the film itself just looks amazing. Brilliant film. I would be disappointed if this film is not at least a nominee for the Academy Awards.

such a sigma movie all my sigmas should watch it

I thought it was fantastic! All of Godzilla fans want more screen time for the big guy so that's a given. The movie was very entertaining and fx was done well. My only kind of negative thoughts is that I wanted more stomping through Tokyo...lol. Go enjoy it fan or not.
This may be the best movie of 2023.  Highly highly recommend.

This movie is not only for Kaiju fans but for anyone who is looking for a good emotional action packed entertainment. Not only is the story well told but the visual effects have you questioning what is Hollywood doing these days because this movie is very low budget. A huge step up from "shin:Godzilla"(2016) this movie is the most important movie to have come out of japan cinema in a very long time.

This movie is a masterpiece. It is one of the rare movies where I felt a true emotional connection to the human characters. Often in a Godzilla film you want more Godzilla and less of the "plot humans", but this movie hit the perfect balance. This is a movie about family, about the value of life, and returns Godzilla back to its serious origins. The effects are also a spectacle, never have I seen such a clear view at Godzilla and have him move in such an organic way. A monstrous Godzilla paired with a somber and beautiful plot. There has never been a better Godzilla film in theater.
The film blew me away! Best Godzilla movie since the 1954 original. Sound design was amazing. People are going to be talking about this film for a long time.
Extremely entertaining once the actions starts. The music is iconic. This new Godzilla is awesome.
This is probably the most dramatic and emotionally filled Godzilla movie, that keeps you engaged from start to finish, with great scenes of destruction with the big G.

Godzilla Minus One may be one of if not the best film in the entire godzilla franchise!

Our main protagonists in the film are engaging and show us the struggles of post war Japan. We feel their sorrow and pain as well as their faith as they push for a better future.

As for the big G himself… WOW!! Every time he is on screen, you are on the edge of your seat! His presence is horrifying and majestic at the same time. He is a walking atomic bomb and it shows!

11/10
Such a great movie! Smart, mature, thoughtful, made by competent people with a really great artistic vision.

The Godzilla films have long suffered from lackluster writing for the human characters. Don't get me wrong, I have seen every Godzilla movie and have been a fan since I was a kid, but it's always been about watching monsters destroying cities. Godzilla Minus One feels like a complete movie package. Great characters, great acting, a smart plot, and a Godzilla that is actually scary. Go see this one in the theater!

As a long time Godzilla fan I went into this film with high expectations, and Toho certainly didn't disappoint. Not only does this film hold an empathetic and engaging human cast but it also tells a tonal and dramatic story of guilt, a soldiers duty, and the aftermath of war. Personally I would've enjoyed this as a standalone film, but the biggest cherry on top is how Godzilla was seamlessly weaved into the story. Godzilla actually played a large roll in the main character's motivations and development rather than the typical random obstacle to overcome. Godzilla himself harkens back to the original 1954 version, a terrifying monster, a force of nature with no rhyme or reason disturbed by humanity's meddling. Godzilla in this film is terrifying, even more so than 2016s Shin Godzilla. Overall I only had minor critiques throughout the film and despite personally finding the ending a bit disappointing, I think the rest of the film makes up for it completely. This film is not only an example of how to make an amazing monster movie, but also just an amazing movie in general. 10/10

This movie was absolutely amazing. It had an amazing story line and the characters in the movie were not useless to the story line. Also the movie did a great job in making the viewers actually care about the humans and what happens to them. They did a great job with the CGI making Godzilla look real. Over all this movie was a 9/10 definitely a must watch.
One of the best Godzilla films ever created and should be seen by everyone!
One of the best films of the year.

One of the greatest pieces of cinema ever out to screen! A sobering retelling of the original 1954 film, Godzilla Minus One (2023) displays the crippling tragedy of war through the metaphor of the monster who has, and always will, do it best. The film is a true emblem of the broken post-war Japan. The feelings of disgrace and overwhelming trauma of the war are expertly woven into the characters and their narrative, providing a gripping human element that gives to heart and weight to the film. A culmination of a nearly 70 year legacy, Godzilla Minus One (2023) is perhaps the best and most raw Godzilla has ever been.

Godzilla Minus One was a very emotional piece, with easily the best human story in the franchise, and quite a classic movie feel. I know this will definitely be one of my favorite films of all time for the rest of my life.
Terrifying, deeply moving, and thought-provoking. See it on the largest screen you can.
Absolutely masterpiece! Godzilla was terrifying and looked amazing. I've never been so invested in the human story of a Godzilla movie before
Taking what makes Godzilla great and taking it back to basics.

Monster Disappointment.  The writer/director (Takashi Yamazaki) talked this up as a film that would capture the horror, terror, and despair that Godzilla would create if real.  The teasers and trailers all mirrored that description, but the actual movie is 10% Godzilla and 90% human melodrama.  I am one of "those" Godzilla fans - the ones who go to a Godzilla movie to see Godzilla, not the human characters.  I never felt any connection to any of the characters and found myself looking at my watch during the last 40 minutes of the film.
I understand a lot of Godzilla fans love this movie, but I was not one of them.

Best Godzilla movie I've ever seen, it's amazing to see what this team did with a 15 million dollar budget. Great storyline and even better visual effects. It's a must watch on the big screen! I prefer the original Japanese with English subtitles viewing if you can make it.
Awesome movie, best version of Godzilla so far. Can't wait for what next!

Incredible a fresh, real, human look at a genre we think we know. Godzilla has become enshrined mythos in Japanese culture and here it is examined through the eyes of authentic characters played by a superb cast. For truly the first time despite the phenomenal special effects we have seen him in the recent monsterverse films the creature is terrifyingly real. The cast and plot aided by top notch direction has given us dare I say it an Oscar worthy tale for the ages.

This was an amazing movie start to finish. The human element of dealing with ptsd, and how terrifying Godzilla is. This is what a monster movie should be. ..a scary Godzilla. Very well paced and balanced between Godzilla and the human element!!!!

As far as Godzilla movies go, Minus One is among the best of the best. Taking us back to a traumatic period in Japanese history, it reflects on Japan's place in the war, and how Godzilla itself is now a representation of trauma. It has great characters, great music, great action, and utilises its budget well. Great film.
The best Godzilla movie yet!

Godzilla Minus One is one of, if not, the best Godzilla movie out there right now. The pacing is perfect. The story is phenomenal, when Godzilla shows up it is extremely tense, and you're on the edge of your seat rooting for the characters. The visual effects and design of Godzilla is some of the best I've ever seen, and it's not just Godzilla who's awesome, every character is well thought out and has their time to shine. It is a perfect balance of human and Godzilla, and they even benefit each other which isn't as common as it should be. I also want to say the sound design was extraordinary, when Godzilla is on screen, you don't just see him, you hear him too. Definitely a movie to see in the best screen/theater possible. I also want to mention the music was also amazing,  it was so cool to hear a ton of classic Godzilla music, and the new music made for this film is possibly better than the classic music. I walked into Godzilla Minus One expecting an amazing movie, but it was an experience I walked out of, and one I want to relive over and over again.
Must watch in 4DX theater. Story is compelling and the action is amazing. Heat Ray steals the show.
Spectacular! Best version of Godzilla movie I have ever seen. This was beautifully written and I will definitely be watching it again.

By far, best Godzilla movie in terms of story and FX.  If there was anything bad, it would be not enough monster but then you run risk of boring movie so they really focused on character development so much that it feels like a post war drama with Godzilla as a backdrop.  What was interesting was the plan to kill the monster which was very creative and just something you never see the humans do in such a film which is fight head on with the monster.
Loved it! Returned to a classic format and Godzilla looked amazing!

Sorry, this film had too many lapses in logic and was marred by poor, stilted, one-note acting to be effective. I mean, the best performance was by the young girl. That's kind of sad, you know. 
The premise is good, but what's on screen just progresses from one scene to the next like everyone is going through the motions. Maybe the only scene with any urgency takes place on the boat when the crew of four first encounters Godzilla. 
And seeing how the US base in Ginza must surely have been destroyed, it's incredulous to believe the US wouldn't get involved. If the director had wanted to get away with a pure fantasy film, he'd have done better to set it 200 years in the past. WWII memories are still very much alive and rewriting history like this is risky business.

Yamazaki's Minus One is an essay on maximizing a modest budget by employing excellent character development that grounds this Godzilla outing to a degree that audiences haven't seen since the 1954 original.  It's a visceral tour de force with all the money on screen.  An engaging often poignant dramatic piece about community, PTSD and survivor's guilt along with self redemption.  The Godzilla set pieces are utterly riveting but it's the uniformly superb ensemble cast that will cement Minus One as one of the best films of 2023 and it's standing within the kaiju pantheon.

An intelligent, emotional story about post war trauma and survival that just happens to have a radioactive monster arrive to add to the wartime devastation.   This is a movie that proves that you can blend realistic characters dealing with authentic problems with fantastical elements and make a compelling story.  In Japanese with subtitles as it should be.  The characters and situations are so well developed you could watch it without translation and still understand the film.   Kudos also for the attention to detail regarding the use of WWII Japanese military equipment and warships that are relevant to the story.   And Godzilla?  He never looked better.  True to the original 1954 version but with details not possible using traditional effects.    This is one enraged and destructive creature.   This is  a Godzilla movie that makes you forget the underwhelming Monsterverse offerings.  Go see it!
Masterpiece! It earns that 98% RT score and SO MUCH MORE (no thanks to Adam Does Movies the only negative critic review). I urge anyone to see this movie you will come out more than satisfied.
This Godzilla is the best. It finally makes Godzilla scary again. In no way is he saving Earth- he's the enemy now. He is so much more powerful. Loved the movie.
This is my personal favorite Gojira movie ever made. It's definitely worth seeing in a theater.  Go support this movie if you are a fan!!!

This film was a roller-coaster from the start. Godzilla was a malevolent force that almost took on a Terminator esque persona. The graphics most of the time were amazing and believable but at times seemed poorly paced and unrealistic.

As a faithful reimagening and retelling of the original Godzilla film. It's provides a unique look at how people deal with trauma and how to move on. 

It is a must see for any Kaiju lover and doubly so for a Godzilla fan.
Great mix of Monster and human story. Great action scenes. Over all Godzilla is and still King of the monsters.

Godzilla minus one is one of the best godzilla films to come out since godzilla 1954. Having characters you want to root for, a monster of war and the evils of nuclear power, and a rich story that doesn't get confusing a muddled like more recent *american* godzilla films.
The soundtrack having a dreadful feeling to it, including parts of the 1954 soundtrack that made me shake in my seat.
Godzilla is a true villain, but you can tell he is still just a mutated creature, having him only become physically dangerous with his heat ray when attacked.
This is the perfect prequel film, and I would gladly watch it again.
If you like Godzilla movies, you will love it. If you like a good story on loss and redemption, you will love it as well
I loved the movie so much. best Kaiju movie.

I went in theaters to watch this film and….
This blew away my expectations, best Godzilla film of all time right next to Godzilla 2014, King of the Monsters, and the original  1954 film.

I seriously recommend this timeless masterpiece to all those about to go out there to the movie theaters, like seriously they made the Godzilla and the human screentime perfectly balanced, and fixed the Goji screentime problem. Filled with emotions, horror, dark tones, and relations.

I'm not kidding, this is the best movie of all-time now (to me at least) but still, I recommend this movie, it was SPECTACULAR I promise you.
SEE IT IN IMAX OF YOU CAN
The best Godzilla movie ever made.  Outstanding acting and story.   Godzilla was really pissed off during the movie.   A surprise ending.    A must see.
Beautiful, directing, powerful film. Great acting all around, Godzilla is scary again.

This is a movie first, and a Godzilla movie second. Yet, it does not neglect the giant monsters. 

Godzilla is very present, and very destructive. 

This movie is more like Shin Godzilla than Godzilla: Final Wars. It's a beautiful piece of cinema that often leaves you astounded at what is presented. 

Run to see this movie in theaters. The sound design is so amazing, it deserves an award. The movie simply sounds better in a theater then it could possibly sound on any smaller screen.

EVERYTHING WAS GOOD MOVIE OF THE YEAR IT WAS GREAT REALLY HEARTFELT FOR MY BIC BOI
GODZILLA
While not as intellectually stimulating as Shin Godzilla, Godzilla: Minus One succeeds in almost every area, making it a must see for any fan of monster movies or war dramas.
this isn't just one of the best godzilla movies ever it's one of the best movies ever period

The first monster movie in a long time where I gave a crap about the humans. I wasn’t just waiting for Godzilla to appear… but when he did … what a payoff! Run, don’t walk! Run like Godzilla was chasing you!

I’m old enough to remember the first Godzilla movie by Toho. First there was the English language version with Raymond Burr which was shown for years on TV when I was a kid. It was an amalgamation for the original Japanese language film which was finally available years later. Far superior. This latest from Toho may be the best yet. Great character development and story. Set after WWII and the aftermath of the Japanese defeat. The way the writers tied all the characters together was amazing. You really cared about them. Of course the monster and the effects are simply breathtaking. I came away feeling like I just saw one of the best films of the year. A must see even if you never saw the original. Brilliant.
Loved this movie.  Probably my favorite Godzilla movie and one of my favorites of 2023.

Loved it. Godzilla is enraged and relentless. The story telling and human connection is superb. The score is so much fun. Great acting and fantastic work, was thoroughly surprised to find out later it only had a $15m budget. Stunning. A+++
It is the best movie with the iconic Japanese monster GODZILLA, a Moral  Anti-nuclear and the very destruction of human beings. I love the fact that GODZILLA in this movie really feels the suspense.
Great movie! Not so much Hollywood involved. Just a great origin story!

This movie does what previous Godzilla movies have failed to do and that is human characters that you’ll actually want to root for and care about. As for Godzilla himself, he is done incredibly well. They have brought him back to his original roots like he was in 54. This movie is truly a top contender for the best Godzilla movie.
Best Godzilla movie of all time, puts the western adaptations to shame. And does it with less than half the budget.

The whole movie kept you attentive both with waiting what Godzilla did in a scene and the story with the characters. The atomic breath scene towards the end was probably at the same height as the Oppenheimer bomb scene.

Minus one is the best movie of the year!

Just got back from an early access fan event. It was absolutely fantastic! The story, human characters, destruction and visual effects are the best the series has ever had. His atomic blast is literally atomic. Not just a great Godzilla move but a great movie period. The best I've seen this year. See it in whichever theatre near you with the best sound system. The Dolby cinema sound was mind blowing. Godzillas roar never sounded better.

I cannot apologize for my review. 5/5 is ridiculous. Are there flaws? Absolutely...but they are minor. For a 15 Million dollar film, I now know that Hollywood is broken. CGI is like the graphics debate of video games. Good stories resonate over fancy visuals.

Am I a lifelong Godzilla fan? Yes. I love 1954, 84(85), Destoroyah, and Shin. But this is by far the best balance of human drama while respecting Godzilla's original themes. Honda and Tanaka would be proud. I am glad Japan has reclaimed its creation. The Reiwa era has followed up with a nice K.O. punch.
Great movie! Don’t expect to see godzilla in every scene, this movie builds great characters and when you do get godzilla it makes it more worth watching
I phenomenal movie. One of the best I seen this year. Godzilla is at his most terrifying we have seen him. The human plot is actually worth watching for once. A must see

A brutal and violent new take on Godzilla that gives new life to the original storyline. Acting is great, story is sad but with several relief characters that give you hope, and Godzilla is a frickin’ sea monster in a way we haven’t seen before. I’ve watched it twice and it’s amazing.

I applaud this movie for having characters we actually enjoy! Everything about this movie is perfect as a Godzilla movie and very well crafted as a legitimate movie. It's better than basically every Godzilla movie and I thought Shin Godzilla was as good as it was gonna get for a newer Godzilla film. Part of the top 3 best Godzilla films that almost anyone can like/love, fan or not. Just be warned that this movie is just as dark as the original in some aspects to the point where you could get teary-eyed watching it.

This movie was incredible. Compelling human drama, outstanding music, and absolutely TERRIFYING. The scariest Godzilla has ever been. Must see on the biggest screen possible. Had me tearing up and rooting so much for the humans.
Best Godzilla movie Ive seen personally. Usually the human characters seem bland and are just there to fill time. This movie I actually felt emotional connection towards most of the main cast. 10/10
I've been a Godzilla aficionado since childhood. This is the best Godzilla movie I've ever watched. Magnificent and happy to go see it again.

I went to an early showing of the film on November 29th, It was a last-minute decision spurred by my love of kaiju films and a desire to see new movies, I invited a few friends and when leaving the theatre we were speechless with only one thing to say, "We need to watch this again." I was blown out of the water by the superb acting and the amazing visuals. I am not an emotional person, especially with films but I teared up and cried at 2 distinct points in the movie, When watching most monster films you wish for the razing of cities and the visual of the destruction and loss of life, here is quite the opposite, believable human characters that you immediately fall in love with. I see this movie as one that is a must-see and at that, a must-see on the big screen, fans of Kaiju films Jaws, and Jurassic Park will surely enjoy. 10/10 no complaints

One of the 3 BEST G movies ever!  Completely stand alone G movie with amazing effects and a heartfelt story. Absolutely loved it! The '54 original, Shin G, and now Minus One are the the standouts in his long running franchise. The American "Monsterverse" movies just can't compete with ANY of Toho's Japanese movies. They lack the charm and feel in every way imaginable. Saw this one in 4DX so it wasa all that much more fun!
Thank you Toho and PLEASE don't stop your truly original entries. Fan for life!

This movie does what it set out to do perfectly, and is a must watch for practically anyone who's even slightly interested.

Despite my soft spot for the American films, they're sloppily written, and are sometimes overbearing and cartoon-ish with just how much they show the monsters doing "cool things."
Minus One has significantly less Godzilla than the American films, and yet has a 100% better use of the monster for what it wants to do. Godzilla is on screen for the perfect amount of time, and is used in a near perfect way.
All of the rest of the screen-time is used by extremely well written human characters, well developed themes, and proper execution of the plot.

Overall, this is easily my favorite movie of the Godzilla franchise, and deserves all the praise that it's getting. Absolute must watch.

This movie did amazing making Godzilla a destroyer, a monster to the human race. His design along with the amazing CGI did him justice. I'm also amazed that the movie made the Human characters so loveable and when the movie progresses you really see how they conquer there issues and trauma. This is probably the very first movie that made me love the human characters in a Monster movie.! And the ending makes me want to watch more so I'm super exited for the sequel!!  100%, 20/10 movie worth the watch
Great visual movie with emotional acting taking the place of  over the top special effects
I was not prepared for how amazing this movie would be.

Excellent movie all the way around! Great plot, great acting. I normally can't watch movies with subtitles, but this was SO good! This is one of my favorite looks for Godzilla, aesthetically; but as far as the destruction he causes in Minus One, it's the absolute best, in my opinion. He is very violent and powerful. Was a great experience watching in a theater. It's a must see!
Great character development and chemistry. The best live-action Godzilla that brings back the original black and white Godzilla memories to the fans.
Ayo who let them cook
This is peak cinema -Martin Scorsese
This Godzilla minus one is one of the best Godzilla movie I watched to date. Make sure to watch it in IMAX make the experience even more enjoyable.
This movie was the absolute best godzilla movie ever. I felt the genuine fear in people , so much emotion in this movie.LOVE IT
A much more moving story than I expected from a Godzilla movie. Really enjoyable experience overall!

This was a great addition to the Godzilla franchise.   The plot was great. Cinematography and special effects good also.  Godzilla has serious anger management issues but this was offset with a really heart warming storyline.
Absolute peak Godzilla

When I mean this is a masterpiece, I mean it's a masterpiece. Not only is this one of the best Godzilla movies but it's a geniunely FANTASTIC movie. With a very fresh concept, surprisingly deep characters, excellent acting, great drama, pleasing visuals, a fantastic score, and bone-chilling Godzilla sequences, this movie is truly incredible! 10/10, A+
I really hope this movie gets serious consideration for Academy Awards. It is so perfect.

The raging King returns! 
A great 21st Century Japanese culture/international level SFX entertainment film, one thing we have been waiting for to come up from the Land of Rising Sun and they finally did it.
I salute to TOHO and the production staff.

To me, the story of "Godzilla Minus One" and its cinematic perspective against of "Shin Godzilla" have a little bit in a similar relationship between "Flags of Our Fathers" and "Letters from Iwo Jima". 
Portraying one huge raged-god-like creature and the people against but from two near-totally different characters and their standpoint s, but, both are still "Catastrophic and horrifying Godzilla landfalls on Japan and the Japanese". 
They have their own pro and cons yet both they are good films, and simply very scary as well as an encouraging film, too, by the end.

Viewing in a DolbyCinama if not IMAX strongly recommended to hear his devastating roar and stamp.

Excellent movie! The human characters are well written and the emotional beats hit hard. The themes are clear and poignant, and it doesn't hurt that the monster action is captivating.

A must see for any movie enjoyers

Incredible!!!!! One of the best movies I have seen in my life so far. One of the best Godzilla main movies since the original.

The acting is incredible. The human connections the bonds, the real worry and terror!

The way they presented Godzilla in this Minus One is one of the most terrifying and genuinely scary renditions I have seen.

Just incredible!
THE GREATEST MOVIE OF ALL TIME!

In complete shock.

Such a beautiful movie - Story, Score, Acting, Cinematography, Sets, Costumes....all the things.

Godzilla is actually rather secondary to the story and the moral of it 

I actually cried.

Went for a campy nostalgia trip and saw one of the best movies I've seen in years. #GoSeeIt #GodzillaMinusOne
The plot was excellent, CGI was good. I found it interesting that some of the effects had a feel of an older Godzilla movie and the use of the old soundtrack made it feel really nostalgic but modern.
Not just the best Godzilla movie ever made, the best made movie of the year.

This was one of the best action movies I've seen in a while. I've really enjoyed the Legendary monster movies, but they could take a lesson from Toho and Takashi Yamazaki on how to create characters and story that are compelling enough to carry the movie without the monster. Then add one heck of an awesome interpretation of Godzilla and you get one of the best movies in the series. The real shocker here is that Toho did this on a $15 million budget. Disney/Lucasfilm/Marvel...Are you seeing this?
BRINGING GODZILLA BACK TO ITS ROOTS TO WELL WRITTEN CHARACTERS AND A NORE INTIMIDATING GODZILLA! HELL YEAH!!!

Godzilla Minus One is a Masterpiece in the genre, this is more than just a monster movie. It tells the story of a kamikaze pilot who struggles with shame, ptsd and survivors guilt while trying to take care of an adopted family. The story at times can beat a gut punch sprinkled with moments of levity between likable characters you learn to love and care for, which makes it all the more terrifying when Godzilla is on screen. Minus One delivers an exceptional story and returns Godzilla to what the original film intended him to be, a terrifying force of nature. Something Godzilla has been lacking for quite a while.

I love it. I went to see this with my brother and cousin and they loved it as well. The whole movie was amazing I love the action and drama. I would give this movie at least 5 Oscars awards. I love it and I would definitely watch again.
Wow just wow. Probably the greatest Godzilla movie made. For the first time I was interested in the human characters while enjoying Godzilla as a monster.

Definitely the BEST visuals in a Toho Godzilla movie to date!  It's a movie that MUST be experienced in a theater to get the full larger than life feel that Godzilla is portrayed here.  Arguably the best action flick overall in 2023...the hype and rave reviews are legit...GO SEE IT!!
The movie was awesome! The 4DX was off track so it was doing things when there was just a conversation and it was kinda annoying!! I wish it woulda synced up better

Best Toho Godzilla movie to date, the human characters and story were interesting and not just fillers between the monster stomping destruction.  The big guy himself was more terrifying and powerful than ever...and that's a good thing 👍🏼

What a wonderful and triumphant masterpiece for Toho! Absolutely loved it. If Godzilla were not in this film it still would have been an emotional drama worth watching. Godzilla was fierce and scary as Hell!
This movie was purely amazing. It was nice to see Godzilla as a horror monster then as some action hero. Godzilla roaring sent shivers down my spine.
The human drama is as compelling as the spectacle. The best movie of the year.
The effects are on point but I found it to be nothing more than the same old same old with Godzilla. Is it possible to retire this IP
Took my family and had us in suspense. I am a seasoned Godzilla fan and I was in awe throughout the movie. Go watch and be amazed.

This Godzilla movie has a very cool and terrifying Godzilla with very likable characters. it's a must watch for fans and I think even if you ain't a fan of the franchise you'll probably like this one.
I've been a Godzilla fan all of my life (I'm 37) and this is one of the best, possibly even the best. A must see!
Finally, a perfect Godzilla film, acting , score, writing and action!

Definitely going back to see it again.
Hopefully 4D.

I have seen most of the Godzilla movies and this y far the best. I plan to buy the 4k dvd if it comes out. For anyone that wondered if the original origin could be remade better this movie should convince you. There is no Raymond burr character, but they do have a quick tip of the hat is a very dark way. Speaking of dark, they do make Godzilla out to be scary and most likely the most powerful variant. By the way, the acting was also the best I have seen, even better than most of this years films. A real tear jerker actually.
This is the BEST Godzilla film I've seen in 50 years! Well done!

Even though there were a couple scenes where some effects looked kinda off, I truly feel that this is a worthy successor of Godzilla, and a new starting point for Toho’s plan for the monster in the future.

2023 making me feel like a 7 year old again with FNAF and now this AMAZING action filled atomic breath action and horror movie | the writing is actually good but to let you now you are reading subtitles the whole time and the ending I was amazed critically 10/10 as a Godzilla fan 100000000000/10

Awesome movie that manages to balance the fearsome spectacle of a ruthless killing behemoth with the story of a broken man trying to reconcile his cowardice. While the movie may have the occasional dragged out slow down, but it still manages to set the stakes for a cathartic finale.

So amazing. Great combination of OG Godzilla, Legendary Godzilla, and a twist of Godzilla only TOHO could give us. So well done. Definitely one of my favorite Godzilla movies ever. Must see for any Gojira fan.
Amazing. I enjoyed this movie. Felt very fresh. The emotional rollercoaster this movie bestows is great. The action packed sequences, the destruction all amazing.

I have loved godzilla as a kid and my first Godzilla movie was Godzilla 2000 and it's still my favorite. Watching Godzilla minus one took me back to when I was younger and made me realize why he is my favorite movie character. Godzilla minus one shows the terror, destruction, emotions, and so much more. This movie made me tear up so many times and made me care for the characters that no other Godzilla movies has ever done for me. Highly recommend this movie! It's definitely in my top 3 Godzilla movies of all time.
absolute masterpiece. The best Godzilla movie since the original. Toho should be proud of this. I cried, I felt anger, I empathized, I felt fear and dread.

First Godzilla movie where the characters were just as interesting to watch as the main monster. The characters had depth and developed through the film and Godzilla (as usual) never disappointed when he was on screen. Toho has made, what I believe, there best Godzilla film since the original back in 1954.

A cinematic masterpiece, it's dark, it had great human characters, great pacing and story, great action scenes, and arguably the scariest and most badass Godzilla in the whole entire franchise, definitely a must see in theaters and its one of the best films in the franchise and its on par with the 1954 original.
Great character development, really made me invested in the story. Way better take on the story then the recent American versions.
A Godzilla movie with characters and a story you actually care about, perhaps even more than seeing Godzilla. But, the Godzilla parts are epic and kind of terrifying.

Story 100/10. Depiction of the aftermath of WWII 1000/10. Absolutely perfect timing for BGM! 100000/10. Honestly,  this is probably one of the best movies made for 2023, and I hope more Godzilla movies by the same director are made.
Amazing! Godzilla doesn't play in this one. He's an unstoppable, killing machine.

Its one best Godzilla movie since Shin Godzilla. The story was great, the charters were well written, CGI was pretty good for a low budget film, and Godzilla was very scary. I highly recommend to see this film if you can stomach the subtitle and trust me, this film is worth it.
The human plot is an Oscar worthy film on its own. Godzilla is added in as a perfect emulsion.  Takashi Yamazaki has done to Godzilla what Christopher Nolan did to Batman.  Perfect.

No need to go into great detail here...this movie is fantastic. I felt like a 12-year old again watching this.  The visual effects are stunning and the human story was better than any in the 70-year series.  Definitely a big-screen watch.

Absolutely my favorite Godzilla movie of all time! 
It truly captures the best visual representation of Godzilla to date.  Everything from the crisp clear CGI, the portrayal of power, the fear invoking unbridled nature of the beast, the ferocity, the aura of invincibility all come together beautifully.   And that is just the King of Monsters by himself.  Add the most interesting human character development and storyline of any of its over 30 movies and its an absolute chef's kiss!!! You truly have to experience this one in IMAX!  I'll be seeing this one again!!!  A love letter to fans of Gojira with the best elements of previous films.  Go see this!!!
What a fun movie! It's not perfect, but it is awesome! This movie has a lot of heart which I did not expect.

Probably the best Kaiju movie that's ever been released. It also has the most compelling human storyline to ever appear in a godzilla movie. The most amazing cinematography. It truly felt like I was on the edge of my seat for the entire movie
best movie I've seen in a long time
Easily one of the best Godzilla films
Godzilla back to form.  Amazing and heartbreaking characters with the reality of a post war country in disarray
Must seea!!!!! Absolutely brilliant film. Phenomenal story, solid character development and ok special effects. It was great to see Godzilla back to his old ways again!

Being a long time Godzilla fan I was hoping for a good Godzilla movie. I instead after watching had to contend with the fact that this is just plainly a good movie.

It has a great story excellent acting and poignant themes that keep you interested as well as pulling off some heart stopping suspense and amazing action scenes.

Making this an Exceptionally Excellent Godzilla film and a great film overall I've recommended all my friends go see it.
As a childhood fan of the original movies I felt they connected well with the audience in true Traditional Godzilla formula.
Pretty much right up there with ’54.
This was a true masterpiece of a Godzilla film. Godzilla himself looked absolutely amazing. Toho has really come a long way and the story itself was very memorable!

Nostalgic! If you liked the old original Japanese version of Godzilla, this movie will take you back in time. The destruction, the storytelling, and unified effort to combat a monster during a time when modern technology was still on the rise is all in this movie.  I loved it. I also appreciate the nod to history and how the Japanese people had to struggle to survive and repair their cities post-WW2. This is a great addition to a timeless classic! Bravo!

I’m really not sure what the critics are watching but it wasn’t the same movie I saw. Pretty terrible. Pacing was off, story was okay but strange editing choices. Acting was… weird. Just strange, didn’t feel like genuine human reactions at many points, made me laugh for than feel anything. Props to the actors you can tell they are really trying their hardest. But man… just BAD lol. It had a couple (literally about 3) good lines and scenes. Characters make dumb decisions, not enough Godzilla, just a HUGE disappointment. I really would not recommend this to anyone.

A new bar has been set for monster films. A instant classic in the genre. A beautiful character driven film with the most terrifying Godzilla we've ever seen as a backdrop to the story. Cinematography, music, acting, even the CGI is all top notch. This is a must watch for all kaiju film fans as well as fans of all Japanese cinema.
This movie is actually amazing! If not almost perfect. You actually care about the human characters this time around , unlike the WB monsterverse movies. - Go out and support this movie in theaters!
What did I like?  EVERYTHING!

This is a proper Godzilla movie and probably one of the best in the entire series. I would say that if you or your kids don’t mind to read subtitles (not an issue with anime fans), the whole family can go and see this and have a great time!
It was good. Kept you interested the whole movie. Nice balance between the story interest of the pilot and  Godzilla
One of the finest Gojira movies I've seen.
This is the best Godzilla movie I’ve ever watched on screen. A true masterpiece by Takashi Yamazaki that actually feels and looks like an updated version of the original. A must see for all fans.
It was a fun time at the movies for sure a great Kaiju movie, loved the actual monster he showed out  🌊🤟🏻

Wow!  Just finished G-1 in IMAX and wow what a movie!  Godzilla has saved the movie going experience with what us easily the best movie of the year. They even gave us IMAX Godzilla Minus One movie posters. What an experience!!!!!  Awesome pulse pounding movie with great acting special effects and that musical score and sound effects. Hollywood please take notes!

The main character has top tier acting. Probably the most talented actor I've seen in a while. The human plot is so well done and gets you so invested. The movie does an amazing job of capturing the damages and destruction Godzilla causes. The first design had me a little worried but once I saw Godzillas true look, it was in awe. They did an absolutely amazing job with the design and effects that it really made Godzilla horrifying. I hope to see more from Toho soon!

After seeing this at the early screening I can say this is my favorite Godzilla movie and in my top 5 movies. Finally a movie that isn't just a fun monster movie but an in depth character study and period piece that lives up if not improves upon the original. The arc of Koichi learning to live is beautiful and perfectly fits the story and the time period. While the effects are a bit clunky at the for a 15 million dollar movie it rivals some 300 million dollar movies.
A total must-see! It was a rollercoaster of emotions and a lot of beautiful visuals! One of the best Godzilla movies ever!

This has to be one the THE BEST Godzilla movies Ive seen. The story was heartbreaking and I actually cared about the human characters. Godzilla looked incredible and was actually terrifying and had some amazing destruction scenes.

This movie was a Masterpiece! definitely go watch it. the acting was superb and Godzilla was just pure evil! there were some parts that were really sad and some people were actually tearing up. the movie got a standing ovation 👏. will be watching it again it's only going to be in theaters for a week only so if you get a chance GO WATCH THIS MOVIE! 🍿
Saw it last night it was very well put together, the action was great the humans in the movie were very great it was like watching Godzilla of old but up to date it truly is a great film

Godzilla fans will be well pleased with this reimaged origin story. I saw it at the IMAX screen. It has a good story, a little of Godzilla Raids again story line here. (how the Japanese fight Godzilla) The tormented lead character is played well by the actor. I dare say non-Godzilla fans will like this movie just for the story . Oh yeah, Godzilla's frickin' AWESOME in the movie. Damn ,2 thumbs way up!!!!

If it aint the best Godzilla movie to come out since the original, its close in the runnings. This is the movie that casual fans and movie goers can jump into and do so along side the crowd who fell in love with the people in rubber suits. Fair warning, watch the trailers for the movie. Its the majority of the movie minus the final act. How you feel during that minute and a half trailer is how you are going to feel the entire 2 hour runtime. By the time the credits hit, you will be exhausted, and the movie will run rent free in your head the rest of your night. See it as early as possible if you want to see it with the fans of the big guy for all these decades. Wait for the applause that will come from the crowded theater at the end. 

The story will keep you invested. The pain you feel, will be along side the characters who might face death at a moments notice when they are not trying to rebuild not just their lives, but their broken selves. Godzilla is a money shot every frame he is on that camera. The cinematography and the sound editing is insanely pulled through. it was like the director had a sense of playfulness with his vision for maximum impact. There is a double usage of Godzilla's original theme for his rampage, but each use is done differently, with the music pushing on a sense of beautiful irony as we get to our climactic moment. Even more interesting is its multitude of themes. Themes are very prevalent in this movie. You have failure and shame, sins of the past. What dictates a family? A subtle hint at the end of Samurai culture as they tackle the notion of self sacrifice for the greater good and how as a nation they should look forward. A strong anti-war message. In my view, a smaller one is this is a movie made by the grandsons of those alive during that time. the ones who felt the effects of the ending of WW2 Japan. The original 1950's movie was a sense of a nation processing the atom bomb. This movie is the next generations message going forward while looking at their own past.
This movie was made for true G-fans! From the storyline to the visuals. Absolutely fantastic!

Godzilla Minus One is a masterpiece, surpassing even Godzilla 1954 in my opinion. I consider it the best Godzilla film ever made. Effectively, it serves as a perfect remake of the 1954 classic, devoid of 1950s American film restrictions for Japanese film. It sets out to tell a story of loss and hope, narrating it in such a masterful way that you become attached to the characters without the need for language. You could enter this film with no prior knowledge of its plot and emerge utterly stunned.

As a Godzilla fan, I anticipated greatness, but what I experienced left me so awe-struck that I found myself unable to speak for a good 20 minutes. Every aspect of the film, from the setting, tone, characters, sound design, soundtrack, cinematography, to the visual effects, surpasses my ability to articulate how amazing it was, especially when watching it in IMAX.

What truly blows my mind is its modest budget of 15 million dollars. It efficiently utilizes every dollar, or technically, yen, so well that I find it challenging to return to most Western entertainment without noticing flaws. It genuinely brings joy to identify myself as a Godzilla fan."

And if America does not award it in some way Hollywood is surly tone def - Tony

I am a Godzilla fan, so all comments should be taken with that in mind.  This movie met my every expectation.  The characters are engaging, the story is clear, and the threat of the monster feels believable. There is a touch of melodrama, but given the setting and the events it would understandable that emotions run high.  The characters delve a little into simplification and trope, but this is a movie about a giant lizard, so accuracy should be tempered.  There is an elaborate plan to destroy the monster that is in keeping with Godzilla history, but nothing that is "hokey".  The acting is a little old fashioned, but feels true to the historical setting.  The visuals are wonderful.  It is clear that they are NOT billion dollar, but they are very good, and in some ways had a better gut feeling.  There may have been some practical model work, or a concerted effort to reach that look (depth of field?) as an homage.  There are few clear homages to the original Godzilla and some other movies, but nothing distracting.  There are few scenes of Big G in action that were quite brutal in his effect on a recovering Japanese population.  His smaller size in comparison to recent movies works better for this movie. There is some interesting point-of-view camera work that went a long way to giving you the feeling of experiencing it firsthand. The fact that it is subtitles only occurred to me the next day, so clearly that did not distract. I do prefer this over dubbing. 
Overall a great effort by all involved. I highly recommend for the casual or diehard fan.  You will not be disappointed.  Some one who has no experience with Godzilla (do such people exist?) may come away wondering what all the fuss is about.
Godzilla: Minus One will go down in history for be one of the greatest, if not the greatest Godzilla movie of all time.

Toho returns Godzilla to its atomic roots with a story line that PREDATES the original 1954 film. The human drama reminded me of some of the early Akira Kirosawa films, and the monster footage delivers in spades. I am one of those long-time fans who still feels Shin Godzilla is one of the series best. This film is at least as good as that one, and at times perhaps better. MINUS ONE manages to bring the character back to its original storyline, but still manages to feel refreshing and even frightening at times. I think the people behind most of the original series (especially Ishiro Honda) would be proud of this film if they were still with us. HIGHLY, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

As lifelong fan of Godzilla, I already had high expectations for Godzilla Minus One. Let me tell you, this movie did not disappoint. I'm certainly not one to love a Godzilla movie just because of franchise loyalty. I'm not afraid to criticize a Godzilla movie, however, I don't think I have any criticisms of this film. 

If I had to describe this movie in one word, it would be ‘Refreshing'. The down-to-earth plot, the genuine fear this movie provoked, the new aspects of Godzilla explored, even the enticing human elements this movie brought with it, Godzilla Minus one was such a refreshing film for the nearly 70 year old running franchise.

With over 30 films under its belt, one might question if there's anything novel a new installment could bring. 'Godzilla Minus One' confidently answers that question with a resounding 'yes.' Godzilla Minus One was a story worth telling and they executed it flawlessly.

This movie is just great. It has a human story as well as tons of destruction! I rewatched Kong vs Godzilla the other day to compare them. Next to Godzilla Minus 1 it's not even a popcorn flick, just a lame story interrupted by, I admit, cool cgi effects. 

Don't get put off by subtitles and japanese language, if you do, you will miss a truly great (monster) movie.
My favorite Godzilla movie, a very grounded (as much as a giant kaiju movie can be) and emotional story that is easy to connect with

Wow! I would rank this as one of my top five favorite films of 2023! I was lucky enough to catch a fan event, pre-screening. 

Just from watching the previews, I had a feeling that it was going to be well-worth watching in a theater because of its production quality. What I did not expect was that it was going to be a high-stakes drama. This movie is gripping, heart-wrenching, quite frightening, and more suspenseful than anything I expected. If I tried to compare it to another movie it would have to be watching the original Jaws for the first time. (There is one scene in particular when Godzilla is pursuing our hero who is in his worn-out tub of a minesweeper.) But this was even better than that!

The director does an excellent job of sucking you into the horror and sadness of post-war Japan. It only took a few minutes for me to become heavily invested in the hero, and then each of the side characters: his found-family and friends. The director also gives you the origin of Godzilla, and you can actually sense the difference in energy between his original and final form. Godzilla is furious, vicious, violent and horrific. The violence in the film does not feel gratuitous - you are going to experience the shock and horror of the victims (the airplane mechanics, the people in Ginza, the unfortunates on the various ships, and the PTSD the hero has from his encounters with Godzilla). Unlike the Godzilla movies from the 60's on, you aren't going to be able to savor the mayhem quite so much, unless you lack human empathy.

If you are going just to see Godzilla, you won't be disappointed though. Wow. He is monstrous. The graphics of him destroying Ginza are incredible, but it is when he is at sea that I found him to be the most frightening. On land, it seems like there is a chance to get away from him. At sea, it is a different story entirely. 

And finally. There is a more realistic quality to this movie than the vast majority of monster movies. In particular, I liked how the plan they come up with to battle Godzilla. It felt thoughtful and possible.

Great Fun! Don't pass up the chance to watch it in the theater!
As a fan who has seen every Godzilla movie, Godzilla Minus One takes everything great in the past entry’s and expands upon it. The movie definitely deserves a 100% rating.

Best Godzilla film to date. Perfect blend of monster meets man. The human side of the movie was a gut punch that you couldn't look away from, nor wanted to look away from. The characters were well written and real. No one felt safe from the destruction, and the relationships between characters tugged heartstrings. Let's not forget the biggest part of the movie, Godzilla. By far the most terrifying and stunning version of the monster to date. The special effects and look of this were fanominal. When first seeing the big G in action for the first time I could only stare slackjawed. This movie made me feel all the emotions and showed no mercy. A real love letter to fans and to film making. Too, thank you so much for this.

Godzilla: A Captivating Enigma of Destruction with a Stellar Score

Godzilla, the iconic king of the monsters, has captivated audiences for decades with its awe-inspiring size and destructive power. While many fans adore the creature as a symbol of nature's untamed might, others view it as a mindless force of destruction devoid of any redeeming qualities. This film, however, manages to strike a delicate balance between these opposing perspectives, revealing the creature's enigmatic nature while also highlighting the plight of the human characters caught in its path.

From the outset, the film establishes Godzilla as an unpredictable force of nature, its actions driven by primal instincts rather than any discernible logic. Its destruction is not motivated by malice, but by a desperate need for survival and a yearning for connection. This enigmatic nature is precisely what makes Godzilla so captivating, keeping audiences on the edge of their seats and wondering what it will do next.

At the same time, the film does not neglect the human element, portraying the characters as complex individuals struggling to survive in the face of unspeakable devastation. Their desperation to avoid Godzilla's wrath and their resilience in the face of overwhelming odds underscore the creature's immense power and the profound fear it inspires.

The film's masterstroke lies in its ability to balance these two perspectives, allowing audiences to appreciate Godzilla's enigmatic nature while also empathizing with the plight of the human characters. This delicate balance elevates the film from mere monster-bashing spectacle to a profound exploration of the delicate balance between destruction and compassion.

Furthermore, the film's score deserves special mention. The music is both epic and emotional, perfectly capturing the film's themes of destruction and resilience. The score is one of the best I've heard in any film this year, and it greatly enhances the overall viewing experience.

In conclusion, Godzilla is a captivating film that succeeds in capturing both the allure of the enigmatic beast and the struggles of the human characters caught in its path. Its ability to balance these two perspectives, coupled with its stellar score, makes it a must-see for fans of the genre and newcomers alike.

Rating: 5 out of 5 stars

I will say these characters are quite on pair with the Original 54 movie and that's a huge achievement with this movie. When Godzilla shows up and see the destruction he leaves, it was just perfect and it really shows the embodiment of what Godzilla really is. The music was perfect with all the moments and the graphics is superb. Overall, I give this movie a 10 out of 5 if I had to. This is a perfect movie for both G Fans and Non-G Fans. Please go and watch this movie!!!
An homage to the original classic. Slight changes from original but they add more complexity to the overall symbolism and narrative that is the Godzilla universe. Well done.

In a world full of movies like The Marvels, and The Flash, Japan comes out and absolutely demolishes American cinema by giving us the most enticing movie that in some ways, surpasses the original Gojira, Ishrio Honda would be absolutely proud.
You don't have to be a fan of Godzilla to enjoy this movie. It has a solid storyline, minus the glitz and corny one-liners that you'd find in a Hollywood production.
Absolutely stunning! The entire movie was a spectacular masterpiece! The story and humans were wonderfully written while Godzilla himself was terrifying but also so damn cool! 10/10

My family and I saw an early showing last night. It was fantastic! Godzilla was the scariest in any movie I've ever seen and the Japanese theme and subtitles was the most authentic as well.  The acting was a little bad but that also makes it more authentic to the original Godzilla movies. Absolutely loved i!

I've been watching Godzilla for 50 years. It's a coin toss as to whether this film or Godzilla (54) is the best. For a modern audience I'd have to give the nod to Godzilla -1
This is a much different experience than the current Legendary series. Plenty of call backs for longtime fans while at the same time this should be a great film for general audiences. I think Honda,Tanaka and Tusburaya would give Godzilla -1 a big thumbs-up.

Excellent movie - It is a great origin story and hopefully a great reboot for more Godzilla movies from Toho.  A perfect 70th anniversary piece.  I was totally invested in all of the characters and loved the ending.

I need more of this!  Hollywood can learn a thing or two about how to make a movie.
Great new twist on the original, with great focus on the characters and how WWII affected them.

I thoroughly enjoyed the movie.  Loved the incorporation of the original music score.  Even use of the original Godzilla roar.  The story pulls you in.  You actually care about the characters having to deal with not only Godzilla, but trying to recover after WWII.  I hope they let the director continue on with his vision.  The ending definitely sets up for a continuation.  Went to two early access screenings on Wednesday.  Plan to see it again in IMAX.  Sadly, no Dolby Atmos theater around me that is playing it.
All Hail and Bravo to this Monumental and Spectacular Epic of a Movie…
Absolutely beautiful. An amazing score, beautiful vfx and amazing characters that you care about, with motivations and flaws. 10/10

I've been dedicated fan of Gojira for all of my 21 years of being on this planet, I have seen all the highs and lows this series has to offer, from its campy moments, to the beautiful scores, haunting moments, and awesome action. So when I put in perspective how genuinely refreshing this movie was for an long time fan to see both the monster, its meaning in nuclear symbolism,  and its human characters all being both grounded in a gritty yet emotional focus, and still remember its a godzilla movie at its core. The king of the monsters has truly come back with a vengeance and I implore anyone, fan, critic, or average movie goer, give Minus One your time, this film is a master class and a frightening amazing experience. LONG LIVE THE KING!
Capturing the terror that Godzilla still hold is step one. Giving you a fantastic group of humans that you WANT to win, step two. Heat Ray, three. What a fantastic film to keep 70 years going strong.
Absolutely incredible. Nice feeling a sense of dread seeing him in action.
third time seeing it and it just gets better, pays so much homage to the original 1954 movie as well as some others. second best if not the best Godzilla movie
Pretty much the perfect Godzilla movie - the monster action and destruction is amazing, but the human story is also really compelling and touching.
Almost everything I’ve wanted to see in a Godzilla film since I was a child!

Godzilla is a destructive force of nature that crushes everything and everyone in its path, without cause, without reason, without regard. The combination of Akira Ifukube's powerful music and Naoki Sato's terrifying strings makes you shiver with pleasure when it's time to stomp and annihilate. Godzilla Minus One manages to constantly catapult you into a perpetual feeling of helplessness in the face of the inevitable. Godzilla Minus One is the best movie since the 1954 Godzilla.
The best use of humans in the entire franchise and probably the coolest versuon of Godzilla yet.
definitely a great godzilla movie that needs to be seen on the big screen, the human characters were actual likeable and godzilla was a threat that was felt

This was emphatically the greatest Godzilla movie ever made. Such beautiful and compelling story telling. Beautiful cinematography. Relatable and empathetic characters. Amazing special effects. And most of all, the most terrifying and gruesome and believable rendition of Godzilla ever portrayed on the big screen. This whole film I could find no flaw.
The Godzilla movie I’ve been waiting 20 years for!!   Go see it in an IMAX theatre. It’s  more visceral watching Godzilla in action. Absolutely loved it!  Going again!

Godzilla Minus One WAS PERFECTION! Blending classic Godzilla with Modern action and visuals to create something so memorable, emotional, and haunting! Godzilla is a force more than ever and the story couldn't have been more touching. This took my breath away!

For starters the humans are some of, if not, THE BEST IN ANY GODZILLA FILM!! The story and journey these characters go through feel earned and by the end of the film, you feel and care for each and everyone of them!

Godzilla was an absolute FORCE TO BE RECKONED WITH! His atomic breath might actually be my new favorite of the franchise. The ocean scene kept me frozen! He was haunting, extremely powerful, and looked phenomenal. Which leads me to talking about the effects, leaving the theater… all I could think about was the saddest part of watching that film was knowing that it probably won't get the recognition it deserves come award season, ESPECIALLY FOR ITS EFFECTS! The CGI/visual effect were all polished. NOT ONCE did it dip in quality!

The score for this film was beyond beautiful, touching at times. I got emotional just by music queues multiple times during the film. At times it was bone chilling, hype, and gut wrenching. Other times, seat clenching and even had elements/full tracks from the original!

It was emotional, action packed, had a beautiful story, gorgeous visuals, and brisk pacing that never dragged. Godzilla is the monster we all hoped for with humans that felt TANGIBLE. This is one for the ages and I mean that with ZERO HESITATION, actually… MINUS ONE!

I highly recommend seeing this in theaters as soon as possible but PLEASE MAKE SURE ITS ON THE BIGGEST SCREEN YOU CAN FIND!

I saw this movie in Japan and again in the United States in iMax. This movie is a different type of Godzilla movie than the Legendary movies or the previous Japanese Godzilla movies. This film is much darker and more serious in tone. The acting is some of the best I've ever seen come out of Japan. This iteration of Godzilla is no hero, he's far more primal in nature as well. The main characters, which is a place Godzilla films are usually lackluster, were characters you could get more emotionally attached to than in prior films. I don't want to spoil anything so I'll just leave it at, when I saw this movie in Japan, I didn't expect to experience a theater of people emotionally drained and many crying.
Such a great blend of the more modernized Godzilla, while still giving the movie heart. And everything we love about the orginal.
Easily a top Godzilla movie. Great mix of action and character moments in a post WW2 Japan. Nice visuals, acting and sound. Godzilla here is a force of nature and does not disappoint.

I managed to get tickets for an early access fan screening yesterday, and as a life long Godzilla fan, I can say with EASE that this is in the top 5 Godzilla films ever made. 

A common complain amongst Godzilla fans, and critics in general is that the human characters are often forgettable and cause the film to drag. This movie is the exact opposite. I cared and was invested in nearly every human story introduced . 

Godzilla was the destructive force of nature we've come to expect, and setting it in the backdrop of a real world 1940's where technology is the most limited we've ever seen in a Godzilla film made for one of the most "edge of your seat" Godzilla vs. Humans battles of all time. Do NOT miss this movie. Second best film of the year after Oppenheimer. Who, ironically enough, probably caused Godzilla to wake up...
Movie was AMAZING!!!! Definitely seeing this one again! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!
Best Godzilla movie ever and the BEST movie of 2023 nuff said
