Truly a modern-day masterpiece in film-making and storytelling. Not only were they able to capture the compelling character development of the original 1954 film, but they brought Godzilla back to his horrific roots and made the titular monster scary again. 10/10 well done!

Awesome Godzilla movie, definitely worth seeing it in IMAX. Even if you’re not a Godzilla fan, go see it!
A must watch for any Godzilla fan! even my girl who didn't know what a Godzilla/Gojira was enjoyed it!

Went to an early fan event viewing. Not "fun" because it emulates the serious tone of the original but a thoroughly engaging experience. Also it looks amazing and has great acting and interesting human characters that I was actually rooting for. Made on a 10th of a Hollywood budget and put most modern movies to shame. A refreshing breath of fresh air to know someone still remembers how to make a genre movie.
Possibly the best Godzilla movie, ever.
Best Godzilla movie next to the original.  Visual effects and audio are outstanding and  story well written.

amazing movie , story was so sad , so fulfilling in the end’

Wow EPIC!!! great soundtrack excellent acting emotional rollercoaster will be seeing again soon

Absolute cinema. If you’re a fan of classic Toho Godzilla you WILL have an amazing time, and even if you’re a newcomer you’re probably going to love it as well. Brilliantly written, directed and acted, with a perfect level of monster action and destruction. Can’t find a fault

9/10

It also does a good job of preserving the roots of the original 1950's Godzilla film, complete with the music and also the setting of postwar Japan. Even has a small hint of the cheesiness of the original franchise at times but it's not over the top.

After seeing it early for the fan event, Godzilla Minus One is everything a godzilla movie should be and so much more, everything about this movie from the characters, music, emotion, tension, dread, and especially Godzilla himself are top notch, this is a must watch and likely the best entry into the godzilla series, well deserving of the Kings 70th anniversary!

Godzilla Minus One SPOILER Review

10/-1

At this time I cannot decide if I like minus one better or my old favorite Godzilla against mechagodzilla. First things first, this is by far the best version of Godzilla. I knew as soon as Takashi Yamazaki was making it, the design was going to be amazing just by his Godzilla in its always sunny on third Street. What I didn't expect was everything else. This Godzilla movie is 100% a horror movie. The beginning scene with Godzilla as a more dinosaur like creature was amazing. That's the kind of Godzillasaurus I wanted to see. His atomic breath is awesome. The spikes coming out and going in was fine. I didn't like it any more or any worse that the normal glowing spikes, but the atomic breath itself is beautiful. With Godzilla being the metaphor for the bombing of Japan, his atomic breath actually creating a nuke like explosion was a perfect touch I didn't realize Godzilla needed. And his death at the end was the second best Godzilla death in my opinion. Nothing can beat heisei melting down. Now the actual plot. Unlike most Godzilla films, this movie has one of the best character driven story's. It's stars a Kamikaze pilot who pretended that his plain was broken to skip out on dying. The twist and turns his story had were so compelling, I almost forgot about Godzilla. His later to be wife's death I saw coming, but it later being revealed to fake, with her actually surviving was the biggest twist in this movie. There where many small nods to older Godzilla films that will excite long time fans, but that's not at all what makes this movie good. While I had a heavily bias opinion on the movie, my friend who has only seen shin Godzilla also thought this movie was fantastic. And, of course, every scene with the Godzilla theme is amazing.
A 100% is the lowest score I will accept for this movie.

Overall I think this has a better plot than the Godzilla movies that the MonsterVerse has. I really connected with the characters and like how it was mostly from one persons point of view. I have two main issues with it with one being that the pace should’ve been a little faster and just felt too slow for me. Don’t get me wrong I liked how we got to know the human characters but the pace still could’ve been improved on. My second issue is that there’s hardly any Godzilla. What’s the point of this being a Godzilla movie if theres hardly  any Godzilla?
Freaking amazing. Most interested human story ever in a Godzilla movie.

This is by far the best overall Godzilla movie since the Japanese original. Godzilla is absolutely horrifying in this film. This is the most devastating portrayal of his atomic breath ever. The human story is usually a weakness in these films but here it is a solid, endearing story.
An absolute masterclass from beginning to end that serves almost as a pseudo remake of the original while updating it for modern audiences.

Toho has taken Godzilla back to the basics with a compelling and delectably   destructive story. With great character arcs that make every character feel like they belong. A dire situation that keeps you hoping the heroes win. And a monster you just can't wait to see on the screen again and again as it makes a thunderous and profound mark on the film. Modern blockbusters should take note. This is how you make a movie worth seeing in the theaters.

Absolutely Epic. Like the Japanese original, only 1000000x better in every way. The 2nd best Godzilla creature ever. Sorry, the new US Godzilla is Bonkers awesome. But.... So is this one. What a time to be a KOTM fan. 1000 Stars

It is the best Godzilla movie you probably will ever watch. I've seen almost every Godzilla movie I like or love almost every one of them but none of them compare to this movie. It's strong character movie. It's like old Godzilla meets new Godzilla. It takes place back in World War II times, but you have the special effects of modern day so you get the best of both worlds of Godzilla …you should see this I saw it in IMAX … I hope you get the chance to also .
It has been years since I saw a movie this intense and amazing. A must watch.

I'm not sure it deserves to be 100% but it was entertaining, great special effects, fantastic acting from the principal actors and actually did something Oppenheimer failed to do: show the devastation and aftermath of the h bomb dropped on Japan. I enjoyed the secondary storyline immensely. And even if you don't take any of that into consideration, Godzilla eats a freakin train! In my opinion that trumps everything.

Hands down best Godzilla movie since the original, and frankly the best movie of the year.  I was in awe of the imagery, and Godzilla was truly a spectacle.  Gritty and emotional, every scene with Godzilla felt ironically personal. The human story was heartbreaking and also endearing.  As a life long fan, I am grateful for the respect shown for this iconic monster.  Visually so impressive with a raw human element that finally really works not seen since the first film.  Dare I say it might even get a few awards or noms.

There was a great deal of character development in the movie. A country still recovering from WWll, the spirit of the movie was about recovery and wrestling with fear. When faced with destruction once again by the ravages of Godzilla, the people draw close to take on an impossible task. There was a great deal of tension between the two main characters, and you expect a romance to bud. But due to personal battles concerning the war, the romance is not fully realized. Really heartbreaking at one point. But not giving anything away, the movie does not leave you disappointed as they battle Godzilla and deal with the demons of the past. I would say this was more of a drama than a old fashioned Godzilla movie.

Excellent movie, with exceptional character development and moving story. There were no cheesy bits and was an overall excellent monster movie that happened to have great story telling with good acting. A movie that showed the horros of war and promulgated a succinct commentary on government shortfalls and the perils of nuclear war. My favorite Godzilla movie by far, and a must watch even for non G fans.

This movie was astonishingly surprising. And both as a critic and a Godzilla fan, it was well kept with a very intriguing human story and very well balanced Monster scenery and interaction. This movie defines what Godzilla truly is and what a Godzilla movie in the future or past could and/or should be. A very fantastic movie

The best Godzilla film yet! Amazing twist on the original story. It was deep dealing with WW2 and the atrocities of nuclear war and the aftermath of destruction.  https://youtu.be/MUE8iJTXK6Q?si=bk1MW8NRtal6qQZi
This movie is a must see

I just finished seeing it and I loved it, it was honestly very good and Godzilla was ruthless and that was needed. I miss the evil Godzilla and this delivered, it almost got me tearing up at some parts.







Spoiler: the way they almost killed Godzilla with a inflatable was kinda funny

Amazing! Godzilla has some real attitude in this one. It's almost the complete opposite of shin godzilla and yet still manages to be on par with it. Solid 10/10 that I want to spoil so bad but won't. Definetly a must see and will be added to my collection once it's available.
amazing movie, not just for a godzilla movie but, in general, an amazing movie

Instant Classic!!! A Masterpiece!!! The Performances were Exceptional. Even if you are a Die-Hard Godzilla fan, you find yourself rooting for the supporting cast. This Godzilla is Truly Menacing!!!⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Words cannot explain how incredible and amazing this movie truly was. It had characters you cared for and a sad heartfelt story that keeps you satisfied while Godzilla is off screen. When he is on screen however is when this film reaches another level. The greatest movie I've seen this year thus far! 10/10!

Just returned from an Imax Screening, really good cinematography in this one, not as much action as Shin Godzilla/Monsterverse movies, but Godzilla's attack on Tokyo is very intense, and the human portion of the story is arguably the best Ive seen in any Godzilla film. Its a very good sorta remake of Gojira.

Absolutely incredible. Not just a good Godzilla movie, but a good movie in general. Fantastic acting, gorgeous cinematography, and an emotional story. What about the big guy? He was downright terrifying. Ferocious, and truly felt like a force of nature. From his first scene, to the last Godzilla delivered on the spectacle one would expect. Absolutely brilliant.

Great action and storytelling, this Godzilla movie actually has a very well thought out storyline and makes the characters very interesting and likable. There is also just enough character screen time and Godzilla screen time and pacing was great. This movie is a must watch even if your not a big Godzilla fan and i feel could be close to movie of the year, go see it now!

This movie was astonishingly surprising. It was well kept with a very intriguing human story with very well balanced Monster scenery and interaction. This movie defines what Godzilla truly is and what a Godzilla movie in the future or past could and/or should be. A very fantastic movie!
I love it. This was my first Godzilla movie but I was bawling my eyes out with some scenes and felt so many emotions that not many movie do. 10/10 would and will see it again

Movie were awesome for the first time in a long time I enjoyed the human element in a Godzilla movie. Love clever, way they did the Easter eggs. And the most important thing, my youngest son 9 year old enjoyed it and he wants to watch it again this weekend.
Must watch in imax to experience the full dread you will feel coursing through your body as Godzilla is on screen.
Best Godzilla film in forever. It truly does the original justice.
Excellent movie. Looked great on the big screen!

Godzilla Minus One is a cinematic masterpiece. It's seriously written like an Oscar nomination film in terms of characterization of the cast. I'm shocked to say this film did the impossible, it's either on the same tier as Gojira (1954) or surpasses it. Sound design was remarkable too. The director did a tremendous job giving us shots and sequences we've never seen before with Godzilla. Easily a 10/10

This is the greatest Godzilla movie of the modern era. 

No shade thrown at the Legendary pictures, they're a completely different monster, pun partially intended, but this Godzilla proves that you don't need to keep making the kaiju bigger for them to be terrifying. From his first appearance early in the film to the heart-pounding climax, this Godzilla is closer to the humans he terrorizes than any since the original 1954 classic. The difference in scale creates a completely different kind of dread - something in between a colossal apex predator and a force of nature.

The people in this film, for maybe the first time in the history of Godzilla movies, steal the show. Godzilla is the backdrop against which post-WWII Japan struggles with the horrors and guilt inherent in survival of mass destruction and whether or not those who came home from war ever truly stopped fighting it. Koichi Shikishima and his found family challenge the audience to do more than simply keep surviving.

I have seen many different iterations of Godzilla over the decades. Minus One is the most successful version since the original King of the Monsters to tell the story of nuclear horror and how humankind has to be willing to do more than fight to the death; they need to find the strength to live.

I just arrived home after watching the early screening. Brilliant on every level - human, monster, metaphoric, every level.  You care about the main characters, their emotional trauma, and their motivations. This is an angry Godzilla and it works because Godzilla is a metaphor for the cruelty and senselessness of war.
Best Godzilla best sound
A once in a generation film. Absolutely incredible. One of the greatest monster films of all time.
If Oppenheimer didn’t release this year, Godzilla Minus One would be the film of the year. This I can say is absolutely better than a masterful film like Dunkirk. This is true Cinema!

First Godzilla movie I’ve ever seen and definitely one of the best movies I’ve seen. Everyone clapped at the end and I heard people talking about how good it was on the way out/ 100% on rotten tomatoes too. A testament to just how good this movie is.

One of the best Godzilla movies I have seen. I was hesitant about the human storyline, but it was intertwined throughout the film very well and compelling enough to keep you engaged. Godzilla was awesome as usual. A must watch and great addition to the franchise.

Saw the movie in a Dolby Cinema theater and it was absolutely top tier. I highly suggest you see this in at least IMAX or Dolby, as the sound experience is next level. The human story really drives home the theme of fighting to live and not wasting life, along with the messages learned from WW2 (PTSD, regret, etc). The human interactions really made this movie worth seeing, and Godzilla is the vessel we see through. Then when you focus on Godzilla, his class theme song, roar, and the heat ray/nuclear blast is eye & ear candy. The only nitpick I have is that some CGI is a little weird with him and the backgrounds/cities. Overall, no complaints, 10/10.

I am not a fan of monster movies. My husband is a huge Godzilla fan so I followed along, thinking I'd have a nice nap during the movie. I was so wrong. The story is captivating and moving. Got to go to the early access screening for an IMAX showing. I am so happy! They made a great Godzilla movie and for only $15 million!!! Disney, take notes! You don't need to spend $200-$300 million to make great entertainment. You need talented and passionate people. This movie has a great and well told story, you actually care about the human characters in this. Direction and cinematography were great, the performances were good, heck the visuals were good! This is how you make a Godzilla movie. See this movie in a theater on the biggest screen you can find. Yes you have to read subtitles, who cares! You can still enjoy what this movie brings to the table. I can't wait to see this again in a few days. Thank you Toho for delivering on this movie! One of the best movies of 2023 by far.

Amazing Great. Entertaing

Great take on Godzilla. The storyline is compelling, the beast is fantastic. Easily among the best in the long series.

This movie is a real tear jerker. There's a lot of humanity shown in this movie, and the fear of being helpless is really so dramatic. Godzilla truly sets the fear in this movie, all the way to the end. Spicy It was magnificent, despite being lower budget the effects were quite amazing.
Was a very satisfying and fulfilling spectacular movie!!!!

The movie really surprised me. Godzilla actually feels monstrous. He was actually terrifying and felt like a force of nature when on the screen. Additionally, the human part of the story was not just the Godzilla waiting room, the story was engaging and I came to really care about what would happen to the cast of characters. Easily one of the best experiences I've had watching movies in 2023.
One of my favorite movies of all time. Ive now seen it ten times

OMG, that was probably the most exciting movie I ever watched, for some reason the 2 hours of this movie keep you wanting more and wishing it never ends! The acting, the effects everything was so amazing. I would say more but I don't want to spoil the movie. It's a must watch and I hope it gets a great support from the audience, but for sure it worth watching it in th biggest screen possible to enjoy it at the fullest! Highly recommend!

I'm am not exaggerating at all when I say that this is one of the best movies ever made. This is considering all genres and franchises. One of THE BEST movies of all time. 

There really isn't a single bad thing I have to say about Godzilla Minus One. The CGI and other effects are great, the human story is the best in any Godzilla movie so far, the action sequences are unparalleled, and the way it all blends together is perfect. This movie deserves every single nomination it got in the Hochi Film Awards.
One of the greatest Godzilla films ever made and one of the best films released this year.

Japanese cinema has done what Hollywood has been unable to do: make an entertaining film with real human characters, real human story arcs, great action and a compelling story. Applause, tears, excitement - the audience was enthralled by this. Not another cookie cutter super hero movie or blockbuster. No ridiculous story line or empty characters. Godzilla minus one is how movies should be made.

Best Godzilla movie I've seen in years! The atomic beam is the coolest. How the dorsal plates pop out right before nuking the entire city! And that one boat scene where the boat explodes! Great movie! Would come for part 2

After the first watch, this movie might be my favorite Godzilla movie of all time. Great acting, good plot and the pacing was great. Never at any point during the movie did i ever feel bored. Godzilla feels terrifying in this adaptation, especially when we first see him. Not only is this movie scary but it also does an amazing job at portraying post WW2 Japan. You can feel the desperation and depression in the characters throughout the movie. Overall I feel like it has a great mix of everything you would want in a movie and would definitely recommend it.

Loved it - one of the best Godzilla films. All of the flavor of the 50's-70's films, with characters that you actually grow to care about. Absolutely worth the popcorn and springing for IMAX if you can find it.

Other than the CGI not being great but also not horrendous, this was an overall entertaining story. I think unlike most, I’m not a big fan of a Godzilla that has no purpose and therefore is nothing more than a destructive force aimlessly reducing villages, towns, and cities to rubble. But I get and can appreciate the metaphor.

-Amazing Story
-Great Special Effects
-Great Acting
-Epic Score
My Favorite film of 2023!!!

This is the best solo Godzilla film since it's 1954 original film. It was very well balanced out between the human characters and the Kaiju himself and the story was very post-war feel, especially for the citizens of Japan and what the hardship they went through in the aftermath.
Great movie and story.

Godzilla Minus One director Takashi Yamazaki has done it… the film is a triumph! 

Yamazaki's mastery of VFX shines through in this latest Godzilla movie, seamlessly blending astonishing visuals with a gripping human story. This entry into the Godzilla franchise reads like a dramatic period piece with a monster horror element. All the actors deliver heartfelt, meaningful performances that connected me to their characters like no other Godzilla film has before.

I truly believe Minus One will be remembered as an important piece of kaiju movie history. Its a movie that celebrates the endurance of the human spirit and our ability to evolve when thrust into the chaos of conflict while remaining accessible to both fans and newcomers alike.
I am Japanese. I saw it in a Japanese movie theater and am typing using the translation. I think there's a good chance that people who love Godzilla will enjoy it.
Godzilla minus one is absolute fantastic🔥💯🔥
